		<date>2015-04-10</date>
		<username>czarinaanya</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Good thriller with two strong female leads</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I like this thriller. Maybe it's a "girl power" thing. But I think it is a good entertaining movie. Maybe not the most unpredictable plot out there, but good for a Sunday with nothing else to do. i could do with a bit less gore and a LOT less F bombs but with a movie that has other aspects that make me like it enough, I can look past that. I want to address a few recurring complaints I have seen in other reviews. For one, GET OVER Kristen steward's "boyish" look. The comment "didn't know at first if it was a boy or girl" is a common comment in reviews I've read. When she started filming panic room she had just finished shooting a movie where she plays a girl that looks like (and is mistaken for) a boy. Thats why her hair is so short in this movie. (obviously she chose to really cut it rather than use a wig). Get over it. It's not that big of a deal and there's a very logical explanation behind it. If you don't want spoilers click off of this review right now. Also some have talked about the "unrealistic" depiction of diabetes. You want unrealistic, watch Con Air, where a character claims he'll die without his insulin in a short time. (Unlikely.) In panic room it IS realistic that Stewart, a type 1 diabetic who is thin, is prone to low blood sugar in times of stress. She probably took a little extra insulin because she drank extra coke (watch the pizza scene where Foster tells her to go easy on the soda but then ultimately pours her more). Taking her insulin like she should (and a little extra maybe) WOULD put her at risk of dangerously low sugar if there is something unexpected like missing her next meal, exercising, being under stress. It is realistic, I know Type 1 diabetics who have to stay up all night some nights to monitor their blood sugar because it's too low and won't stay up. Hypoglycemia can go downhill very quickly. And in the "almost coma" scene, Forrest Whittaker is NOT giving her insulin (as someone complained) they are giving her a shot of sugar, most likely glucagon, which diabetics do keep in syringes for emergency and is an appropriate treatment for this situation. It does not have to be given intravenously as someone claimed, and would be easy for someone who doesn't know much about injecting. (He should have cleaned the site first though and it shouldn't have been kept in the fridge but rather room temperature.) The most unrealistic thing about the diabetes storyline is the special monitor she wears on her wrist. From what I understand that technology (especially in 2002) is still very much "in the works" and isn't really "a thing' yet. My last rebuttal to other reviews is the scene where Forrest Whittaker gets arrested and loses all the money. OK maybe you want him to get away with the money because he's not such a bad guy. Im' not saying I felt differently, but I always saw this part of the movie differently. I saw it as a noble sacrifice, like the man in "A tale of Two Cities" who dies so the woman he loves can live happily ever after with the man she loves. In Panic Room, Forrest Whittaker is getting away with the money when he hears and realizes that the mother and daughter are still in danger. He hesitates a split second before going back to help them. I think it's a conscious decision he made, the ultimate sacrifice and redemption, that he KNOWS going back to help them can cost him his escape, but chooses to do it anyway because they're innocent and he can't live with himself if they come to harm. He values their lives over his own freedom. That's why when he does get caught and releases the money into the wind he has a look of resignation. I think he mourns his freedom, family, and the wealth he almost had, but that he knows he did the right thing and that gives him a peace about it all. I think it speaks volumes about what kind of person he really is deep inside. That makes him ultimately my favorite character. LOL I didn't mean to get so philosophical but it is a good movie and well worth the watch on a rainy Sunday without too much else to do.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>jc-osms</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Panic attack</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Director David Fincher has some Hitchcockian ("Rear Window", "Lifeboat" for example) "enclosed-space" fun with this frankly unbelievable thriller set almost entirely within an apartment building in New York as three would-be robbers break into the abode of a rich divorcée and her diabetic daughter to steal millions of dollars worth of bearer bonds. Luckily, this new apartment has a custom-made panic room to keep them safe-ish, but it's also where the loot is hidden. When mother and daughter lock themselves into the sealed compartment, a game of catch as catch can commences between them and the interlopers.Seasoned performers like Jodie Foster and Forrest Whitaker do a commendable job keeping their faces straight acting through ever more unlikely scenes as the film progresses, occasionally with dire dialogue to match, for instance mother hen Josie says to her initially bratty daughter played by a young Kristen Stewart, "It's disgusting how much I love you " the kind of line only a movie mother would utter.Fincher employs every weapon in his armoury to draw in the viewer, with a succession of camera tricks designed to create mini-climax after mini-climax but the premise won't stand it and in the end I just felt battered about the head by all the noise, violence, swearing and supposed high-tension.Besides Foster and Whitaker, the surprise turn in the acting is by country-singer Dwight Yoakum, although quite why he goes through half the film with his face covered escaped me. Maybe he had the measles. You will be amazed too at how he survives getting his hand jammed in a lift door, then getting walloped on the head with a sledge- hammer and falling down a flight of stairs, getting up one last time, as it happens, to swat away Stewart and threaten to cave in Foster's head. It's that kind of movie, ludicrous and crass yet not without some vicarious thrills along the way, but these are overdone and come in too quick succession. In the end then, it's easier to mock than be shocked by what's on display here.Which I'm sure was hardly the director's intention.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2014-12-13</date>
		<username>Red_Identity</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Decent enough</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is certainly not a great film, definitely one of Fincher's lesser efforts and nothing like his most acclaimed films. It's pretty standard, Hollywood stuff, but it's still enjoyable enough, to a degree. It doesn't do anything spectacular, even action0wise or tension-wise and that fault lies in the screenplay. Fincher definitely brings his usual directorial flair, but one can only do so much with a directorial vision when the script still doesn't allow for more. But it's still at least a bit better than The Game, while not as ambitious still doesn't frustrate as much. I hesitantly recommend it, but if one was to skip it it wouldn't be a big deal at all. Foster is strong though, as usual.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Standard Thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*** SPOILERS ***Pretty much what you would expect: A bunch of robbers coming to hit a place they hear has a lot of money (think "In Cold Blood"); a sudden, unwelcome, and ultimately psychotic addition to the team (like any heist movie); a character with a potentially life-threatening condition (lots of movies where someone's trapped); and a single location (like "Bound"). All of this is no surprise since the screenwriter is the untalented David Koepp (who ruined the film version of "Jurassic Park").David Fincher uses lots of camera tricks to try to make the film more interesting, but it is ugly looking like a lot of Fincher movies. Lots of monochromatic interiors, for example. Howard Shore's film score is lifeless and uninteresting, typical of modern film scores.Of course, there are a lot of plot holes, chiefly, everyone's making a TON of noise throughout the movie, and no one hears a thing; we learn the police had been notified, but take an hour to show up; Foster's ex just walks into the brownstone without the police (or anything else) in tow; The former owner just leaves tens of millions of dollars in the safe; wouldn't you leave bearer bonds like that in say, a safe deposit box?Oh well, if you're gonna see it, turn your brain off. At least!****** (6 Out of 10 Stars)</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2012-08-18</date>
		<username>axlrhodes</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Falls somewhere in-between Home Alone and Funny Games.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Through the lens of David Fincher and the pen of David Koepp comes this simplistic, but highly polished home invasion thriller that while being one of it's directors more incidental films, is still a hugely competent effort with more than enough to recommend it by. Meg Altman (Foster) and her daughter Sarah (Stewart) have just moved into their new Manhattan pad. Built into the master bedroom is a state of the art panic room and ? 'whaddya know!?' ? on the first night there's a break in. And so begins the film. Just like in his previous feature film Fight Club, David Fincher cleverly opts for CGI to create some otherwise impossible visuals as the camera prowls and glides around the huge house with an eerie grace prompting some good early tension. Once the break-in happens and we get acquainted with the invaders, some of that tension dissipates, indeed there's one comical moment in which a slightly burned Jared Leto reacts in a way that recalls the bungling burglars of Home Alone , but thanks to a menacing turn from Dwight Yoakam the balance is never tipped too far that way and we're never allowed to fully relax. Like all good survival horror's, Panic Room works like a fun puzzle as it often gives you the opportunity to mull over what you yourself might do in similar circumstances. Good direction makes Panic Room a functional suspense thriller that while in terms of classic status could never be mentioned in the same sentence as Se7en or Fight Club, still helps it stand tall in a long line of the old school Friday night-in popcorn rentals.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Meg Altman is a single mother who is going through a divorce and just moved in separately with her pre teen diabetic daughter Sarah. But things start to become quite tense when they realize that what the burglars are looking for is also in the same room. It takes place 99% inside the mansion and over night. The sequences builds tension minute by minute and every move made by the burglars and the home people becomes tense every time. 		<date>2011-05-03</date>
		<username>Momcat_of_Lomita</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>It's clever, it's well-crafted, it's well-acted, and feels routine.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I guess it's a measure of my respect for Jodie Foster as an actress that I expect more of her and the movies she chooses than a well-made, watchable drama that really doesn't rise above the level of ordinary.It's very watchable, though, and if you're looking for a good popcorn flick for a "girls' night in" evening, this is a movie I'll happily recommend.Jodie Foster and Kristen Stewart bear the weight of this film as Meg Altman and her daughter Sarah Altman, who are the newly-shed ex-spouse and daughter of Stephen Altman (Patrick Bauchau), who is evidently a dirty rotten stinking rich magnate. They are house-hunting in the high-rent district of Manhattan and the realtor they are working with, Lydia Lynch (Ann Magnuson), has a lead on a property that is so new to the market that it isn't even in the listings yet, and so wonderful that it will be snapped up by someone before nightfall.It's the former home of an infirm and reclusive megamillionaire who equipped it with every modern convenience, including a state-of-the-art "panic room": a sort of high-security vault where the residents can stash themselves in the event of a home invasion. When closed, it's impregnable from the outside and equipped with closed-circuit monitoring of all the rest of the house.As the realtor who has the sales listing for this manse shows it to Foster and Stewart, we get the information that the eccentric former owner has recently died, and that he died intestate, and that the heirs are battling over his fortune.Jodie Foster as Meg allows herself to be talked into purchasing the house, and further talked into taking full possession immediately, and she and her daughter move in that very night.Thus starteth the nightmare. It develops that one of the heirs, "Junior" (played by Jared Leto), just happens to know that there is something hidden in the panic room. He wants to get this something and scoop the other heirs. And he has enlisted the assistance of a couple of baddies-buddies to help him get it: Burnham (Forest Whittaker), who works for the company that built the panic room; and Raoul (Dwight Yoakum), whose presence is only necessary as a dramatic device to bring a truly evil, menacing presence to the party.Junior, Burnham and Raoul break into the manse late in the rainy, spooky night and discover that the empty mansion they expected is unexpectedly inhabited. Meg and Sarah are sleeping upstairs. While the baddie-buddies discuss the unexpected development in menacing whispers downstairs, Meg awakens for a late-night potty run. Coming back from the bathroom in a sleepy stupor, she glances at the monitors in the panic room and sees the baddie-buddies up to no good downstairs.With great presence of mind, she manages to rouse her daughter and the two of them dive into the panic room just ahead of the baddies, who have come upstairs to see what can be done. So Meg and Sarah are safely ensconced in the panic room. The problem is, what the baddie-buddies want is hidden in the panic room with them.And so the rest of the movie consists of Junior, Burnham and Raoul trying to get Meg and Sarah out of the panic room, while Meg and Sarah try to find a way to get help to come and route the baddie-buddies.I won't spoil how this situation develops; it's well-done and suspenseful, and I enjoyed the movie even though I knew what the outcome was going to be. It was interesting to watch how the story moved along to the inevitable and predictable climax. Foster is, as always, very watchable; Stewart does a nice job, and Whittaker, Yoakum and Leto are workmanlike baddies.It's a good entertaining movie that hits all the right buttons and leaves you satisfied without breaking any new ground or giving us any new insights. Which, for Foster and the kind of work she usually does, is faint praise indeed.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2010-04-17</date>
		<username>MartianOctocretr5</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Suspenseful, but marred by inconsistent tension levels</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>With two excellent actors and a strong premise, this suspense thriller opens with potential. The basic premise is that new tenants to an apartment, a mother (Jodie Foster) and daughter (Kristin Stewart), inadvertently get caught up in an "inside job" robbery at the apartment building. They're in the wrong place at the wrong time.The ensuing cat/mouse pursuit, complete with a well crafted claustrophobic atmosphere, provide for what is usually an exciting story. The chess moves made by both sides are logical to the characters, building the plot and suspense level. Forest Whitaker (as one of the three criminals) and Foster deliver the convincing performances expected from these talented actors. However, weaker acting of others in the cast, and inconsistent direction, don't maintain the mood or tension. This weakens the film's effectiveness.The other two villains start out menacing, but when you see some idiot trap his hand in a doorway (and some other slapstick behavior), it's too awkward to take it seriously. The intent was clearly not a Home Alone type satire, but sometimes resembles it. The line reads by the the two dumb crooks, as well as Stewart, just aren't convincing; they each become caricatures. The latter's role is a tom-boy diabetic teen with an attitude, but she plays it more like a mumbling zombie that spikes her insulin shots with heavy depressants.Whitaker and Foster carry the film, and ultimately, succeed in saving it. The ending sequence works well, and has a nice irony attached. Good for one-time viewing, but you probably won't want to revisit it.</fullReview>
	</review>

The pair find a spacious "to die for" Manhattan brownstone, and quickly take up residence. One of the home's selling points is a "Panic Room" where you can hide out safely in the unlikely event of a home intrusion. Well, you guessed it. As the new residents begin their very first night's sleep, three dangerous invaders enter the house...Looking for millions hidden (guess where!), the crooked trio - kindly non-violent Forest Whitaker (as Burnham), maniacal bus driver Dwight Yoakam (as Raoul), and "not built for prison" Jared Leto (as Junior) - terrorize the new residents. David Fincher directs the cameras to move everywhere and anywhere; he surfs through the house - up stairs and through pipes, vents, keyholes, and even walls. This is a predictable, well-produced David Koepp thriller, with some prolonged gruesome scenes.****** Panic Room (3/29/02) David Fincher ~ Jodie Foster, Forest Whitaker, Dwight Yoakam, Jared Leto</fullReview>

		<date>2009-08-30</date>
		<username>RONALD B. RAFF (herbstnebel2ss)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Stall for the inevitable double cross.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Besides being a thrill a minute actioner, Panic Room clearly exemplifies the fact that there's no honor among thieves.Jodie Foster and Kristen Stewart give above board performances as Meg and Sarah Altman. The two latest statistics of the broken family syndrome, they have just moved into a majestic house in Manhatten.Unfortunately for them, their home has been targeted by a trio of thieves intent on liberating millions of dollars in bearer bonds hidden inside. The three consist of Burnham (Forest Whitaker) Junior (Jared Leto) and Raoul chillingly portrayed by Dwight Yoakam.It is only after the three are inside that they realize the dwelling is occupied. Yet the stakes are so high, they decide to pursue their quest. Awakened by the intruders, Meg and Sarah take refuge in the covertly installed panic room. As was revealed early in the movie, the room is virtually indestructible and the thieves spend the majority of the film trying to gain access to it. Not only do they want to get to Meg and Sarah, but the treasure they seek is in the room.During their endeavors Junior and Raoul engage in a power struggle, while Burnham just wants to get the whole thing over with.They are really creative in their attempts to get the Altmans to open the door, trying everything from poison gas to beating Meg's soon to be ex husband to a pulp. Meg and Sarah are just as creative in seeking outside help.As time races along and it becomes clear that the room is impregnable, the inevitable falling out occurs between Yoakam, Leto and Whitaker.I really liked the clip at which the movie progressed. There are more than enough tense moments, tight spots and fisticuffs to keep your attention. Performances were first rate and convincing, especially Dwight Yoakam as the cold blooded Raoul.There were several flaws however. Early on while Meg and Sarah are initially examining the house, Meg reveals to us that she is extremely claustrophobic, yet throughout the remainder, she shows no such symptom's even though she is confined in the panic room. Another is when the real estate agent demonstrates that the panic room door will not shut if anything is obstructing it, much like an elevator door. Yet later, it slams firmly shut on Raouls hand.Despite these minor flaws, Panic Room is exciting, suspenseful and will have your heart skipping a few beats.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-06-24</date>
		<username>Aidan McGuinness</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>I want to marry David Fincher, but not this movie.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had high hopes for this movie. After all Fincher did `Fight Club', which is in my personal top three movies of all time, as well as `Se7en' which is in my top ten. He's got a lot to live up to and yet this concept, a sort of adult `Home Alone' had me wary. could he pull it off? Almost, but he was let down by a poor script by David `Spiderman' Koepp.The plot's nice and simple. Meg Altman (Jodie Foster) has moved into a huge New York home with her daughter Sarah (Kristen Stewart), using money gained from her divorce. One of the house's features is a panic room - a room cut off from the outside world which you can lock yourself into in times of trouble. Guess what? Trouble arrives in the form of three burglars intent on stealing something. The problem? What they want is in the panic room, and the Altman's, terrified, have now locked themselves in.The script is where things get let down. It's obvious. You can generally predicate what's going to happen and are left unsurprised then when it does. The burglars feel very much like stock characters - there's the I-am-not-so-bad-just-down-on-my-luck type (Forrest Whittaker), the crazy-wild-guy (a disappointing Jared Leto), and the cold-psychotic-guy (Dwight Yoakam). They thus feel one dimensional, not helped by Leto's manic, over-the-top performance that almost renders them comically inept. This isn't good for a thriller. Fortunately Jodie Foster puts in a fine performance as the strong, concerned mother who genuinely emotes fear, love, and hate on screen and Kristen Stewart is a welcome new addition for teenage actors by virtue of not being loathsome as most are.It's up to David Fincher to save the movie, and he mostly succeeds. He's the current maestro of atmosphere and visuals in Hollywood, using innovative techniques to help otherwise staid scripts rise over their limitations. Here he doesn't get quite as creative as he does with `Fight Club', both because it's a more mainstream picture and because the movie doesn't require it. Nevertheless his camera work is superb. It roams from room to room, and yet also is able to enter keyholes, or examine minute particles of dust in incredibly fluid transitions. Naturally, with Fincher at the helm, there's a great use of lighting and shadows - one of his goals was to achieve a `realism' in this movie, in that the viewer would be no more privy to what a character could see than that character. This works excellently, allowing him to crank up the tension by suffocating the viewer in the same closed universe as the protagonists. The use of a relatively small set, notches up the claustrophobic angle, accentuated by the aforementioned lighting. The music scheme to the movie is typically subdued, never overwhelming but creating a linger sense of fore boding in the viewer's head - Howard Shore's work is again appreciated by me for not having the full on effect of a James Horner piece.Despite Fincher and Foster's work here, I can't help but feel disappointed by `The Panic Room' because of the oft-flimsy screenplay that failed to fully realise the movie's potential. The visuals and acting were good enough to distract me and let me gawp at their prettiness, but afterwards I was left a bit cold feeling Fincher's creative talents could be better spent on material that allowed him to expend all his energies. It's his work alone here that makes me add a few marks on to the movie to give it a 7.8/10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-06-16</date>

		<shortDescription>where is the unexpectedness that i had been waiting for?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>one thing i knew about david fincher films was that they were all based on `you think you know but you have no idea` theme. that is at one minute you think that you have put things in your mind in a logical way and can peacefully go on watching the film but at the next minute everything is mixed up again. that is especially true for Game and Fight Club. but unfortunately fincher failed to achieve this unexpectedness in Panic Room. SPOILERS AHEAD! when Meg and her child come to the house we see the mobile phone in closeup, when 3 guys come and rumble the bedroom we again see the mobile phone this time under the bed. even at that point im sure that it was clear in everyones mind that the phone would be useful in future situations. now where is the unpredictability? it was also very sentimental to see one of the robbers giving an insulin shot to the girl but hey this is all too much mainstream! even the camera movements cant make the film an exciting one. hope that Finch will regain his all-time-unpredictability in Mission Impossible 3..</fullReview>

		<date>2002-06-09</date>
		<username>kevgill</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Don't panic, but Fincher's lost the plot...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>How fortunate that Jodie Foster happens to be wearing a tight white cleavage-inducing camisole and grey sports pants to bed on the night when three burglars come knocking. If she had chosen to wear a pair of snuggly Bridget Jones pyjamas as night clothes on the first night in her new home, then we wouldn't have a film would we?Whilst this is arguably a more aesthetically pleasing choice (particularly to the testosterone-fuelled males among the audience), it does represent a conformity to action movie formula and cliché which has satisfyingly lacked in David Fincher's previous efforts.It is not entirely clear why Foster and her pubescent daughter need quite so much space when they move in to a multi-storey town horse, but need it they do, and into the bargain comes an impenetrable `panic' room, into which our heroines retreat when said trio arrive. The problem though, is that their booty is in that very room. This ensues a war of guile and one-upmanship as both parties try to solve this immensely tricky conundrum.Given the rather limited premise and setting, it is testament to Fincher's directorial flair that he has created a strikingly visual film. ?Panic Room' is, at times, reminiscent of Alfred Hitchcock's ?Rope', as the camera pans through the building in long takes (engineered by hidden editing), showing us every corner of every room of the location.Unfortunately though, comparisons with the master end there, as Fincher fails to capture a sense of terror and suspense that pervade so much of Hitchcock's work. In fact the complete opposite is true, as the film becomes increasingly predictable and formulaic right up until its ridiculously clichéd climax.Indeed, to favourably compare ?Panic Room' with ?Rope' is not to tell the whole story, as it also whiffs of ?Alien' and, yes, ?Home Alone'. Jodie Foster's character, the strong female in distress, could easily be Sigourney Weaver's Ripley at home on planet Earth. Likewise, given that some of the burglars' behaviour borders on slapstick, it might just as well be Daniel Stern and Joe Pesci who represent what is, after all, a genuine threat to the lives of our two heroines.One would think that a straightforward premise would implicate a straightforward plot. Not the case. The film is as implausible as it is predictable. Details are skipped over for the sake of convenience so the movie is, in this sense, incredibly lazy. (Possible spoilers ahead.) Most of us can't even change a fuse but Foster can, it seems, make telephones. Why, into this `impenetrable' room, can gas be pumped from the outside? Why, by the same rationale, is there a small pipe that leads out to the Manhattan streets? Much of the content is a betrayal of the premise on which it is based.?Panic Room' is ultimately a fairly enjoyable film, but we expect more than that from Fincher. There are countless flaws that disappoint and annoy. Some blatant and shameless product placement for Sony and Evian water is a particularly difficult pill to swallow given the anti-consumerist themes of Fincher's previous movie ?Fight Club'.</fullReview>
	</review>

The story wasn't really explained that well. Forest Witaker was good in it. You tend to loose interest after the first hour. For a movie that was suppose to be suspenseful, I wasn't frightened at all. Save yourself the trip and the seven bucks you would have paid to see it plus the money for the snacks and go rent a movie. Overall I gave this movie about a 6 out of 10 and that's being generous.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-06-02</date>
		<username>David, Film Freak</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Don't panic.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When Meg Altman (Jodie Foster) and her daughter Sarah (Kristin Stewart) move into a new house, they find their lives in danger on the very first night as 3 burglars break in, attempting to steal a large sum of money hidden in the houses' main selling point, the Panic Room. Of course, as soon as Meg sees the robbers, she grabs her kid and the 2 lock themselves inside the panic room. The robbers try just about everything to try and coax the two out of hiding. Of course, luck would have it, that the phone line inside the Panic Room has been disconnected and even after Ms Foster bravely exits the room to grab her cellphone they find that there is no reception. Even later we find out that the girl is a diabetic and her insulin level is dropping faster than Oprah would should she be jumping off a diving board. The robbers now enter the panic room with the girl still trapped inside and the mother just manages to throw her insulin injections into the room before the robbers close the door. It all comes down to an edge-of-your-seat climax as the courageous mother fights for her daughter's life and all hell breaks loose. Jodie Foster is brilliant as the mother and Forest Whittaker and Jared Leto play their stereotypical bad guy characters well. The suspense is built up nicely throughout the film and overall, is a great thriller worth seeing more than once. Even the opening credits are interesting!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I have just come straight from the theatre to write this. The film's opening titles are stunning, a pseudo billboard suspended in air against the Manhattan backdrop. This, the opening scene, and the final scene, are the only outside shots in the whole movie. Claustrophobia is avoided though, apart from where intentional, and the whole film is shot in a tense, subdued light.Foster's performance is virtuoso, and is subtly complemented by the supporting personae.Superb, immaculate timing and, apart from some over-laboured fingernail-stretching situations at the finale, rather believable as well.A rather enjoyable night out!</fullReview>

Instinctive thinking in the face of adversity is well portrayed and makes this movie all that more watchable while giving it momentum. We are also shown the very dark side of people on one hand where cold-blooded killing is the norm and also the morally conscious person where protecting life is more important above anything else. Look out for the opening credits its so beautifully done!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-05-09</date>
		<username>richard winters (rwint)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Standard but Solid Thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>A mother and daughter move into a Manhattan apartment that has a small, tightly sealed, security sensitive 'panic room'. A room that is generally used by those who are rich and prominent, to hide out in when being invaded by intruders. Naturally, on their very first night there, the place is broken into and the two must use it.Generally solid, well paced thriller that avoids the claustrophobic feeling despite all the action taking place in one building. The building by the way was actually constructed on a sound stage, but done with such detail that you won't even notice the difference. You get a real good sense of it's dimensions because director Fincher literally glides the camera all through the place. It's almost like being a fly on the wall. It definitely gives the viewer the intended sense that the building, and especially the room, is like a third character.Foster and Swanson, who play the mother and daughter respectively, do a competent job. Foster gives her patented 'don't mess with me look' and Swanson seems very much like a young Jodie. Also the screenwriters make sure to ardently adhere to the first mandate of screenwriting 101, which is if you have a bunch of people trapped anywhere one of them must be a diabetic and in desperate need of a insulin shot.The crooks are actually the ones who become the 'stars'. Although they are not quite the complete clowns of HOME ALONE notary, they are still quite human. Their constant bickering is both lively and fun.The film builds quite nicely, but the ending seems a bit abrupt. There are also a few loose ends that go unanswered. Also there is a discrepancy involving a 911 operator that had several people in the theater verbally rolling their eyes (including a eight year old girl that was sitting right behind me).Despite a few flaws this a refreshing change of pace for a modern movie. The emphasis is on the suspense and not the special effects or violence.Foster was reportedly pregnant during the shoot, but they disguise it well, except for one really quick moment. Also the man sleeping in the apartment across the street is actually Andrew Kevin Walker. He was the screenwriter for SEVEN, another feature directed by Fincher.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>SPOILERS BELOW************The first half of this film was great, good build up, but I just couldn't ignore several holes....The worst ones- 3 criminals, one of them an experienced guy who works for a security firm, break into a house with loads of cameras. 		<date>2002-05-06</date>
		<username>Gary Ballance</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Best movie of '02, so far. *MAJOR SPOILERS*</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The sign of a good movie for me is when I don't have to look at my watch once- (I looked at it over 10 times during A.I.- what does that tell you?!) Panic Room is a good non-watch-checking movie.It was extremely well-written; not boring at all and constantly increasing the tension as it goes on. The directing by David Fincher (Se7en) was excellent- while a lot of directors might consider a thriller "beneath them", and deliver very pedestrian efforts, Fincher invests in this movie giving really cool &amp; innovative camera shots (the keyhole shot, the CG assisted kitchen shot and the subtle-but-brilliant shot of the shadow behind Foster (the one on the poster).)The acting was very good. I was really surprised that *SPOILER* Jared Leto was killed off so soon, but I suppose Dwight Yoakam was really allowed to develop after this. After seeing Jodie Foster in this movie, I can't imagine Nicole Kidman playing the role. While Kidman was very good in The Others, this role really suited Foster. Kristen Stewart was brilliant, particularly encouraging her mother to tell the thieves to " get the f*** out of my house!" Forest Whitaker was also good- I was surprised he didn't get away at the end. Jared Leto was a bit annoying at first, but got better, and Yoakam was amusing delivering a couple of deadpan jokes.Very enjoyable film- it develops like a game of chess, each side getting a move and it's very suspenseful- especially Foster running for her cellphone. Poor old Patrick Bauchau got the s*** kicked into him! Anyhow, Fincher once again delivers. Excellent.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>If anyone can remember the famous 'Likely Lads' TV episode, whereby the lads go to great lengths to avoid knowing the England football result before they watch the highlights on TV, you'll know what I mean. This is very exciting (sad, I know) but I haven't seen a single review of this film; nor have I heard anything about it; nor did I get any vibes from the fellow audience (who numbered about ten in a large cinema).Basically, I wanted to write a review and not be swayed in any manner by other opinions. Well, here goes. What the hell was Jodie Foster doing in this load of old rubbish? I mean, 'Hannibal' was rubbish without her, so I guess she may have been making this movie at roughly the same time? Why? Why? Why? Is it meant to be a comedy or what? Even Jodie Foster's normally impeccable acting was reduced to mediocrity in this unbelievable tale of a so-called 'panic room'. The big mystery is why didn't they come out before carnage, mayhem, and bad lines abounded?! If the papers tomorrow rate this movie I'm an ITV Digital's Monkey's Uncle. I know that there are always some bits of a 'thriller' which are bound to contain far-fetched plot-lines, but I seemed to be doing five-bar gates of the flaws and running out of fingers after the first ten minutes. I did enjoy the credits, thankfully at the start of the movie where they belong; but, that aside, and I can think of no other credit-worthy points to make. It really was like an adult version of 'Home Alone', complete with daughter and mother; but the humour was more akin to the 'Carry On' series. Perhaps I'll discover, when I read other reviews on this site (as I managed not to peep once during navigation to this area), that I am in a minority, in which case I'll know I've gone completely loopy. The reason I wanted to see this movie was because I am not unfamiliar with the ability to have a good panic, but panic I did not. Thank God for the trailer of 'Killing me Softly'. At least I had a good gawk at my number one pin-up Heather Graham, but even that didn't improve my mood sufficiently to be able to enjoy this load of all codswallop!</fullReview>

		<date>2002-04-29</date>
		<username>tostinati</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Old School "A Picture" Thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Contains possible spoilers.This film never lets up. Of course, what film DOES let up in these days of the big pounding-sound track, retina-tattooing, senses-flooding filmic Experience? What gives this flick distinction is the excellence of the performances, the rapidity and intensity with which the challenges present themselves, and perhaps most important, the general level of verisimilitude/credibility of the events. (I only caught them on two questionable points: 1.the propane fire should have raged probably out of control, raising the temp. of flammable material in the area enough to combust it, and 2.the descent into diabetic coma seemed too slow/stretched for story's sake.)Forrest Whittaker is the heart of the film. Even if the rest of the film is too much for you, see it for his performance. We see his character-- a plodding career security company employee/nebbish who hopes to retrieve a dead man's millions from the safe room of an uninhabited house-- being sucked inexorably into something far more violent and ambitious than he can handle. From the first time we see him, a great bear of a man being danced circles around by his incessantly gibbering, candy-nosed accomplice, we sense his unbridgeable distance from the frenzied would-be brain of the expedition, and his doom; we begin to root for him, if only over his out-of-control accomplices. It is a sad, knowing performance, one wherein a single gaze speaks volumes. It forms an excellent companion piece to his role in Ghost Dog a couple of years ago.Ten stars. I wish all Hollywood's formulaic thrillers could be this good. --And if the movie-going public was a little more insightful and discerning, they might become so.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Good solid performances from good solid cast</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I had seen the previews and eagerly looked forward to the release of this movie - and I wasn't disappointed. From the stunning opening credits (more later) it was the kind of movie that has you on the edge of your seat - there are some predictable moments, but then there usually are, but there were more surprises. I caught myself thinking "don't go there", "look out behind you", "no way would *I* do that". I came out of the movie very satisfied having seen a good story told well and acted well. And for the lovers of technology - go marvel at the incredible detail of the opening credits - the reflections in the windows, the perspective and shading of the lettering with the changes of ambient lighting - they look so real. And note also the startling camera work: especially note when the camera goes places cameras can't go, like through the handle of a coffee pot. Neat! Go see this movie - you'll enjoy it.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-04-22</date>
		<username>Daniel Marrin</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Something's just off (SPOILERS)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>You expect more from David Fincher than this. You expect a kicking hard-rock soundtrack, and brutality that will have a revelatory aspect to it, as it did in Seven, the Game, and Fight Club. Most of all, you expect to be captivated by characters. I may have walked in a couple of minutes late (just as they were beginning the tour of the house) but something just felt off about Panic Room. Maybe it's the lead casting. After seeing what Nicole Kidman did with the Others, I can't help but wonder how she would have made the claustrophobia a lot more palpable in this film. (Shouldn't we be getting the feeling that living in a big house is a comfort to Meg given her claustrophobia, from the start?) Also, the relationship between her and Sarah seems really -- dead. I know she's just gone through a divorce, but you expect a little more honesty in the relationship between them. On the other hand, the three thugs are wonderfully cast. I had no way of imagining that Dwight Yoakam was the thug operating under that ski mask, and it is a welcome change to see Jared Leto as a sniveling know-it-all who finds himself (SPOILER) the least necessary of the trio.  You keep watching the film for Whitaker, however, and maybe that's where the problem comes in. Because the ending of this film seems even more unjust and less poetic than that of Seven. (SPOILERS) I for one left the theater wondering what the hell was the point of making this guy into the hero, fundamentally, who'd go and give the daughter an insulin shot to save her life, and then double back to save Meg at the end, only to end up damned.  (SPOILER) And also, when and where did all those cops come from? I mean, it might have made sense if the first duo had decided to stay staked outside the apartment and happened to see Whitaker coming out, but a friggin' SWAT team? What was that about? MY ALTERNATE ENDING: The best sequence in the film, and perhaps one that should have capped the entire movie, was the propane bit. That has to be saved until the end, planned by Burnham to take care of Raul AND Junior. Burnham knows, having designed the rooms, that she's got a lighter in there. So, he protests about the amount going in, knowing the two of them'll disagree. He tells them both to listen in, urging them to hear them coughing, and then backs away at just the right second. They both get burnt and collapse. Whitaker gets away with the money Junior had offered (but not the bearer bonds). The two cops arrive, with Meg's call having gotten through. Meg and Sarah get out OK, it would have been a much better flick. (Even better -- now the cop's doubt about her saying "there are three" makes even more sense, because he sees only two men lying on the ground, and Meg, with Burnham having given the insulin shot, denies the cop's claim. Burnham goes home, and Meg and Sarah decide to move to a smaller apartment, sans panic room.  Now, as the ending was, I and many others walked out having been somewhat thrilled but wondering what the heck was the point.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-20</date>
		<username>Andrew (aorman)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Home Alone for grown-ups it ain't</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The point of this film is to ask yourself, what would I do in this situation? For the most part, Panic Room has us asking that question at a feverish pitch.David Fincher has a wonderful directorial style that ignores the physical limitations of the world (walls, floors, etc.) when describing the spaces the characters operate in. There is also an intensity of character focus which is more prevalent in his earlier films than in Panic Room. Unfortunately this intensity disappears about two-thirds of the way through the film, and the final third becomes run of the mill and predictable in both writing and direction. Present however is Fincher's usual play with colour.Despite several attempts at shoring up the main characters, the only one whose characterisation remains strong is Bhurman (Forrest Whittaker). Raoul (Dwight Yokam) changes from a frighteningly cold-blooded mercenary to a run-of-the-mill villain. Meg (Jodie Foster) seems weak throughout, and young Sarah (Kristen Stewart) is difficult to identify with as she portrays the stereotypical annoying teen.The verdict: this is a good film, not a great one. The first two thirds are a delight to watch for Fincher's direction, the last third is disappointing.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-19</date>
		<username>meyborg</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>visual striking!-way better than Game</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is Fincher's Hitchcock. And people, who tell that all the CG stuff is crap aren't modern movie watchers. They are the people that tell you over and over again about the old, analog times. Panic Room is now like a bridge between classical Hitchcock-fans and the matrix-generation.the credit sequenz is pure Hitch! The music is pure Hitch. And the setting is pure Hitch! Fincher does just bring it into the 21 century. And in years, when Fincher is an icon himself, people will always connect this peace of suspense with mr. Alfred, and kids will get to now Finch first and secondly starting to search for the other guy. I must say that story isn't something that does interessed me that much, so I'm not objectiv, but panic is a cool thriller, that can't be compared with seven or fight club as new, outstanding and cynical, but the way it's done it has the power to tower of "game" and nearly reachíng the level of seven.9/10</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-15</date>
		<username>ShinKyo81</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>David Fincher should include in the DVD Extras the real ending!!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It's quite difficult to believe "Panic Room" as a creation of one of the most astonishing directors from nowadays: David Fincher. His path along the film industry has been followed by many newborn directors, trying to copy the style of Fincher's creations, like "Se7en" or "Fight Club". But David Fincher didn't exactly start from nothing. He begun working at the special effects crew in productions like "Return of the Jedi", "Never Ending Story" and "The Temple of Doom", in the ILM. Then, in 1992, he directed his first well-known film: "Alien3".Three years later, it started the "Fincher's fest": in 1995, "Se7en" came out from his imagination and became one of the best movies of the 90's. In 1997, "The Game", not as good as the 1995 production, but still on the Fincher's track. And two years later, the outstanding and incredible "Fight Club", who broke all the models in the film industry creating a new way of modern criticism. And here comes "Panic Room", starring a brilliant-as-always Jodie Foster and the typical creepy atmosphere of "The Game". Two things really original in the film: the starting credits (very original) and the camera movements, typical in Fincher's films: he will put the camera through the keyhole, the coffee pot handle or the wall, wherever he wants. A worth look. You should consider that this film is NOT like the other Fincher's creation. First, IT HAS NO TWIST ENDING AT ALL. If you're expecting some twist like the "Fight Club" one, you'll be extremely disappointed (like me for example). You should understand this movie like a new one, not like a following of the style of the other movies. Anyway, you wouldn't have had energy for a twist in the plot, because "Panic Room" really scares the crap out you! It keeps you at the edge of the seat during the 2 hours! It's true! Probably the most frightening movie from the last years. Maybe "Panic Room" could be compared to "Home Alone" but for adults, maybe the ending is quite predictable and poor (hey, think about "Planet of the Apes" for a bad ending), but it's a brilliant thriller with a creepy atmosphere, a lot of style, and created by David Fincher. "Panic Room" is very good way to spend your money and your time! Worth a look!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>**SPOILER** Cringeworthy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie is very average. Jodie Foster wears a low-cut tank top and has a lot of running and bending over scenes, while trying to play the strong, in-control mother protecting her daughter. Quite a mixed message. Much is made of her drinking before falling asleep, so that she doesn't hear three bumbling crooks breaking and entering, and walking around her house. Then she is awake and fully cognizant instantly, so that she can get into the panic room with her daughter. You will cringe often watching the crooks screw up, then watching Jodie and daughter react poorly, so that the movie plot can continue to unfold. The scene where she connects phone wires then tells her daughter she has no idea what she's doing is a perfect example (of course she hooks it up right and makes the call, while the criminal races to the basement to cut the line). After much melodrama it's all for nothing, as the loot just blows away into the night, and the "good" criminal gets caught anyway. Wait for it to play on television or rent it from the library.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-13</date>
		<username>Matthew Buckley (buckleym-1)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Decent, but ultimately forgettable</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>David Fincher's "Panic Room" traps and eventually buries itself under cliche and familiarity. Jodie Foster plays Meg Altman, who recently divorced from her husband and moves into a new house with her daughter (Kristen Stewart). Of course the first night in their new home, three burglars brake inside in pursuit of a missing fortune located in the panic room. Meg and her daughter, Sarah, hide in the panic room after the three men break into the home. Thus begins the cat-and-house game between the mother and daughter and the burglars. The definite highlights of the film are the camera movements and Foster's performance. The camera is extremely mobile, moving all around the house, through walls and along the ground. This adds to the sense of dread around the situation along with the claustrophobic feel of the house and panic room itself. This style perhaps allows the audience to get an even better idea of the surroundings than any of the actual characters in the film. Jodie Foster does a great job in a difficult role. She switches from a confused and weak protagonist to a smart and creative heroine in a split second and does it with the utmost ease imaginable. David Fincher films have always featured intentive camera work and dark source material and this is no different. The problem though relies in the fact that while Meg is a strong lead, the script allows for no other memorable roles only cliches. Forest Whitaker, a vert gifted actor, plays the bad guy with the noble intentions. Jared Leto (who was terrific in "Requiem For A Dream") is the over-the-top psychotic one and (country singer) Dwight Yoakam plays the evil one that never dies. Throughout the course of the movie Raoul (Yoakam) has his hand crushed in a metal door, and is bashed in the head and still keeps coming back for more. Foster's acting in "Panic Room" shows why she is one of Hollywood's best actresses and Fincher adds some dark touches. The film, however, bogs down under cliche to point where the whole film, especially the ending, leaves an empty feeling inside. A 6 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-04-12</date>
		<username>drvath</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Enjoyable but flimsy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Okay, I'll start by saying that I expected more from David Fincher. Se7en and Fight Club are two of the finest (albeit disturbing) films to have been made in years.Yes, the plot is a bit flimsy, with some gaping holes. I also didn't feel that the film was terribly suspenseful, but I may just be jaded. On the other hand, the cinematography was excellent, as were most of the actors, and I was never bored as some here have said.There was one major technical flaw that I want to delve into, since I haven't seen anyone else mention it, and just 'cause I'm that way. Critical, that is.The entire episode with the propane tank was completely impossible. Firstly, because propane tanks require a special hose with a valve in order to release the propane, you can't just duct-tape a garden hose onto them. Secondly, propane is heavier than air; it would have gone to the floor of the panic room, not remained at the top. And thirdly, propane has an (highly effective) odourant added to it for safety reasons, Jodie would not have had to stick her nose into the air duct to know she was being gassed.No, I am not a real-life Hank Hill, anyone who owns a propane grill should know these facts.All that aside, I did enjoy the film overall, although I may have preferredto watch it on DVD at home. I'd give it a 6.5 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>biskitzbakery</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Diabetes portrayed properly - ggraham-2 of Lincoln, Nebraska is incorrect</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just wanted to respond to ggraham-2 of Lincoln, Nebraska, who must have missed the bit in the film where Forrest Whittaker asks Sarah which needle she needs. To which Sarah shakes her head at the insulin and when he picks up the orange emergency case containing pure glucose in a needle Sarah nods. Being a diabetic I was happy to see low blood sugar finally being treated properly in a movie. Low blood sugar/insulin shock means the body has too much insulin and will crash if sugar/glucose is not administered immediately. Forrest gave Sarah the right shot - he gave her pure glucose. Now, if you want to see how to not correct low blood sugar/insulin shock just rent ConAir because Nicolas Cage is trying throughout the whole movie to get a needle to give his buddy an insulin shot to correct that fact that he hasn't eaten (low blood sugar/insulin shock). Wrong. Nicolas would kill the guy if he gave him insulin. Anyway, I liked Panic Room with or without the diabetic angle. I do want to know where to get the glucose monitoring watch Sarah wears in the movie but I'm assuming it's a movie prop because my searches have only brought up one glucose watch and it looks nothing like Sarah's sleek sporty watch. Thanks, Laura</fullReview>

		<date>2002-04-11</date>
		<username>wetcoast</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Can you really be safe in a room encased in steel?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was lured into the Panic Room by a catchy trailer. It is, in fact, a catchy movie. Set in a large, old, New York brownstone which had been previously owned by an eccentric old man(unseen) with a eye on security, the film is shot in drab grays, primarily on a stormy night.Claustrophobic mom Meg Altman(Jodie Foster) and her angsty daughter Sarah(played very well by Kristen Stewart)try to get a good night's sleep in this altogether too large apartment. Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto &amp; Dwight Yokam(again cast as the 'baddy' - see also SlingBlade) play the unseemly trio bent on disurbing the peace.The film works on the level of the filmaker's careful use of camera angles, stark lighting and good editing. But the fatal flaw, is too much detail at the beginning about the Panic Room itself.I don't like movies which lay out too much 'could go wrong' at the beginning. It would have been just as effective to 'mention' the panic room as the real estate selling factor and not give it so much weight at the very beginning, thereby setting the scene for the entire movie. Most movie goers are sophisticated enough to put the pieces together without gratuitous information.Would I recommend it? YES, definitely. It does a good job of making you wonder how it will turn out, despite some cloying 'giveaway' details.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-11</date>
		<username>mr_doright11</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Very intense, but also a good character movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was thrilling as well as it was a good drama. Jodie Foster does an outstanding job as per usual as Meg Altman. Forest Whitaker also does a great job as the reluctant villian. Sure, the character is a little cliche (bad guy who doesn't want to be bad but has to for someone he cares about), but that didn't matter to me, because he did a great job none the less. Great acting, and some heart stopping intensity makes this the best thriller I've seen in a couple of years.I think that Kristen Stewart did an exceptional job as Jodie Foster's angry and sarcastic daughter Sarah (another a cliche character, but once again, played to perfection), who has to hide out in the panic room with her mom. Dwight Yoakam steals the show as the mysteriously scary robber Raoul, who remains an enigma through the whole movie. Raoul is the violent and mentally unstable (of course!) thief, would have no problem blowing away Meg and her Daughter. This movie takes some pretty scary turns here and there, with a lot of slow motion running and getting away in the nick of time.I have to admit that I went in to the theatre with low expectations (it was a Sunday and I was bored, so I grabbed a friend and went to the movies), but I was pleasantly surprised when I left. There was action, a little comedy, and non stop thrills, which is usually what I like about a movie, besides great acting, but it has that too! I recommend this to everyone who doesn't mind a good deal of violence, and isn't claustrophobic. Enjoy! 9/10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>**SPOILERS**</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Typical Hollywood fare with all the thrills and implausibilities intact. We have one character who gets his hand caught in a heavy steel door for minutes on end, gets shot and falls down a steep staircase, yet still manages to crawl back up the stairs to wield an axe at the heroine. We have a wealthy housewife from Connecticut who can figure out how to strip an outside phone line and connect it to her cell phone. If you're interested in yet another movie that asks the question, "will Jodie outwit the bad guys?" (and is there ever any doubt?) then this movie is for you. The pluses: the opening credits are some of the most amazing I've seen. The photographic angles are also breathtaking - Fincher takes you inside the phone line, inside the key hole, etc. Whatever you do, don't see it alone.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>talk about fostering paranoia</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*eh, not really a spoiler, but does reveal some parts of the plot*I just saw "Panic Room" last night, and rather than go and write a whole 'nother review, I'm going to quote directly from what I wrote about it in my journal last night. Profanities deleted, of course, at the request of the IMDB guidelines:"I ended up going to see "Panic Room," which was quite good. And not just cause I have a thing for Jodie Foster and her scared-puppy facial expressions. And that accent. Mrow! *grins mischievously*Pretty good flick. But I thought the kid was a brat, with her Sid Vicious shirt, when you could tell she had no idea who the Sex Pistols are/were. Or maybe I'm hostile towards kids who try to look punk when they also look like twelve-year-olds. Plus she was a pain in the [expletive deleted]. I mean, she was slipping into a freaking coma, and I for one did not feel the slightest bit bad. My thought processes went more along the lines of, "Thank god... if she's comatose, maybe she'll shut the [expletive deleted... this is getting eerily reminiscent of "Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back"] up!"Forest Whitaker, with whom I was not previously familiar, was cute, the kind of guy you picture seeing at church or the library with his kids, not breaking into people's houses and causing gas-related explosions....I think, however, that the highlight of the movie had to be Dwight Yoakam as the psycho bad guy. Because, for chrissake, it's Dwight Yoakam! The dorky old guy that sings country and has that music video where he and the band are all bouncing on trampolines, complete with bouncing instruments including a grand piano! A grand piano!! At least, I'm pretty sure that's Dwight Yoakam. It's either him or the Mavericks, it's been a while since I've watched CMT :P."After that, it gets irrelevant to the movie, but I think it expresses my opinions better than I could do it now because it's how I felt half an hour after seeing the movie, and if that's not an accurate depiction of my opinion, I don't know what would be.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Igor Henrique</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Great psychological Thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Trespassing the house is the main factor to ignite the plot, once it happens at the very first minutes of the movie and immediately provides suspenseful moments. This perspective is different in relation to some other Thriller movies, where tension progressively rises up as time passes. Throughout the film, we can notice constant changes between extremely suspenseful moments and other not so much ones, in which characters stop to brainstorm the next step to be taken and serve as "refreshments" for spectators. This can be considered as a real psychological Thriller, once an interesting "action and reaction game" is created by taking into account all various elements featured in the plot. Strongly recommended!</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Another frustrating film that totally gives up on story, so it can concentrate on sterile camera movement, obvious premeditated lighting, character development of people we don't care about in the first place, &amp; the failed attempt to imitate Kubrick by inserting long pauses in random places. 	<review>
		<date>2012-03-21</date>
		<username>Gerald Warren</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Some Plot holes, but still decent movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room is not a bad film by any means, but it does suffer somewhat from a mediocre script, thin characterization and a lackluster ending.The main problem I have with Panic Room is the performance of the three thieves. They enter the film like The Three Stooges, immediately undermining the tension that their entrance generates. I mean, for the film to work as strongly as it could, they should be a major threat, but instead they enter the film while bickering like a bunch of numbskulls. And two of them even think they can break through concrete and three inch steel with a sledgehammer. You're dealing with mental midgets here.Stupidest of the three is Leto's character. He doesn't know how escrow works, he puts his head against the wall when Foster is about to ignite the gas they're pumping into the panic room, he shouts at a PA system and he exposes his plan to screw over his fellow burglars simply by talking to himself. The extent of his stupidity is really too much to ask of an audience with any intelligence and his whole character smacks of lazy writing.But thankfully Leto's character gets shot halfway through. And his killing is nicely done. It's quick, it's brutal and it allows the unhinged Raoul to step up to the plate as the main villain. And although Raoul is a knob and a bit of a rent a psycho, he does seem like a genuine threat. And it's even more impressive considering that the actor who plays him, Dwight Yoakam, is a country music star. He may sing hick music, but he turns in a superb performance.But although Yoakam is excellent, the film easily belongs to Foster. She's strong, she's resourceful and she's entirely believable as a mother who'll blow your head off if you mess around with her kid. After all, is there anything more dangerous than a mother backed into a corner? Personally I'd rather take on a 6 foot 4, 300-pound, bum-hungry redneck called Bubba than a 5 foot 4 woman who wants to defend her kid. The burglars should have left the second they realized they were dealing with a 'mom'.However, while I can easily believe in Foster managing to wrestle a gun off of the psychotic Raoul (again illustrating how stupid the thieves are, Raoul at one point tells her to come out of hiding so he can shoot her and get things over. Didn't he ever have a mum?), her MacGyver routine stretches credibility ? igniting the gas is fair enough, but there's one bit where she somehow hooks up the phone line. She even says, "I have no idea" when her daughter asks her what she's doing. It's obvious that Koepp (the writer) has written himself into a corner and this is the result: suddenly she's a phone expert. But I'm willing to overlook these sorts of things as Fincher gives us ample opportunity to stare at Foster's cleavage when things get silly. It was actually an excellent decision to have her spend virtually the whole film in a black vest, as you're never too far from jiggling breasts, which is fair compensation for gaps in logic.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2011-06-29</date>
		<username>CinemaClown</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>David Fincher's Most Underrated Film, Arguably.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>From the director of Se7en &amp; Fight Club, Panic Room arrives as another intensely gripping, nail- biting &amp; edge-of-the-seat experience from David Fincher which further solidifies his position as one of the modern masters of thrillers, and beautifully balances its style with substance to succeed as one of the most captivating, entertaining &amp; satisfying works of Fincher's career.Set in New York City, the story of Panic Room concerns a recently divorced mother &amp; her 11-year old daughter who purchase a new house which comes equipped with a safe room in case the security is breached. But on the very first night, three burglars break into their house in search for a missing fortune which is present in the very room where the two ladies are now hiding.Directed by David Fincher, the film quickly sets up its plot &amp; from there on handles its suspense amazingly well throughout its runtime. Screenplay is brilliantly penned down by David Koepp, cinematography is quality stuff that comes very much influenced from Fincher's last film, editing keeps the narrative tightly structured, &amp; Howard Shore's score takes its tense ambiance to a nerve-wracking level.Coming to the performances, the cast comprises of Jodie Foster, Kristen Stewart, Forest Whitaker &amp; Jared Leto, who all chip in with fabulous performances. Foster is undoubtedly the most impressive of them all but Whitaker isn't far behind while Leto is near unrecognizable in his role. Also, the film makes extensive use of visual effects, including CGI, but it is executed in a very subtle manner which could easily go unnoticed.On an overall scale, Panic Room is a masterly executed thriller that has Fincher's trademarks signed all over it &amp; is effective enough to qualify as one of the best films of its year. It may not be counted amongst the director's finest works but that's no indication of it being any lesser in quality than others. Arguably his most underrated work along with The Game, Panic Room comes strongly recommended.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2011-06-27</date>
		<username>bobsgrock</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Fincher's style brought to fruition.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room remains sleek, trim and well-executed right through to its conclusion. For some cinematic snobs, the film seems to be too neatly wrapped up. However, thanks to the very stylistic and innovative direction of David Fincher and solid performances from Jodie Foster and Kristen Stewart, this film holds tension for as long as thrillers do, and then some.The premise is as simple as can be: a mother and daughter move into a new Manhattan home, three men break in one night while the two women protect themselves in the home's panic room and shut the burglars out. This classic chess-like standoff allows for several breath-holding moments made even better by a brooding Howard Shore score and some of the most amazing camera work ever put on film. Fincher went even further than his excellent work in Fight Club to combine CGI with Steadicam style to give us a virtual tour of the house, allowing us to understand its every dimension as it is the only set used. Adding to this tension is strong acting from Jodie Foster as the everywoman, capable of sticking up for herself and her safety along with Kristen Stewart as her wisecracking daughter, Forrest Whitaker as a morally centered burglar, Jared Leto as a whacked-out greedy one and Dwight Yoakam as a psychotic gun-toting accomplice.If you are searching for simple entertainment, thrilling sequences and solid performances, this has that and more. The material is lifted out of the doldrums of mediocrity by David Fincher's brilliance of pacing, shot choice, angles and swirling camera moves that will make you ask, "how did they do that?" Of course, by the end, you will be too busy trying to catch your breath to answer that question.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2009-01-07</date>
		<username>Vincent</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>I was expecting this to be annoying but it was a pleasant surprise.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is a nice neat thriller. The claustrophobic setting allows us to focus purely on the lead characters and motivations and actions with no extraneous distractions.The acting is good as you'd expect with the adult cast but even the child, Stewart, is watchable. With the sick daughter the danger was that this would become maudlin and emotional but it avoids that, the danger to her health is simply used to crank up the pressure as the film progresses.There are a few twists as hope is stripped from the pair in the panic room and as the criminals realise they won't be having everything their own way. There are some pieces of action throughout although the action mostly takes a back seat to the build up of tension.Over all there are enough surprises to keep you interested and the ending, although predictable, is done well.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2007-02-18</date>
		<username>alexx668</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Panic Room</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room is a disappointing film by David Fincher, who turns to be an inconsistent director. Simply put, it doesn't utilize it's true potential. Here's why.First of all the claustrophobic settings are used to little effect, apart from maybe the scenes where the burglars fill the panic room with gas, and the one with Altman trying to get out to fetch the medicine for her daughter. Then the reverse situation with Altman out and the burglars in is still not used to full effect.Then we have the slight irony of the security cameras. As the burglars break in, Altman and her daughter watch as the intruders move around their house. Not terribly sharp, but a nice touch nonetheless in this age of reality shows et all.Finally there seems to be a very faint touch of symbolism, with the money hidden in the bourgeois mansion inhabited by it's upper class denizens, the lower class burglars breaking in, the most humane of them almost making it, but then surrendering to the police. The final scene with the money flying in the air is nice.But despite Fincher's hints at what could be social commentary, this is mostly a generic action thriller, deplete with Hollywood-type slow motion scenes etc. It does show though Fincher's evolution as a director, using some fairly elaborate angles and shots.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-10-16</date>
		<username>Allan Goodall (agoodall@hyperbear.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Disappointing and Sloppy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Warning: although I don't spoil the end of the movie, I do mention a number of things that happen in the movie. If you don't want to be spoiled, skip this review.My wife is diabetic. She absolutely flipped over how the film messed up the plot surrounding the girl's diabetes. While locked in the room, Jodie Foster and the girl spend some time looking for a candy bar or something with sugar. The glucose meter the girl is wearing shows her blood sugar is dropping. The refridgerator in the girl's room shows the bottle of insulin. So, the girl's sugar is dropping. What does the mother do? Try to get her insulin. Ummm... sorry, that would kill her! Insulin drops blood sugar levels. What she needed was to eat something with sugar in it. It's possible that the syringe that is eventually given to the girl is actually full of a glucose solution, but this wasn't mentioned in the film and not supported by shots of the interior of the fridge. Besides, glucose has to be shot into the blood stream while Forest Whitaker's character was told how to shoot insulin, which can _not_ be injected into the blood stream.The fact that the movie got a fairly easy to research thing like this wrong shows its sloppy nature. It's just as sloppy with foreshadowing. Insulin in the fridge? The girl is going to have trouble with her diabetes while locked in the room (you can figure this out before the home invasion even begins). Call to her ex-husband? He'll end up showing up. One of the thieves is troubled with his conscience at the film's beginning? He's the guy who will end up saving things in the end.Film characters in desperate situations -- if they are not portrayed as stupid -- have to act smarter than us. When we can think of things to do that they can't, we feel cheated. If the woman and daughter in the room can see the bad guys, they know where all the bad guys are located. So, why didn't they take several opportunities when they saw the bad guys were occupied to open the door, dial out, call 911 quickly, and then shut the door? Why couldn't they fashion an antenna from all the wire in the room and hang it out the ventilation pipe?It made for a rather disappointing film. The acting isn't too bad, but I've seen Foster and Whitacker in other things where they were much better. It's not a horrible movie, just not one of the better options out there.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2003-01-29</date>
		<username>goatrealm</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>huge medical hiccup</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>i was having quite a bit of fun with this movie--it's visually quite enjoyable, and the suspense wasn't half-bad either-- until a plot hole jarred me, and hard.SPOILER ALERTso foster's kid is a diabetic, and she's becoming hypoglycemic. that means she needs to get her sugar levels back up. the movie, unfortunately, has an ill-informed sense of what diabetic medications do. most knowledgeable laymen (as well as doctors, nurses, paramedics, and the 16 million diabetics in the U.S., oh, and some of their relatives and friends--that's a significant chunk of the U.S. audience) realize that diabetic Rx LOWER blood sugar levels. in other words, foster should have been running to the fridge for orange juice, or to the pantry for crackers or candy, not for some vague, unspecified medication in the med kit. if foster injects this hypoglycemic kid with insulin, as the movie seems to suggest, the kid's toast, as far as sentience is concerned. the movie's confusion over diabetes would have been somewhat excusable had it been a minor part of the story, but ignorance was trumpeted left and right when an entire sequence of hunting/gathering "the medicine" ensued.of the hundreds of people who worked on this film, couldn't one person have said, hey, this doesn't make sense? or did someone make a suggestion that would be panned by silly movie execs looking for a bit of nonsensical drama?and what kind of panic room has no emergency calories tucked away?the movie started out promising to be a way-above-average thriller. but the aforementioned silliness was quite a let-down.</fullReview>
	</review>
