	<review>
		<date>2002-09-30</date>
		<username>(billybrown41@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Awesome</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What happens when one of Hollywood's most ingenious filmmakers decides to try something totally different than what they're known for? Well, sometimes, they're praised for it and sometimes they're trashed for straying too far from what they do best. In David Fincher's case, he's created some of the most mind-boggling, creative, and visually impressive movies in cinematic history. This time out (his fourth), the guy who directed Se7en, Fight Club, and The Game, trys something totally different. And it works.In Panic Room, Fincher takes a COMPLETELY stripped-down script, a confined setting, his AWESOME visuals and makes it all work. Here's a mom (newly divorced) who takes her daughter and moves into a gargantuan town-house in West Side Manhattan. Along with the house comes a Panic Room. The opening of the film gives us a brief little rundown of a panic room. It's a concrete room with it's own telephone, ventilation system, survival kit, and monitor system so that the house can be watched at all times. In short, the Panic Room has one purpose: to keep people out. One night (their first night, no less) three crooks break in. The brains behind the outfit, Junior (Jared Leto), the inside man Burnham (Forest Whitaker) and the psychopath with a gun, Raoul (noneother than Dwight Yoakam). With these three, there's no telling what's liable to happen but they all have one agenda: to get INSIDE that room, because (wouldn't ya know it?) what they're after is INSIDE that room. There's your set-up right there and it sets the stage for much cat and mouse, profanity-spewing action. Awesome camera tricks, great dialogue, and good strong performances by all, carry this one, making it one of the most entertaining movies I've seen all year. To say any more would spoil something, but I will say that David Fincher tried something new and it worked. I can't wait for his next picture.The performances here are flawless. Jodi Foster is incredible as the sharp-witted mom and her and Kristen Stewart have great chemistry as the mother and daughter in a tight situation. Jared Leto was suprisingly funny as the dread-locked Junior and Forest Whitaker shines as the only one of the three who seems to have a heart. Dwight Yoakam once again proves that he's got what it takes to be a great actor. His portrayel of Raoul was scary as hell. The guy is a walking time bomb. You have to understand that David Fincher didn't want to play with our heads on this one. His goal was to deliver a "popcorn/suspense film" and it works right on up to the last frame. 10/10</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-09-27</date>
		<username>Ivy Sykes</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Tepid Storyline</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Panic Room is essentially the story of a jilted wife, newly divorced from her wealthy, philandering husband and her young daughter having to fend for themselves and fight off three intruders the night they move into their new large brownstone on the upper west side of Manhattan. The only place of refuge that they can turn to is the "panic room" - a room built for any sort of emergency to seal them off inside and keep them safe from whatever lurks beyond - an impenetrable fortress of concrete and steel. The intruders in the meantime wreak havoc on the house trying to get into that room and a tale of cat and mouse follows. Given the whole idea of a panic room and the premise of outwitting three seriously dangerous men in your home leaves open such a vast array of opportunity for twists and turns and suspense in a movie.Now, all that being said, I would like to say that I was disappointed with this film, but I can't as I found myself too lackadaisical to be able to ever get disappointed. Technically proficient this movie certainly was, but I pin this waste of time on the writer, David Koepp and whoever the hell the producers were on this film. Jodie Foster as Meg Altman turns in a wonderful performance, when does she ever seem to fall short as an actress? Her daughter, played by Kristen Stewart was also quite good and David Fincher as a director, well, he's just magic. You give that man a camera and he settles for nothing less than perfection. However I have a suggestion for the studios regarding Mr. Fincher - why don't you try giving him a top A list script. Hell, I don't know, maybe have William Goldman stir one up for him, but for God's sake, do something because to see such a stellar actress and such a phenomenal director deliver all the way round and still have the story be so-so - well, the blames on the executives and the people who were supposed to be producing this thing. I looked up the budget on Imdb as soon as I finished viewing it, and to find out it cost 48 million nearly made me choke. Yeah, movie budgets are soaring through the roof nowadays, but please, for close to 50 mil, I want suspense, and I want plot twists that I don't expect and there wasn't much here that I wasn't already anticipating way ahead of time. I voted a 7 and I really think that's too high but I did so only because of Foster and Fincher - afterall, why should they suffer for something that wasn't their fault.Oh, and by the way, Jared Leto is soooooo two dimensional in this film - what was he thinking? And actually, what was Fincher thinking putting him in the role? Villains can be very complex and they can be three dimensional, hell - real life ones are. Leto, on the other hand, spends half his time whining and the other half screaming and never does it come across as anything deeper going on in him. Dwight Yoakim is slightly up the food chain from Leto, but on an acting level he's still superficial. The only one that holds up is Burnham, played by Forest Whitaker. He shows that it's possible to take a part of a burglar and have conflicts and criminality at the same time as having humanity. Perhaps if the other villains had been as good as him it may have helped the story not seem so robotic in it's style.All in all, I would say it's not a bad movie, but if you're looking for a good thriller, I would not recommend this film. The only recommend I would give for this film is if you're killing time watching cable. Above and beyond that, it just doesn't do enough to warrant much more. And not to nag, but will somebody please give David Fincher a great script, finally???</fullReview>
	</review>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A disappointing "panic" attack</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After the box office disappointment of "Fight Club", it seems as if director David Fincher felt the need to pursue less controversial, more rudimentary ground for his next film. Probably the same could be said for Jodie Foster, who after the failure of "Anna and the King", apparently wanted to play it safe and reaffirm herself as a successful female Hollywood star. And so they both settled for "Panic Room". I say settled because perhaps this latest feature is a letdown for fans of both stars, and in hindsight, is probably also for both of those two individuals. After a "so that's what all the fuss was about?" title sequence, the story begins as single mother Meg Altman (Foster) and her daughter Sarah move in to their new home in bustling New York City. A guide shows them around the house, detailing the house's features, including its panic room. Essentially this first act exists so that we the viewers become acclimated to the geography of house, and Fincher does a good job at this. But already Meg Altman is established as a pent-up nervous reck - unlike everyone else, she would rather not have that panic room in her house. Geez, Meg just moved into a new home and already she looks like she could have a heart attack at any minute. Not too much later the three villains of the picture show up, intent on getting a certain amount of money in bonds contained within the panic room, and mistakingly think that they are alone in the house to do so. Thus begins the film's string of unlikely coincidences, and annoying character and story contrivances. Not only is Jared Leto's character frequently misinformed, but he doesn't shut up, and of course he only cares for himself when it comes to the bottom line, partners be damned. Plus it never fails that this type of character will prove himself to be an utter moron when it comes to strategy. For when it comes to logic and fore-thought, that is completely Burnham's (Forest Whitaker) speciality. But he's not just a devious antagonist, he's one with a heart. One who deep down inside cares for others, especially when they are about to go into a coma or when they are being tortured by someone else. Uh-huh. Nevertheless, once both of the Altmans are trapped within their own confines, the story covers their numerous attempts to get out of the room while defeating the three burglars in the process. In one sequence, the three bad-guys try to coerce Meg and Sarah to come out of the panic room by spewing noxious gas into the room via a hose. While this was a slightly inventive sequence, I thought a more foolproof method to do this if I were the one of the burglars would be to instead pump water into the room via the hose. I don't know how the screenwriters would have written their way out of that one, but perhaps that kind of suspense sequence has been done in too many movies already? Overall, most of these suspense sequences are in that kind of mold, but they make-up a major part of the movie and are only semi-gratifying. They are slightly suspenseful, but after Meg and Sarah find their way out of one, it's onto the next one; and none of them particularly advance the story in anyway. They just add to the film's running time and are strictly for entertainment purposes. They're cotton-candy suspense sequences. In fact, the only sequence that is vibrant throughout the entire movie occurs a little past midway through, when a pair of suspicious policemen show up to check out what's going on inside the house. It's only in this moment that Foster lets down her steely intense guard and enjoys having a role in this joyless feature. The dialogue between Meg and the two policemen is comic and subtle and tense, all tightly wrapped together. And it is only then that Fincher discards his heavy, brooding tone that he is known for. A paired down suspense film like this needs some air to breathe, and amid all the over-the-top, unnecessarily explicit violence, it is hard to find. More than any other Fincher film, this is "just" a movie, in structure and in content. So why is the film as unpleasant and unsatisfyingly taught as it is? Expect both Fincher and Foster to go back to more substantial material in the future. Final Grade: B-</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-09-22</date>
		<username>crawl-1</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>One point of clarification</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Others will describe the details of the movie but I must tell you one scene which is somewhat unrealistic. A close relative is Type-1 diabetic. I have seen the situation with the low-blood-sugar daughter many times. While closer than many Hollywood attempts, here's my experience with someone whose blood glucose has dipped below 40. They get very combative, not compliant. Once the blood sugar drops to the point of being in convulsions, the person doesn't "come back". The spell doesn't pass. The blood sugar keeps getting lower and lower until coma. The shot Forrest W. administers was mostly right, except for a few small details. At the blood sugar she was at, the daughter likely would not have been able to help him at all. Didn't you find it odd the prior owners would build this room and not put any food in it? Especially candy or other carbohydrates? There's plenty of Type-1 diabetics around to help Hollywood get it right. Most productions I've seen always get it wrong.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Panic Room is a story about a newly divorced woman (Jodie Foster), and her daughter (Kristen Stewart) who have just moved into a very nice home in what is presumably New York City. Upon purchasing the house the realator shows them what he calls the 'panic room' or the safe room. It has a seperate phone line, security monitors, blankets, first aid, etc. in it, and is completely surronded by three inches of steel. The room has one purpose: to keep people out. There is no possible way to get in, but unfortunetley what the three robbers want is in that room and they aren't leaving until they get it. Panic Room is a great movie, which is superbly shot, with great acting by Foster, Stewart, Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto, and Dwight Yoakam.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-07-18</date>
		<username>Jacob Rosen (bix171@comcast.net)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Technically Brilliant But Still Entertaining</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>David Fincher's cold technical skills are a perfect fit for this manipulative, by-the-numbers thriller starring Jodie Foster as a newly-divorced mother whose brownstone is invaded by three men looking for a fortune hidden in a fortified room. The first half is Fincher showing off--at the expense of the plot--with impossibly complicated tracking and zoom shots through rails and walls and electrical outlets and plenty of scenes filmed at floor level. But he settles down in the second half and lets the conflicts between Foster and the intruders as well as between the intruders themselves (well-played by Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto and Dwight Yoakam) play out; then the film becomes engrossing, well-paced and satisfying. Fincher and his screenwriter, David Koepp, play fast and loose with the story--there are plenty of holes in the plot (a scene involving the use of sound is particularly flawed)--but the performances and the razzle-dazzle help you get past the suspect moments. Darkly but cleanly photographed in Panavision by Conrad W. Hall and Darius Khondji.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>clark-39</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>I loved it.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room is exactly the type of movie you would want to see at the theater, or even at home when it comes out on video. Following a terrific opening titles sequence, Jodie Foster and her daughter are moving into a big mansion, recovering from a bad divorce. Everything's okay on their first night until three burglars enter the home unaware of its occupants and looking for several million dollars locked in a safe. That safe just happens to be in the panic room, designed to protect the house's occupants in case of an emergency, and that's exactly where Foster and her child go. Now the crooks have to devise a way to get the two out. This film is extremely pleasing with a twist around every corner. Director Fincher sets the entire movie inside a house and it holds your interest until the end. Foster tries various ways to get out of the room, all of them mixed with hair-raising tension as the crooks also use various ways to get them out. This film is taught and drenched in beautiful camera-work. Shots through keyholes and coffee pot handles and even a close-up of small concrete particles shifting and moving give the camera a fluid style and it's amazing. There are very few special effects, just a solid thrill ride the whole way through. You'll be gripping your seat a lot of the time. Forget all the junk about stupid crooks and no plot, this movie is worth your money if you want to see a great thriller that doesn't cheat you out on scares. Extremely entertaining.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-06-14</date>
		<username>Chris Brown (christopher6453@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Few movies in our lifetime really jolt you to the edge of your seat, makes you squirm and chills your pulse as effective as Panic Room.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The latest David Fincher thriller is dread-ridden and accomplished and is a major indication of his mood-altering brilliance of a director. His films seduce and punish you until you're as trapped as its desperate characters. Fincher invokes such a high level feeling of anxiety in his dark, near pitch black paranoid visions. The result of his new movie is a thriller that pushes all the right buttons on the audience. Jodie Foster plays the recently divorced Meg with a young daughter with diabetes named Sarah (Kristen Stewart). They are talked into purchasing a new triple-decker brownstone located on the better half of New York. As common in movies where the house is big and formidable like the Xanadu mansion in Citizen Kane and the Overlook Hotel in The Shining, the house in play here is an ominous character where it's large and expansive spatial diameters are practically ready to swallow up its timid inhabitants.Foster, however, has never been anyone's victim. When three burglars invade her house on the first night, she panics with little awareness of where to run but makes the right crucial decisions. She wakes her daughter and gets her to run with her to the high-tech secure shelter called the Panic Room (there is an exciting chase as the bad guys, led by Jared Leto, lunge after them). Harbored by steel walls, the discreet but claustrophobic room has a buried phone line that is (in)conveniently unconnected, its own ventilation system and a survivor aid box.The intruders have a serious, high-stakes agenda and nevertheless, the prize they have in quest is located in the very room that Meg and her daughter are occupying. The bad guys quarrel over the situation, with Forest Whitaker as the sympathetic crook and a third character (the actor is better off unrevealed until the closing credits) is the madman wild-card who spends the entire time hidden under a ski mask. The bad guys try to hammer their way into the room; they try to suffocate the ventilation system, and try to use every threatening method imaginable to get Meg and Sarah to leave the room. The men box up the entire house and threaten not to leave until they get what they want. Suspense is built as much negotiation goes on between parties, and occasional trips from the room are made as Meg tries to retrieve a cell phone that was on her bed side desktop before the incident began. Sarah has diabetes complications and needs her injection. Dirty and greedy maliciousness takes place as the bad guys narrow in on how to harm Meg's most vulnerable fears.Not until after the curtain lowers do all the script flaws come into question. Foster, at one point, does have an opportunity to bring in more outside help but reasons that it will trigger more danger. The ending has a false note with the invincible villain rising from impending death one more time. But this is a director's movie and the power of the images and intensity of the events make this one heart-pounding experience, and is not for the feint of heart - which is what we expect from Fincher.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<fullReview>Ok, that's the best film I've seen recently. (Not counting The Others, but that's another story.) And I just can't see the problem of some people. (Possible SPOILERS ahead.) I just start hating the world "cliché". Yes, I admit that there are many clichés in the world of films, and yes, some of them are REALLY annoying. But hey, wake up! People make films for 100+ years! That means a lot of films! Thus it gets harder and harder day by day to make a really original story of which no one can say it's "clichéd" (I think it is impossible). The most important thing - for me - is simple: Panic Room can stand on its own. And it has no real faults.I don't want to repeat others, but it seems that I have to for some. Yes, the burglars made some stupid mistakes, but hey, they aren't professionals and they are REAL men - not all criminals are "Die Hard"! And yes, Foster had to be a little bit "MacGyver" and yes, his daughter had to be diabetic, because we wanted an interesting and exciting film - if you would make Panic Room with my sister and her daughter, believe me, it wouldn't be near that entertaining! And the little things... Why is that ventillation system accessible from the inside? Because the panic room isn't a prison for God's sake, its designers were not thinking about cut phone lines and criminals just wanting to get in there! (But anyway, there were that other tube leading to fresh air.) And the cameras... So simple. At the start they were the only way of two-way communication. After that they just wanted to frighten the women so it made sense to let them see what they are up to. Maybe later it would be wiser to set them off but they just forget it (they aren't perfect and they were in a stress).All in all: Panic Room is a great film, 10/10.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Light on Suspense</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When the movie came out, I was rolling my eyes thinking how could they make a movie like this. Two hours about being stuck in a room that is impenetrable, how much excitement could there be? But figuring David Fincher is going to direct it, I thought he might be able to make something out of it.The movie had the usual Fincher touches from Fight Club, and there were a few scenes where I could feel my heart beating. But I could not say the suspense held on long enough for it to be fully effective. It was basically many short break-out/break-in attempts in between rest periods. But the rest periods were not like a commercial break, since there were still a feeling of despair during those time. Also, I guess the writers threw in the diabetic daughter so that it would not just be a sleep-through for the women trapped in the safe roomThere were more than once where I keep thinking why those men did or did not do such and such (like take out the cameras or make a story up about getting access to the safe), I shouldn't have to come to those thoughts, especially when there are three of them there with at least one that has a brain. Even a thing or two that Jodie Foster's character did came into doubt in my mind. She could have bluffed about calling the police with a cell phone she had when they showed that they cut the phone line.It comes down to the weakness of the script. Lack of events to allow the director to do his stuff.Still, a decent movie.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-06-04</date>
		<username>SanderStrijbos</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Great Thriller (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Another great film by my favorite director, David Fincher. Although the film doesn't reach the brilliance of Fight Club and Se7en, it's a very enjoyable film with great performances by all the actors.The story is known, so I won't spend any time on it here. Koepp's script is no Academy Award winner, but surprisingly clever for a big-budget film. God knows we've seen enough (too) simple scripts turned into box-office smash-hits. And Fincher knows what to do with it. He lets the camera spin, fly, move through the house, ceilings, walls and floors. Very close to Fight Club, these camera-moves.Another great thing is that we never leave the house during the actual story. From the moment we take a look (with the characters) in the house, we stay there. That's also a good thing. We learn to know the house along with Meg and her daughter.The villains aren't the most clever people alive. One times, when Meg does something (won't say it here), Raoul says: "Why didn't we do that?" and that makes the character more human than the average Euro-terrorists who dominate action films so much. People I know said the burglars made stupid mistakes. Well, people make stupid mistakes.Minor things I liked: the opening credits. Brilliant. Perfect. The weaknesses of Meg and her daughter. They aren't perfect, just like the bad-guys and that makes them human and we can relate to them.One thing I didn't like (and now the spoiler comes): The final scene. We see Meg and her daughter on a bench in a park, looking for a new house. In my opinion it didn't add anything to the movie and we left the house. I'd like us to stay in the house until the very end.In general this is a great film, has its minor flaws, but they are compensated with a clever script, great performances, terrific camera work, perfect direction and the house itself, which I thought was one of the main characters. It might be a little bit of a safe bet for Fincher to do a big studio film. Personally I'd like to see him more risky projects, like Se7en and Fight Club, but he does a great job here and gives me confidence in Fincher doing Mission: Impossible 3, like the rumors are.</fullReview>
	</review>

Well the images are not so innocent as that because as a matter of fact that house is heavily sinister and we don't understand why a young woman and her early teen-age daughter like it so much. So the inner view of the house combined with the sound track music make us shiver from the beginning. The foreseen danger materializes itself soon in the persons of 3 more or less awkward and somewhat human burglars that enter the house with the aim of finding a lot of money they know it's hidden in the panic room, a kind of inexpugnable bunker against burglars where the woman and the girl take refuge and close themselves in. Well I won't tell you the rest of the story of course which develops itself in a succession of events full of suspense until the final outcome which will rivet your attention until the end. On the negative side of this kind of movies there is always of course a certain amount of clichés but anyhow in this case not very unplausible. All the actors play their parts with talent but not with a special genius. Though not a masterwork this movie will not make you feel you have wasted your time by watching it providing you are a movie fan of course.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-05-30</date>
		<username>HotPopMcLintock</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>A stunning piece of work</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Although many of my fellow users here have criticised this movie for not being another "Fight Club", I think this factor remains one of the strongest points in its favour. This is David Fincher's movie, no doubt about it. The performances are all superb, and the script is well paced and often witty; but this is a truly masterful film maker flexing his "mainstream" muscles. Wow.I loved every second of it, for one pure and simple reason; I had totally forgotten what it felt like to use the edge of my seat in a cinema. A "thriller" had become a reason to stay at home - as Hollywood is still consistently rewarding mediocre, and just plain untalented, film makers in the mainstream sector. The Hitchcock comparisons, I feel, are hugely apt; but for me this is Fincher's pure, unadulterated homage to his beloved "Jaws".And although it obviously doesn't scale the dizzy artistic heights of "Fight Club" or even "Se7en", it shows the auteur theory in all its bright, shining glory. "Panic Room" is quite simply the work of a master.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-05-30</date>
		<username>serafina_vespertine</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>A nice ride, tad predictable - spoiler!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie really did have me on the edge of the seat - however the movie was not completely perfect.Some of the plot was predictable - such as when the three men kept arguing, and the fact that it seemed obvious it would lead in part to their downfall, and the ending was a tad trite - however in terms of a suspense movie, I think it really delivered.It has been accused of several flaws which I thought I would address in my own understanding of the movie:- that you could speak out of the panic room, but not in.. I don't remember anything being said about that, and when it did happen, Jodie Foster's character used an intercom which I thought was part of the security system in general.- that "Raoul" could not have gotten his hand stuck due to sensors being in the door. Yes there were sensors, in my understanding there was one at the head, one at the chest area and one at the feet - but these don't sweep the whole way down, therefore if his hand was not where a sensor was, it would get caught (which it did).One flaw that really was a flaw however was the gas cylinder scene - it was wishful thinking to believe that it would be possible to do that and not blow the whole place up or something equally drastic!!I find the movie visually was quite appealing, and the opening credits really set the scene, and made me think this movie was going to be something different than a movie about a panicky mum.As to Meg turning away the cops - well it's simple really.. if she let them in, the men would have killed her daughter for sure, but by not letting them in on anything, she could be sure that at least whilst inside that room, her daughter would be safe. As to why she didn't wink etc.. I'm not sure, it could be something to do with the fact that she was freshly divorced and wanted to prove she could stand on her own and be just as capable as any man.All in all, it's NOT a waste of money, it's a nice ride even though at some points a tad predictable - in general, I don't think David Fincher has let himself down with this one.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Skilfull thriller, but disappointing for Fincher</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Panic Room" is all in all a very thoroughly made thriller. The acting is good and especially Forest Whitacker's character is very likeable in spite of the fact that he's a bad guy. But still, seeing that this movie is directed by one of the most promising and brilliant directors of the past decade, having brought us movies like "Fight Club" and "Seven", it's simply way too standard: there's a happy end, there aren't any major plot twists etc.Very enjoyable, very high production standards, but ultimately a bit disappointing.*** out of **** stars</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-05-19</date>
		<username>Howlin Wolf</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Caution! Deflate expectations and don't compare it to most of Fincher's past work, and you'll be fine... (SPOILERS MARKED WITHIN)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First, the bad news. Barring "The Game", the spectacle and effect of which was utterly ruined by the ending, (see review) this is definitely David Fincher's worst film to date. This does not mean it is bad, though; it is indeed quite watchable. All the 'star power' and innovative direction in the world only JUST manages to overcome a fairly formulaic premise and a dull script. THAT is where this film's problem lies.I actually believe it would have been far more interesting to see the Meg Altman character as being destroyed by her divorce, and relying on the mental strength of her young daughter to get her through the resurgence of vulnerability that occurs when three men have the nerve to invade the sanctity of her home. There are little hints of this sort of direction in the script, but they were never pursued far enough for my liking.I understand it was originally going to be set up as I describe, until the script was tailored to suit Jodie Foster's participation after she replaced Nicole Kidman due to a knee injury. Whilst such a change undoubtedly suits Foster's style, it probably hurts the film. Young Kristen Stewart showed me that she was a more than capable enough actress to be able to handle more complex material like that, so it was a little disappointing to see the film descend into a fairly predictable tit-for-tat battle between the indignant homeowner and the burglars. Forest Whitaker is also another standout on the acting side, doing well with a clichéd role. I can't complain about Foster's performance, since I've never seen her be anything less than excellent. I just felt her character to be rather perfunctory. All of them are, in fact, with the already mentioned exception of the young daughter. On a completely base note, special mention must go to the person who recommended Jodie Foster wear such a low-cut top for the predominant part of the movie!(MAJOR SPOILER COMING UP!)After the fairly surprising death of one of the main characters, the script provides no more shocks for Fincher to buoy the material with, so the production design and cinematography are the only things left to help the actors keep us interested. Although that side of the movie is admittedly excellent, at this point there is still a sizable chunk of the movie left, and the 'gasp' factor is now virtually nil. The great visuals could seriously have used a bit more substance to back them up.(END OF SPOILER)As a result of this lack of depth, I found the villains to be much more interesting than our two heroines, because, despite being similarly simplistic, at least they were occasionally funny! This unusual development left the ending something of a moot point for me; which is perhaps just as well, because it's every bit as unsurprising as most of what came before it.Even after taking into consideration its flaws, it's still a good watch; I guess I just expected more from a Fincher film. To be fair though, just like in "The Game" only to a much lesser extent, he gets his part of the job right, but is let down by the quality of writing he's working with.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-05-19</date>
		<username>Harrismh</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Nobody does feminine fear and rage better than Jody Foster.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>----POSSIBLE SPOILER----Panic Room is a thriller set in the NYC brownstone home of Meg Altman [Jody Foster] recently divorced with a young teenage daughter [Kristen Stewart]. The brownstone has a secret high tech `safe room'; legend has it the former owner left a fortune hidden in the building. It's Meg's first night in her new digs and she's just getting familiar with the phone and electronics system. Burnham, Raoul and Junior [Forest Whitaker, Dwight Yoakam, and Jared Leto, respectively] stop by looking for the money. Burnham installed the safe room system, Raoul nursed the former resident, and Junior is packing the heat. Meg and the kid head for the safe room, the intruder's breakout sledgehammers and other assorted goodies of mass destruction. A contest between brain and brawn ensues; in the end the bad guys are at least one `right-hand-man' short. [See the film to get the meaning of this last comment!]Panic Room is the best of the current litter of thriller / suspense films. The story keeps you on the edge of your seat [or maybe under it], without using Hollywood's dumb video tricks. The plot is focused and fast paced, the story is well scripted, and the acting sharp and expressive. Events are unpredictable leaving viewers to guess what's up next, even having seen the previews. All the action takes place within the brownstone, making the situation all the more focused. The exceptional cinematography starts with the rectilinear layout [squared angles] of the opening credits against NYC buildings; this is a clue of the photography yet to come.Nobody does feminine fear and rage better than Jody Foster, just ask Clarice Starling in Silence of The Lambs. Foster is at her prime in this film. The three stooges of break and enter, led by Forest Whitaker, are a case study of `honor among thieves' [or lack thereof] as they are foiled at each turn of events.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-05-17</date>
		<username>rdorsey</username>

		<shortDescription>Not too bad</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>As suspense movies go, Panic Room was definitely watchable and holds your attention throughout. Beyond that, there is nothing outstanding about the movie, nor anything tragically flawed. There are frequent times during the movie when you inevitably ask, "Why didn't she just do this?" or "Why don't they simply do that?". But those errors do not detract much from the action and the story maintains a healthy amount of believability. Six out of ten.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-05-13</date>
		<username>evilasahobby</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Old story, new look</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>At an early part of Panic Room, Jodie Foster's character remarks that the panic room is "very Poe", or something to this effect. This description is very apt for the film overall, as Panic Room is a very dark, gothic film in tradition with Edgar Allen Poe's work. However it can also be seen as a reference to the movie narrative - you've probably seen or heard it before.I couldn't really get into this film. The camera manipulation is very good with the house being fully explored by this floating point of view, but it feels like the camera replaces any real attempt at plot. Its nice to be able to see everything, but maybe that's the film's problem - it lets you see everything, where it may have been more effective to keep certain things hidden. The panic room is meant to be a closed, tiny space with minimal outside interaction, but instead we fly around the house, listen in on the criminals, go back to the room, watch the criminals some more, etc. The atmosphere is never really allowed to build. Foster's character (and her daughter) are never in any real danger except for the climax, and even then you can see what's coming. In the hands of a lesser director or cast, this would have been a really mediocre film, but Fincher does a fantastic job in setting the style and tone, with the cast putting in a really solid performance. It's a stretch for no-one, however, and isn't worth all the hype its been getting. Even ignoring all of the plot holes, Panic Room is really a see-once-and-forget film. *SPOILER* What really destroyed this film for me was that everyone seemed willing to help (police, neighbours, ex-husband) and yet Foster's character shut them out and went it alone. Again, the panic room is meant to be a small, shut-off area, yet every attempt at seeking help is successful but unwanted when it arrives.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-05-13</date>
		<username>sharron albert (morgana@gci.net)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A must for Jodie Foster fans</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was very pleased with this flick. It has few 'idiot' devices (i.e. only an idiot would do that), something I abhor in a thriller/mystery. How do you trap someone in their panic room so that they can't alert the police? Do it the first night in their new home, before everything is hooked up. That's not giving away much, as it happens early in the film. Thus begins the series of problems for everyone: victims and criminals.The criminals have their own problems: they didn't know anyone had moved in yet, so their keys didn't work, and what they want is in the panic room. As they attempt to coax the victims out, they have internal conflicts about how to proceed. There's a fair amount of dithering by them as one thing after another goes awry, but they are human reactions, not just plot conventions.I've admired Jodie Foster movies for a long time, as she picks good scripts and portrays strong women. As a mother, trying to protect her daughter and to figure out how to get out of this dilemma, she's done it again. The character isn't perfect, but she doesn't panic and she uses her brain.The acting is excellent to very good. Worth seeing on the large screen so you can be fully absorbed in the story.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-05-12</date>
		<username>(christianhut@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Fincher goes Hitchcock or Fincher goes commercial?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>***Minor spoilersLet's get one thing out of the way first; David Fincher is my favorite director. He has a talent for using all tricks in the cinematic book in a way that perfectly marries the content. He also always makes the most out of every script, which means the comparative quality of the movie relies strongly on the quality of the script Fincher has to work from. Alien 3 was a false start for Fincher, a mangled and predictable script made watchable by excellent direction and some good acting. In the cases of Se7en and Fight Club the screenplays were brilliant and so are the movies. The Game has a script that's slightly more streamlined toward being a full-blown blockbuster, but contains enough subtext to be fascinating in its own right; so is the film. This brings us to his latest film and a strong contender for the worst screenplay Fincher has worked from (yes, that includes Alien 3 and his Madonna videos).I won't even begin summing up all the plot holes David Koepp has come up with (ripped off is more accurate). And the fact he's aware of some of them (a villain says `we could've done that' after Jodie Foster's Meg Altman smashes the cameras) doesn't make them any less dumb. There's a case to be made for characters not behaving completely rational in the circumstances the movie presents, but Panic Room frequently stretched my ability to suspend my disbelief. Fincher does a good job of masking some of them (apart from one particular and far too explosive sequence), but no amount of great directing could ever compensate for the script's inclination towards cheap thrills.Koepp's screenplay is conceptually quite strong but turns out to be not only a shelter for plot holes you could build a panic room in, but also a collection of ideas that you could call 'tried-and-tested'. I would rather call them tired-and-testing. You've heard the derogatory terms before; it's Die Hard in a house! or: it's a grown-up Home Alone! - although to be fair the Home Alone flicks are far more sadistically violent. There's truth to both labels, but it goes beyond that. A scene echoing Rear Window I can forgive, but does that cops-knocking-on-the-door sequence have to be lifted from Bound entirely? And is it just me or does the (in itself excellent) opening sequence merely update the one from North by Northwest? Then there's the use of plot devices so familiar you have trouble actually remembering in what film you've seen it before (because it's ten movies, not one). The best example may be the diabetic kid fitted as standard.Another thing I appreciate in Fincher's other films is the amount of depth he finds room for. One thing becomes clear when watching this film, it's Fincher's Hitchcock project, a thriller played straight with some technical wizardry supporting it (lots of CG camerawork and a reverse dolly zoom, a technique pioneered by Hitch in Vertigo, as the final shot), but a thriller which mainly goes for suspense. While Fincher's direction goes a long way in the suspense department (he cleverly bypasses the predictability of the screenplay) he doesn't seem to have applied any knowledge about why (certain) Hitchcock films are still interesting. Those films' main strength are the strong psychological themes throughout (Psycho, Rear Window and Vertigo). While Koepp makes some desperate resort to Altman's claustrophobia, it doesn't really go for that angle. In fact it doesn't seem to go for any psychological angle at all. As such, I found it too plot driven and lacking characters I really connected with. That lack of depth in any sense may not kill the movie, but it does reinforce my impression that this is Fincher's 'good-career-move' flick. A straight, stylish thriller with plenty box office potential but little substance. It feels somewhat like a film to rebound his career after cult hit Fight Club became a box office dud.BUT....like I said, while the writing on this film isn't anything to be proud of, in terms of bringing it to screen there are little errors. Fincher succeeds in drawing tension from the most trivial of scenes, using his trademark bag of tricks. He's helped by Howard Shore's fitting soundtrack as well. Again every one of his shots is interesting in itself while they still serve a function, which is atmosphere. It's not as doom-laden as Se7en but threat is always sustained throughout. Panic Room isn't simply stylistically satisfying the way most Hollywood movies are nowadays. It goes beyond that. Technically, this really is a masterpiece. Also, Fincher gets the best out of his cast. Foster has a few truly wonderful (short and emotional) beats, while also showing being capable of handling a physical role such as Meg's. And the triple act of the burglars works wonders, even if Dwight Yoakam goes far OTT by the end.So how to rate a film which I thoroughly enjoyed due to direction, acting and the excellent work by all technical departments (the set-design is absolutely brilliant, as is the cinematography), but rubbed me the wrong way it terms of writing? Hollywood High Concept filmmaking and Hitchcockian direction go head to head in this one (where they should have gone hand to hand), and I feel the first wins in the long run. Make no mistake, I DID have a good time watching this, but will I be talking about it in a week or so? No, and that's less than I expect from Fincher.Rating: 6/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-05-11</date>
		<username>Jenny Ho</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Simple but exciting concept</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The ?panic room' of the film's title is a sealed off room designed as part of a house for refuge during an emergency situation. It is also equipped with screens which monitor activity in different locations inside the house.Jodie Foster plays a recently divorced mother who moves into a huge mansion in order to start afresh with her teenage daughter. Soon after mother and daughter move into their new home, three intruders break in with the intention of stealing and splitting the contents of a safe which resides in the house's panic room. This plan is foiled when they discover that the residents of the house have retreated into the same room.The break-in occurs soon after the scene is set: mother and daughter view the property and are introduced to the panic room concept; they move in and on their first night, the break-in occurs. The remainder of the action stays inside the house and because of this, the audience is able to become more involved in the events which occur. Tension is built up as the camera follows the movements of the intruders while the occupants sleep in their beds. Any woman who has ever slept in their home alone can surely relate to their vulnerability in this situation!Essentially the film is a ?cat and mouse' situation with the intruders who will try anything to get at their loot and the two heroines who will use unbelievably desperate and resourceful measures to escape and get rid of the bad guys. Although the situation is tense in the house, there is a surprising amount of humour in the film and this prevents the intruders from coming across as very menacing.It is also good to see Foster back on the screen ?like in ?Silence of the Lambs', she gives a convincing performance portraying a woman who is independent and strong enough to take matters in her own hands. The only thing I'm not convinced about the character is why on earth does she need such a big house for just herself and her daughter? ?Panic Room' does not have the impact of David Fincher's recent work ?Seven' and the ?Fight Club', being less dark and intense and more mainstream. My main concern before deciding to watch this film was whether such a simple concept would keep me interested for the full duration. I need not have been concerned ??Panic Room' is a very satisfactory thriller with enough exciting moments to keep you entertained for the full 1 hour 50 minutes.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>One of the best films of the year so far!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I waited eager with anticipation for this film as I am a big fan of David Fincher, he is a great director, Seven was one of the best thrillers ever made and the Game and Fight Club were two eerie and surreal films that demand watching. The Panic Room is a great film, simply because the Direction is excellent and the acting top notch, these both combine to create a tense and exciting thriller. While the story is fairly simple and far more straight forward than Finchers other films, in particular the Game and Fight Club, the film sets out to keep us on the edge of our seats with suspense and successfully does that. Fincher directs with style and perfectly captures the dark and unsettling atmosphere the house provides, the cinematography in this is very good. There is some stylish camera movement that weaves through the house and this is used to good effect as the camera will smoothly drift from one floor of the house to another. The acting is great in particular from Jodie Foster, Kristen Stewart (as Fosters daughter) and the reluctant crook played by Forrest Whittaker. There are also some elements of humour incoperated in the film just to lighten the tone every now and again. Jodie Foster is at the top of her game and she also looks very good in this as the mother who turns at to be a pain in the ass for the three crooks as the film turns out as almost a very dark and errie Home Alone without the annoying blond kid who can't act (sorry Mackauly but you can't mate). They never try to make Foster so tough she turns into a Lara Croftesque action woman, just an intelligent woman doing her best to keep her daughter from harm. The film never drags and while this doesn't compare to some of Finchers other films it still has his trademark atmosphere and is certainly one of the best films that has come out in 2002 so far. 8/10</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-05-05</date>
		<username>(notahappybunny)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Testament to Fincher's Ongoing Legacy</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Whilst not quite the exception that was Fight Club and Seven, Fincher's latest masterpiece is certainly a lesson in the art of suspense; one that seems to have escaped other Directors since Hitchcock's time.From the outset, and the disorientating opening credits, Fincher litterally winds the audience up to a frenzy of paranoia with his obscure angles and rollercoaster camerawork. Blazing a trail through his house of terror, the Director performs stunning and inspirational shots of the kind we should expect to see many more of in the future.The acting too is first rate stuff with seasoned pro Jodie Foster slipping on her thriller guise to give an excellent performance as Meg Altman, distraught single mother. For someone who has been outside of the A-list for such a long time Jodie delivers a truly emotional character, complete with tear-jerking hurt. You FEEL her isolation, as well as seeing it in the low angled shots that make Fincher's location even larger and more looming.The Panic Room itself however, is another story. Once forced into the Panic Room, a safe house to rest and relax whilst the police come to your rescue, Fincher goes to work on the claustrophobia, downsizing the room in contrast to give Meg and her daughter Sarah's (Kristen Stewert)'panic' all the more believability.Forest Whitaker too proves that his soulful, deep characters don't stop with lone ninja assassins (Ghost Dog) as the haunted Burnham, one of the three thieves who breaks into Altman's home. Torn by inner conflicts Whitaker takes Burnham and gives him the sympathetic edge the audience needs. Dwight Yoakam performs marvelously as the masked psycho and Jared Leto's inept idiot provides the black humour rounding off an excellent cast.The script is not a big thinker, there's no philosophy in this Fincher flik, but the Director handles it well, considering the single location, single concept premise. In short this film comes highly recommended.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-05-04</date>
		<username>The Movie Buff</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Well written, acted, directed</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic room is a first class thriller. It is a completely fresh idea. As stated above, the acting, script, and directing were all top notch. So far it is the best movie of 2002. Panic room wastes very little time setting up the story. After a brief intro, they get right down to business. After a while the camera work gets a little annoying, penetrating vents, pipes, and hoses, but it doesnt distract from the film. The movie possess some of the most heart pounding moments in recent time. Most of the intense moments, such as when Jodi Foster left the panic room to get her cell phone, were all done in slow motion, which increased one's pulse. If they had been done in real time they would not have been as effective.  The movie didnt allow itself to get too serious, presenting some comic relief scenes that were done perfectly, ie they were funny enough to get a laugh, yet not too funny to distract from the overall theme and feeling of the movie. This is the first movie I have seen in a while were I cannot add any suggestions to improve the movie. Listen for Panic rooms name at next year's oscars.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-05-01</date>
		<username>phiggins</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>In its own limited way, a work of genius.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Spoiler warning. Despite the plot flaws, the disappointing ending, the lapses in logic and sense, this is still, somehow, a wonderful thriller. It delivers crazy tension and laughs in equal measure, until you think you might just go insane. The set-up is ludicrously simple: Jodie and her kid move into a house which has a "Panic Room" and then bad guys show up so they get into the "Panic Room". And that's about it. Except of course that the bad guys are actually quite sympathetic and interesting characters, especially the dude played by the great Forrest Whitaker, about whom more later. There's some superb banter between these dolts, including the great exchange: "Who ARE you?" "I'm Raoul." You have to see it to appreciate it. The first ten minutes set up the relationship between Jodie and her daughter (who looks uncannily like McCauley Culkin, star of that other "Trapped-in-a-house-full-of-bad-guys" movie...) with great economy and should be seen by anyone who wants to see efficient film-writing in action. It's nothing fancy, but it works. Night falls and the bad guys show up. They could just be anonymous goons in balaclavas, but they're not. They're real people. They screw up and argue and are not particularly bright. This is both refreshing and annoying. The latter because we empathise with Whitaker's character but he's technically a baddie, so we know he's doomed. He has some bright ideas but they're half-hearted and don't amount to much. His sad, mournful face is as expressive here as in anything he's done, and it would have been interesting to make the whole film from his point of view: some guys break into a house that they think is deserted and find that someone's living there. He is torn between getting the money and not hurting the people. Instead, this dilemma is there in the film, but it doesn't amount to much. Jared Leto and Dwight Yoakam are superb as the other two crims. Yoakam in particular as the super-cool Raoul is a delight to watch. Meanwhile, in the Panic Room, Foster and the kid are finding there are all sorts of ways they can get back at the intruders. Cue lots of flames, running around to get the cell phone, etc. Why didn't the baddies just wait outside the room until she was forced to come out? Which would have happened, as her kid has diabetes. Which is another handy plot point, is it not? It gives Forrest a chance to redeem himself by administering her injection later on. Which makes his fate all the more unfair. Why didn't Whitaker's character, who knows how these rooms are built, know there was a hole in the wall that led to the outside? Couldn't he have somehow pumped gas/bullets/whatever through there? Couldn't he just have stopped their air supply? Why didn't Jodie get burned when she lit the gas? While you're watching it, these points don't matter, as the film has you in its ultra-tight grip. Fincher's camera glides through the house, through key-holes, through light-bulbs, etc. etc. Presumably he's worked out that there's really not that much you can do to make a film like this exciting. Two people stuck in a room. Bad guys outside. Yawn. Somehow he has managed to turn a ludicrous premise into a gripping, hypnotic thriller. It would have been nice to see what happened to Whitaker's character at the end, as many critics have pointed out. Going from Jodie's frazzled, blood-stained features to a nice shot of her and the kid in Central Park discussing where to move to seems at first a little insulting. Maybe that's the point. "Nice" upper class folks like Jodie give not a f**k about anyone but themselves. They don't care what happened to the guys who threatened them, so why should we? And why SHOULD we? In her situation would we be sympathetic if they terrorised us but they really needed the money for their kids or whatever? So what? Get the hell out of my house. "Panic Room" in the end then becomes metaphor for the class war. The bad guys are out there. Some of them have needs and motives that are not necessarily bad in themselves, but drive them to do bad things. So what? Get the hell out of my house.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-30</date>
		<username>GroovyDoom</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Wait Until Panic Room.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>David Fincher offers up an array of fancy camerawork in `Panic Room' that has probably made Dario Argento green with envy. Jodie Foster also turns in a solid performance, as she usually does, and Kristen Stewart really holds her own next to Foster while playing her slightly difficult daughter.The script, however, is strictly run-of-the-mill stuff dressed up in extravagant sets, so don't go into this expecting any outlandish surprises. The script is basically a rewrite of "Wait Until Dark", snipping out the blind element and making the spunky young girl the heroine's daughter. Just like that film (and a great many more), this movie gives us three villains: a sleazy creep with some ill-advised cornrows; a home-invader with a heart of gold; and of course the mandatory psychopath. In fact, I kept thinking of `Wait Until Dark' so much that when Jodie Foster started knocking out all of the lights in the house with a sledgehammer, I wasn't surprised.The premise is probably well-documented by now: mother and daughter buy an impossibly large `townstone' in Manhattan, then end up having to utilize it's well-stocked bunker on the very first night they are there, when they find themselves victimized by thugs after the hidden money that the house's former tenant left behind after his death.That's about it for plot. The movie wastes no time getting into its cat-and-mouse situation, and pretty soon the ball is rolling. The weird thing is that even though the movie works, it still feels a little empty. My initial reaction after it was over is that it wasn't as engaging as it could have been. Nothing happened in it that I did not expect.For instance, Forest Whitaker's character is the humanist crook. He doesn't want to hurt anybody, unlike Dwight Yoakam's Raoul, who wears an understated ski mask and who obviously intends to use the gun he brought along on the mission. Whitaker delivers the requisite moments of clemency, while Yoakam handles the terror efficiently. The remaining crook, played by Jared Leto, is so badly drawn that you know exactly what's going to happen to him when things start going wrong.Fincher does deliver some virtuoso set pieces, most of them involving those kinds of scenarios where movie characters only have moments to sprint to safety while the villains are hot on their tails. These scenes deliver the only real excitement in `Panic Room', while the rest of it (like the annoying bickering between the crooks) seems designed to create tension through aggravation. There were a couple of ridiculous things that happened, including a scene where Jodie sticks her arm in a vent to ignite some concentrated fumes and emerges from the experience without a burn, but I was mostly aggravated by the more obvious elements of the plot, which sort of defused a lot of the potential that the film had.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-30</date>
		<username>Ali B (xzjq@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>One of the best action-thrillers I have seen in a long time...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What can I say? It's been almost 2 hours since I walked out of the preview screening... and I'm struggling to find a flaw in the whole film. The acting is top-notch, with the characters being believable and the talents sliding into these forms effortlessly. Jodie Foster stands out though as Meg, the lead character who has just gone through a divorce and is trying to settle down in a new house with her daughter. As a strong Fincher fan I was not at all disappointed with this film, as I knew before I saw it that there was no way it would be as good as Fight Club. It was better than The Game (starring Michael Douglas), which I thought was dragged out a bit too much and had an ending which, amongst my group of friends and myself, has been the target of many laughable conversations, although I guess there wasn't really any alternative... I can only pick on one part of Panic Room - the ending. I won't give anything away (coz that'd be nasty) but you do get out of your seat thinking "hmmm. I wish they'd at least done something better with the money than that..." Otherwise, all the other Fincherisms were there. The CG-assisted camera shots moving through walls etc (like in Fight Club) could be considered overkill, but I prefer to look at them as required art which raises the tension by portraying the proximity of the burglars to the females, whilst raising the sense of chlaustrophia in the Panic Room itself. With enough touches of humour to call this a part-comedy, this is a thriller that grabs you, throws you about a bit and doesn't let go until the final scene... and the action sequences themselves are pulled off with incredible stamina and energy. And boy, that bit with the cellphone, all in slow-mo and absolutely NO sound whatsoever... had me sweating! This is going straight on my 'to-buy' list...</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I never liked Jodie Foster, in fact the only movie of hers that I ever enjoyed was "Contact" (1997), and when walking into the theatre to see "Panic Room" I wasn't expecting much from her, but I knew that "Fight Club" director David Fincher was behind the camera and I had a feeling it would be good. Panic Room opens up introducing divorcee Jodie Foster and her daugther (whos father is rich, and is the only reason why Foster's character can afford such an expensive Brownstone, if it weren't for the daughter, Foster would most likeley be living in some cheap 2-bedroom apartment)and they move into a new home. 	<review>
		<date>2002-04-29</date>
		<username>mikel weisser</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>latest header trip intensely effective despite a few tired tricks</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>SPOILER ALERT. once again the stylish vision of david fincher gives us some heady visuals in his 2002 thriller, Panic Room, a film so effective at creating viewer tension that it handily surpasses its few glaring lapses into mundane cliche film making. from the very beginning with its surrealistic cityscape title sequence there isn't a doubt that fincher eye for the unusual is as keen as ever. once the paranoia soaked plot, of jody foster and her ill daughter trapped in a house w/ three seriously ruthless home invaders, gets underway, for a sustained hour and a half the viewer's breathing comes in "oh my god, what'll happen next!" gasps and veteran spookmeister screenwriter david koepp's plotting stylishly works itself through an impressive series of variations on the old cat and mouse routine. BUT STILL, a couple garish visual and plotting cliches and a few major logic faults in the final ten minutes hold this one back from the seamless excellence of Fincher's benchmark tour de force, Fight Club. maybe not a rare truly visionary classic like his last film, but Panic Room is easily the best pulse pounding thriller you'll likely runs into anytime soon. i just wish fincher hadn't given his unique New York vision such a worn-out Hollywood ending.</fullReview>

The three of them work on trying to get into the Panic Room while not trusting each other and not sure about the motives of the other two.This turns out to be quite interesting and suspenseful at parts. The movie has good dialogue and comes off as being believable. Panic Room does not try to be anything other than entertaining and suspenseful. It does not attempt to be a great movie but meets the goal it has set for itself.Panic room earns a strong 8 out of 10</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Thoroughly enjoyable and thrilling</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you've read plot summaries about this one and found yourself wondering how much suspense and thrill can you get from a movie whose entire storyline centres around one room, the answer is: "probably more than you think".This is a very good production with all the elements of a good thriller and will keep you on your toes throughout. Jodie Foster gives a splendidly controlled performance and David Fincher through excellent positioning of cameras always clearly defines the characters' positions in the house as well as in relation to each other. In addition he "sends" the camera through walls, keyholes and other unlikely places creating some very smooth footage that adds to suspense and is very enjoyable to watch.Again, this IS a tense movie, (probably just up there with "What Lies Beneath") and I fully recommend it as such. (8 out of 10)</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-23</date>
		<username>Johan Leupen</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Not altogether unsatisfying but ultimately unremarkable and forgettable.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room comes from director Fincher whose body of work up until now can be characterized as refreshing and unconventional, even if not all of his efforts have been succesful. It is therefor surprising to see him turn out something that is relatively run-of-the-mill and unremarkable. Panic Room relies on the premise of a mother (Foster) and her child finding themselves trapped in their own house by criminals, having to retreat into a so-called panic room, their only safe haven. In this sense at least it fits into the paranoia-realm that Fincher made his own. Panic Room doesn't suffer from any obvious flaws. Stilistically, the film bears the Fincher-trademark: the sets are dark and gritty, a lot of attention has been spend on detail (especially on the dimly lit panic room itself). Also, the opening-credits sequence deserves special mention. Furthermore, Panic Room features many acrobatic camera-movement as previously seen in Fight Club, although i have to say i sometimes found it too distracting from the narrative. Whitaker is unremarkable as on of the criminals suffering from a morality-attack in the middle of his operation, his acting-range is basically reduced to looking really sad and troubled. Few can be said concerning Foster's acting: it is solid but lacks depth. This is probably not her fault as her role is underwritten; we constantly see her heavy-breathing with eyes bulging out of their sockets but there is relatively little dialogue for her to excell at and there is little complexity to her character. Twists are few and none of it made much of an impression on me. Panic Room is violent but not earthshocking in any way (as we have come to expect from Fincher, eventhough it may not be fair to compare this to his other work). The problem with Panic Room lies in it's subject matter or lack thereof. One of the strengths of Fight Club was it's tendency to cover a lot of ground, tying together many loose ends that didn't seem to add up. The same holds true for The Game, which is extremely cleverly constructed in retrospect. In Panic Room storytelling is chronological, restricted to one space and one (all-seeing) perspective, all of these restrictions add up to a film that isn't altogether unsatisfying but ultimately unremarkable and forgettable.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-23</date>
		<username>supertedg</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Reading about the production and plot of this movie online I was a little skeptical at first, it seemed a bit of a let down compared to previous movies Fincher had done. But seeing it at a cinema - WOW - it is incredible.From the funky opening credits to the amazing blue-flame scene in the "panic room" to an ending which actually makes you feel sorry for a criminal who broke into this poor lady's house, this movie has it all! Everything about this movie is great, especially Fincher's directing. CGI is used extensively, but not "overused" or made to seem too gimmicky like the new Star Wars films. Parts of it felt so much like a "true" sequel to Silence of the Lambs, especially when one of the crooks took of his mask and looked exactly like Buffalo Bill! Best movie of 2002.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-22</date>
		<username>JessicaBrandy</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Maybe not "Wait Until Dark" but definitely an amazing movie</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>How funny. On the way home from seeing the movie my boyfriend says to me, "Do you remember 'Wait Until Dark' with Audrey Hepburn and Alan Arkin?" and I was nodding in total agreement. Yes, this movie totally reminded me of 'Wait Until Dark' and scrolling down I see a comment putting this movie down because of the connection (and now I'm convinced that there is a total connection). But is that a bad thing?? Movies are unbelievably unoriginal now-a-days but at least 'The Panic Room' takes the idea that the Hepburn movie had and used it well. Goodness, with Austin Powers 3, Charlie's Angles 2 (double unoriginal!), yet another Jason movie (just shoot me!), and a remake of 'The Warriors' coming soon, you would figure that at least they took an idea and made it really good, instead of ripping off one exact idea after another. I am shocked by the number of people that did not like this film. It was just such a good movie in my opinion. I'm always impressed with the cinematography of a film, and you can tell that the same director directed 'Fight Club'. Now, there are a lot of REALLY good shots in this film but that certainly didn't make it what it is. The story was just too cool. Now, don't think that everything about this movie is an A+. I thought Jared Leto was just over done a little, and the ending was a bit sloppy-ish. There was this here and there that will have you saying, "no no, you should have had her do this, or that" but its still okay...Hey we all want the girl to not go into the dark basement when the light is blown out and the suspense music is playing, but she does doesn't she?But there were just so many great scenes: **SPOILERS** When Jodie Foster had to run out for her cell phone and no music played, how unbelievably amazing! The continues shot of the house when the guys start breaking in. The scene where she comes out of the room for her daughters insulin and the ruffle that happens and the scenes after where she is just insane with determination to get her daughter well.I don't know...yes its a bit of a rip off from another movie, but you know what, its a good movie with a good idea, take it and make something with it. And, yes, it has its silly parts but all in all a must see and you must see it in the theaters. Its like a really good first date. When you think about the date over all, it was great, but I'm sure that not everything that came out of his mouth was perfect (especially the part where he still lives with his parents, yuck!)</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-22</date>
		<username>virek213</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Intense, claustrophobic thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The thing about PANIC ROOM, which combines elements of STRAW DOGS and WAIT UNTIL DARK in its story, is not merely the intensity of the situation, but also how extremely claustrophobic it feels. This is the first time in a good long while that a film can make the viewer feel literally trapped. Jodie Foster and Kristin Stewart are a mother and daughter who move into a Manhattan townhouse with a "panic room", a virtual 21st century fallout shelter complete with TV monitors and emergency supplies. To their horror, however, they find out they have to use it when three burglars (Forrest Whittaker, Jared Leto, Dwight Yoakam) break in, looking for a multi-million dollar stash. Worst of all, that stash is hidden in a wall safe whose location just happens to be the Panic Room itself!Except for an excess of profanity in the screenplay, both director David Fincher (SEVEN) and screenwriter David Koepp (JURASSIC PARK) have concocted perhaps the best example of a home invasion horror/suspense film since STRAW DOGS. Foster is, not surprisingly, incredibly good in her role, and Whittaker, though he plays a heavy, actually elicits a modicum of sympathy while his two "partners" go off on psychotic tangents.If you can stand the claustrophobic feel of it, PANIC ROOM is well worth the price of a ticket. It is one of the best films of 2002.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Mr. Fincher pulls it off again?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I must admit that when I went to go see Panic Room, it was with some bias. I really like what David Fincher has done in the past: Seven, Fight Club, The Game and I guess I am one of the few people that I know that really liked Alien 3. So, I expected to like Panic Room. And I did. The pacing was great, Jodi Foster was as brilliant as always, Jared Leto was cast perfectly, Dwight Yoakam seemed right; his character being close to, but a little more menacing than, Doyle from Sling Blade. Kristen Stewart did a note worthy job. She wasn't annoying to me at all, like so many movie children can be. The whole production was quite good. I had just one little problem with the Burnham character, played by Forrest Whitaker. His character was a little predictable, because it was played by Forrest Whitaker. You wouldn't expect Forrest Whitaker to be, or play, a REALLY, REALLY bad guy and true to form, his character is not. That aside the movie puts you into a very tense situation very quickly and keeps you there almost until the very end. I wont spoil a thing, but I kind of expected the end to be a very `Hollywood Ending' and it was a just a little bit `Hollywood', but not like it could have been. I'm glad my expectations weren't met. All in all, this was well worth the money paid to see it. Very entertaining. That's my take. What's yours?</fullReview>

		<username>Shane Abrahams</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Chick flick meets Action film (warning: spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is all about female empowerment. The basic plot is this: Smart, sexy newly divorced mother outwits bumbling male robbers. And on that level the plot works. In other words, if you're looking for some light entertainment to take your mind of your day to day problems, then this is a good way to kill a couple of hours. The main characters are well acted with great camera work and the director manages to keep the suspense going even though you can guess how its all going to end (I mean we've all seen Home Alone and we all know the dumb burglars are not going to get away with it). However, what spoils the film for me is the tedious sub plots: Foster coming to terms with her divorce and trying to build a relationship with her daughter. Okay, I realize its an unwritten rule in Hollywood that you can't have a convincing female lead who doesn't have some kind of emotional baggage. But, in this case it just slows down the film.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-04-16</date>
		<username>Unimatrix4567</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>"Panic" Not a Picnic</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Some movies are easy to get into, easy to rate, leaving you with a definite sense one way or the other as to how much you liked or disliked it. Then there are films like this one. "Panic Room" revolves around an interesting idea: a safe room in a house where the occupants can go if evil enters uninvited. Of course, that's exactly what happens. Pitting the grit and fierce motherly protection of Jodie Foster against the evil intent of Forest Whitaker and Dwight Yoakum, the script has some genuinely intense moments. Dwight Yoakum? In one of the worst casting experiments in recent memory, Dwight does his best to separate the country singer from the country actor and (literally) falls flat on his face. There was so much unrealized potential in this roll that could have been filled with so many competent actors (Gary Oldman and Kevin Spacey come to mind). Then there is the script --- more full of holes than a donut factory (you will count at least three continuity errors and a few lapses in character motivation that must have been caused by some serious editing). But, thankfully, there is the strength and center of Jodie Foster to carry the movie....and carry it she does. She is a wonder to watch. I just wonder why I watched it.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>emccarthy-2</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Tribute to Die Hard?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>****Mild Plot Spoilers Below*****When I saw the Preview for The Panic Room, I thought it looked like a domesticated version of the original Die Hard movie: a terrorist situation where much of the plot revolved around the fact that the setting was a controlled environment. That is, all the action was limited to the confines of a fixed setting without outside influence.When watching the film, I noticed minor plot devices which came right from Die Hard, such as the breaking of the glass in the bathroom to prevent a barefoot person from running through (a major plot point in Die Hard revolved around Bruce Willis being barefoot and his terrorist opponents shooting out all the windows in order to use the broken glass to limit his movement.) The other major similarity was the fact that in both films the loot was in the form of bearer bonds, and at the end of both films the bearer bonds were sent flying through the air, caught up in the wind current created by the rotor of a helicopter.Just curious as to whether anyone in common worked on both films or if Koepp or Fincher used these devices in the form of a tribute to one of the better action movies ever made.</fullReview>
