	<review>
		<date>2002-04-14</date>
		<username>clover27</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Pleasantly Surprised</shortDescription>
		<fullReview> I was surprised at just how much I enjoyed Panic Room. Having seen the trailer beforehand, and being put off by its overbaring noir-ish tone, I nearly didn't go. However, being a fan of director David Fincher (and an even bigger fan of his last directorial effort, 'Fight Club') I decided to check it out. I'm glad I did. Jodie Foster gives an excellent performance as beleaguered mother Meg Altman, and newcomer Kristen Stewart is wonderful as Meg's daughter, Sarah. Forest Whitaker delivers a solid performance as Burnham, the burglar with a conscience, as does Jared Leto as the cocky young Junior.Panic Room is an effectively thrilling ride of a movie, utilizing some excellent performances, fantastic camera work, awesome special effects and an almost water-tight script. It's a much-abused cliche when discussing movies within its genre, but Panic Room really does leave you on the edge of your seat for the majority of its 112 minutes. My only real complaints with the film are uneven performances by two of the actors. Patrick Bauchau who plays Stephen Altman, the ex-husband of Jodie Foster's Meg Altman does not imbue his character with any sort of personality whatsoever, and as a result his character comes across as flat and one dimensional. Maybe it's partially because the Stephen Altman character is not (physically) introduced until around halfway through the film, but we are not really given any idea of what sort of character he is. (And consequently, you don't really care what happens to him.) Dwight Yokam's portrayal of Raoul, one of the burglars, seems to be a 'paint-by-numbers thug' role. He does no favours (to either movie or audience) by playing it as such. These instances where there is definite lack of character development are minor blemishes on what is ultimately an effective and engrossing thriller. Watch out for a cameo by ?Seven' scribe Andrew Kevin Walker as a clueless neighbour and a (vocal) cameo by Nicole Kidman as Stephen Altman's bitchy girlfriend. I'd recommend Panic Room as a good thriller movie - but if you're squeamish, you might be best to wait for this one on video so you can skip the yucky bits. ;)9 out of 10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-04-11</date>
		<username>Josh (darkjosh333@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Suspenseful, But Nowhere Near Fincher's Previous Work</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>After delving into a different dimension with Fight Club, David Fincher has returned to the genre that helped realize his brilliance. Panic Room brings Fincher back into the suspense game, directing Jodie Foster in a thriller that finds her forced to retreat into the room of said title.David Koepp (Stir of Echoes) scripts this potboiler about a recently divorced mother (Foster) and her diabetic daughter (Kristen Stewart) move into a New York home whose previous owner had a panic room built in; basically it's a room surrounded by steel and filled with surveillance monitors, medical kits, and water to last for days. It's a good thing, too, since on their first night, three burglars (played well by Whitaker, Leto, and Yoakam) break in, attempting to find a fortune that's been hidden in, of course, the room.Foster is used to playing strong women roles, but she's never come off as being more resourceful as in Panic Room. She makes her character seem like less a victim than a force to be reckoned with, and instead ably matches her captors. Whitaker, Leto, and Yoakam all play their parts convincingly as the intelligent, strategic, and violent burglars, respectively. The only role that comes off as a plot device is the daughter, who seems to be there not as a character but more a hinderance to the film's heroine.Fincher is a master of suspense, and there are droves of it as Foster smartly and able participates in a game of cat-and-mouse with the thieves. She comes up with clever and effective ways of dealing with them, which I won't reveal here. Suffice to say there are many moments when the audience is riveted to the screen and also never feels as if the movie is becoming an implausible eye-roller. Panic Room isn't near Fincher's other work, but still is a tense, above average thriller. 7 out of 10</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-11</date>
		<username>Sean Choi</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>A stylish, well-made thriller.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>In the hands of a lesser director, "Panic Room" could have been all too routine and conventional. But thanks to the directorial skills of David Fincher, it rises above the average thriller coming out of Hollywood these days. It might seem at times that Fincher's too concerned with things like the film's visual style and CGI-assisted "camera movement" (e.g. there is an incredible scene where the camera glides down from the second floor into the kitchen, and then *through* the handle of a coffee pot and straight *into* a keyhole--and back out!), but that's part of what I like about this film. It's by a director that really loves and is a master of the craft of filmmaking, and is willing to shoot scenes in a creative, unconventional way. The suspense, after the initial set-up, is pretty taught and it never really lets up until the end. All-in-all, although Fincher fans might be somewhat "disappointed" that "Panic Room" isn't up to the level of "Fight Club," I think Fincher's latest effort is still worth seeing. It doesn't break new grounds, but it's a lot better than most so-called "thrillers" in recent memory ("Memento" being a definite exception).</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Captivating Thriller, Fincher reigns supreme once more</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>While his other movies have all silent thunderstorms, Panic Room has the media hype to match the brilliance of the film, for better or worse. I belieive worse. For people expecting some horror flick with a bit of a thrill you're mistaken. This film while it has its brilliant moments which will, shoot me for using this terribly over used cliche', have you sitting on the edge of your seat, is mainly a great film to watch, and watch again because of the mastery Fincher has over the camera, his ability to place the camera anywhere, and i use that in the exact sense, is spectacular. The film it self lacks the depth and creative flare commonly assosiated with this now, household name director. All the elements of this movie: music, cinematography, lighting... everything creates a wonderfully suspenseful story that keeps you on the edge of your seat until the last second. 		<date>2002-04-07</date>
		<username>zerodegreesk</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>OK... but that's about it</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This was just an ordinary movie in the "suspense" or "thriller" category. It does nothing new or extremely creative with itself. The script was predictable and mostly boring. What kind of twist can they put in these movies that makes them interesting throughout or worth spending an hour and a half watching them? There's no statement about anything. All of David Fincher's movies had this, in my opinion. It's obvious in Fight Club. There are messages in the other three, too. This movie was just... like, who cares about these people, really? These three thieves with the all too familiar character traits, er, faults. The wife of the rich dude who lives in this monsterous apartment with just her daughter, who is the only one worth caring about in the entire movie. Then there's the filmmaking itself to consider. Personally, I can't stand to have "impossible" camera shots in every other scene. It seemed that David Fincher used them tastefully in his past films, but in this one... it's CGI hell. I very much looked forward to seeing this movie, but wish I had chosen to see Blade II instead. Wait, as one last note, the acting is GREAT in this movie, seriously. Dwight Yoakam can play one MEAN character, I liked seeing more of Jaret Jeto and Forrest Whitaker is amazing, as usual. Jodie Foster and her daughter (sorry I didn't catch her name before I started this) were fantastic figuring they only had one room to work with for the majority of the movie. I guess really the main problem was I expected more out of the story. David Fincher has picked great scripts in the past, but he should have left this for Tony Scott or Remy Harlin or whoever directed Arnold Schwartzeneggar's last movie.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-07</date>
		<username>thedarkocean@netzero.net</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Painfully obvious-a Fincher failure (spoilers)</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Let's start with Fincher's main style and aesthetic. His dark, depressing lighting has become very stale. Like Marilyn Manson, provoking art is turning into a novelty. Does everyone in his movies like dank, grey lighting and interior decorating and clothing? Hopefully he will explore another area of his interest next time. Now, I'm not a film freak. I don't write reviews of every movie I see. And I think Fincher is okay making this film. It's a movie meant to scare, disturb and shake up preppies and make a lot of money-which is apparently did well so far. Let's start with the script-it's painfully obvious! The backstory is literally thrown in your face, and Koepp's sharp humor between the main characters just doesn't seem real. Everyone in this movie seems out of their element. They all give mediocre performances. Foster's motivations for her actions never come through clearly enough. All of the thiefs are basically idiots, and you would think that putting stupid thiefs up against stupid, frightened preppies would somehow even it out and make a decent movie, but it almost turns comedic instead of frightening. Once they realize that there's people in the house, they start their loud whisper argument-pretty intelligent! Leto, Yoakam and Whitaker just don't seem to gel as they should in this situation. It's pretty obvious Yoakam will do whatever he has to to get the money, including killing others and his partners, but Leto and Whitaker can't see this? Looks like Keystone Kapers from here on out. Once locked in the room, we're again subjected to Fincher's flickering flourescent lighting, giving us that grey Fight Club pallor. But look, it's dark and raining outside! Not surprising, given his other movies. Yoakam doesn't learn his lesson when the propane trick backfires, and he continues to aimlessly make idiotic decisions. When your characters lose common sense, they become less human and in turn less believable. The slow motion trick doesn't work, either-it just draws out a boring movie. My favorite scene is when Yoakam gets the sledgehammer across the jaw, falls down two flights and then crawls back up to fight again. Come on, Fincher, what are you doing? This isn't Scream. And finally, at the end, Whitaker happens to have his hand on the bonds when the cops nab him. Who's going to do that? Only him, I guess, just in time to throw them into the air in a Platoon-like arm raise that reminds me of the Green Mile. Watch the goods float away into the obvious wind machine rain! Pretty darn bad. Fincher has made Seven and Fight Club, so he is allowed to make some mistakes, so better luck next time! This is just a really bad movie on so many levels. Mediocre all the way.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-07</date>
		<username>matthew wilder (cosmovitelli@mediaone.net)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fincher-as-Mondrian</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The director, David Fincher, doesn't care who you root for; doesn't care if the heroine's little girl dies of diabetic shock; doesn't care if the righteous black man gets away in the end; doesn't care if the kinda-bad ex-husband gets his bones broken. He frankly doesn't give a rat's fat ass about much of anything except keeping the images as dark and monochromatic as Gordon Willis in the halcyon days of Don Corleone. Which, in these dog days, is fine with me. The premise is simple: Jodie Foster and Little Daughter are trapped in the high-tech (or so it seems) "panic room" of a pricy Upper East Side "townstone" while a troika of hoodlums tries to get in and kill them. The blunt basicness of this conception allows Fincher time and space to focus on the things that mean a lot to him: like making Jodie's ten-year-old kiddie seem like a budding brainy lipstick lesbian. (Fincher's close study of the perverse snarkiness of John Schlesinger pays off here.) The movie peels away all the touchy-feely "humane" layers of Hollywood moviemaking to get to a highly formalized abstraction not seen much on cineplex walls since the first release of ZABRISKIE POINT. This can make the picture seem schematic, bloodless, and devoid of idiosyncrasy and warmth. And yet and still: in the words of Jerry Lewis' lawyer in THE KING OF COMEDY: "Who cayuhs? WHO CAYYYUUHS?"</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-07</date>
		<username>supermaninthejungle</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>amazing!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is a masterpiece... David Fincher once again proves he is the best modern film maker we've got... While not quite up to par with Fight Club, Se7en, or The Game, Panic Room nonetheless is an achievement in film making. And when I say film making, I mean directing and cinematography. The writing sucks. David Koepp, who penned such notably horrible scripts as The Lost World: Jurassic Park 2 proves that he is completely incapable of brilliant screenwriting. However, Fincher takes this lackluster script and turns it into a work of staggering genius. Jodie Foster is perfect as Meg Altman, and Forest Whittaker steals away every scene as a do-gooder thief. But the real gem here is Jared Leto. In sharp contrast to his roles as "Angel Face" in Fight Club and a heroin junkie in Requiem for a Dream, his portrayal of high-strung Junior is Oscar-worthy. Overall, Panic Room is dark, moody, scary, and incredible. The way the camera captures every nook and cranny of this New York townhouse is mindblowing. The final moments are breathtaking - your heart might even stop beating for a few seconds. Fincher is god. Absolutely amazing...</fullReview>
	</review>

I will admit I went to this movie not expecting much, and I was pleasantly surprised leaving very happy. If you are going to see one film this weekend, I recommend this one.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-03</date>
		<username>reimann810</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Is the Panic Room, the safest room in the house?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Movie choices are often a matter of taste. I personally don't like olives, but many do even when it's not soaking in a martini. Jodie Foster's new film, PANIC ROOM, was anything but an olive for me. Most films deal with conflict of one sort or another, good films take the movie goer to the next level referred to as "complication". Foster's character finds herself with her child in conflict when intruders invade her home and seek the safety of the panic room. The plot becomes an emotional complication when Foster's character becomes trapped outside the panic room with her child trapped inside with the intruders. That's good story telling with a twist. The film is edited especially well and does not lose the audience with a series of quick action scenes. So, here's my suggestion, stop sucking on olives and go see the PANIC ROOM.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-03</date>
		<username>Craig Silliphant (onlymaxpower@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Not Fincher's best work --- but he is a God.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>David Fincher's thriller, The Panic Room, was a forum for amazing visuals, if nothing else. The acting was first rate, and the dialogue was very believable. However, the plot had a few holes and left a bit to be desired. Fincher is known for his twist endings (Seven, The Game, Fight Club)and great material. This foray came up a bit lacking. With that unpleasantness out of the way however, it was an engrossing thriller that did deliver chills and spills. Fincher's use of computer animation and real shots made the viewer feel as if it was a ghost floating through the house, moving through keyholes and floorboards to be privy to all the action. If Ridley Scott is one of the most over-rated directors (besides Alien and Blade Runner) then David Fincher is probably the most underrated. Like Michael Mann, Fincher has a unique visual style and production design asthetics that are astounding. David Fincher is a God. But, even Gods make mediocre films occasionally. Lucas made Episode I didn't he? The Panic Room, while better than most of the Hollywood drivel that comes out every year, does not hold up well to Fincher's earlier work. But the dude's got shots, man. 3 out of 5 stars</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-02</date>
		<username>cureholder</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Absolutely Fantastic Execution!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This film is my favorite kind--an extremely simple premise that hooks you in, but executed in such a way that virtually all the bases are covered and it is unpredictable.David Fincher, the genius behind Fight Club, does a stunning job of turning an ordinary house into a menacing backdrop for terror. The film is well-planned, in that the set-up makes the implausible plausible. The acting is good (Forest Whitaker is again great, in what is sure to be yet ANOTHER underappreciated role for him!)One of the more interesting facets of the film is the contrast shown between BAD and EVIL. While this subtle distinction eludes most people most of the time, everyone will see it in this film.Run, do not walk, to see this film!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-02</date>
		<username>anya_angie (anya_angie@yahoo.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Cinematography, Score, plot outlining, definitely the best.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I see movies I expect nothing. I am there to be entertained, so if a petty detail might bug me I don't mention it until I see the movie in its entirety for myself, then if it's still an issue I analyze it. Well, I was not disappointed with this movie. When it started out slow at the very beginning I knew it was to establish some characterization, but I was worried about my older sister saying it was too slow. Well, she didn't say a word about it.WARNING, A SMALL SPOILERI wasn't disappointed in anything. I suppose that's because I didn't expect anything. Since I am legally blind I asked my sister to read who did the music, which is something I always look for in movies. When she read the name Howard Shore I couldn't help but say "Oh YES!" in a bit of a loud voice. I loved his score for Lord of the Rings, and I was not disappointed with this score. The plot was dry, but there were some twists that kept me interested. Our mom is a diabetic, and I bet when she sees this movie and sees the girl into sugar shock, she won't want to watch anymore because it's too scary. I couldn't help but think of that while the poor girl lay there almost dying.SPOILER DONEThe performances are okay, but Jodie, Jared, Kristen, and Dwight all stand out. I was surprised when I came home and looked this up and saw that Jared was in it. I knew the voice, but since it was too dark to analyze faces I didn't really pay attention. But I loved Jared in Urban Legend and I loved his portrayal here.The most impressive thing besides the score was the cinematography. Definitely worthy of an award of some kind. Very innovative, perhaps the best I have seen since The Mummy (1999) and its sequel.If you expect a lot from this movie you may get let down. Try to be neutral, and you just might be surprised and entertained. I can't help but rave about Shore's work in this, it's awesome.Looking back I was only disappointed in the characterization. For example I did not feel any emotion at all for any of the characters except, near the end, the girl and Jodie, and the "bad guy turned good guy." There was little room for that I suppose. Still I would have liked to have felt as if these people were "real" I think is how I want to say it. More than just your typical thriller characters. The best thrillers to convey that kind of emotion I suppose is "Don't Say A Word" and "The Skulls."Again, if you expect a lot, you probably won't get a lot. But if you expect nothing, and just go because you're bored, you might be surprised.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-02</date>
		<username>Caliban-23</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Good movie, poor ending.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie had me sitting on the edge of my seat until the end of the movie. Jody Foster performed very well in the leading role. And literally I enjoyed 95% of the movie. It was the last 5% that caused me to have a let-down.The problem was that there were several outcomes at the end of the film, and I felt that the writer choose a very safe ending. What disappointed me about the ending was that there was no 'grey' area. The movie ended quickly and in a very neat and tidy hollywood script fashion.</fullReview>

		<username>taz027us</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Sad</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>My wife and I have been looking forward to seeing this movie for weeks now. On her night off, we went to the theater and paid our 20 dollars and grabbed a couple of good seats. The show starts with some incredible credits, very nice, and that's where the fun ended. How stupid does David Fincher think the movie going public is??? I'm not one to pick apart a movie on stupid technical stuff, but this was just plain bad. Time after time, one thing after another, we almost walked out of the theatre. And talk about predictable; my cousin's kindergarten play was more of an "edge of your seat" production than this movie. Before I close, I would like to apologize to the late Mr. Hitchcock for Mr. John Epstein's comment "David Fincher has mixed his own style with Alfred Hitchcock's!". Mr. Hitchcock was a master of suspense, David Fincher, however, should call my little cousin. In closing, I feel my wife and I would have enjoyed our 20 dollars better if we had watched it burn on our front lawn.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-01</date>
		<username>jujues</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Don't Miss David Fincher's Latest</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I was totally on the edge of my seat for most of the movie. Even if you've seen the trailer you don't exactly know what is going to happen ? and when. I don't want to give too much away but I will tell you the basic premise since it is pretty much common knowledge. And for all you wimps out there ? It isn't a scary movie but a suspenseful / creepy one.Jodie Foster plays Meg Altman, a newly single mother who buys a huge NY apartment. The realtor refers to it as a combination of brownstone &amp; townhouse. One of the bedrooms contains a safe room or PANIC ROOM where you can go if you're being robbed or attacked. The room is equipped with closed circuit cameras, emergency supplies and a buried phone line. Plus it is reinforced with 3 inch steel. Pretty impenetrable.Needless to say the first night in the apartment three intruders (Forrest Whitaker ? who's always excellent, Jared Leto ? sweet cornrows! and Dwight Yoakam ? almost unrecognizable with his choice of headwear) enter the apartment and the Altman women (Kristen Stewart plays the teenaged daughter, Sarah) find themselves running for their lives to the safety of the PANIC ROOM. What follows next is roughly an hour and a half of cat and mouse with a few twists thrown in for good measure. The director David Fincher (who also directed Se7en and Fight Club) uses some pretty cool techniques to keep you in suspense. I loved his use of sound and silence and how he takes you into the action with his use of strange camera angles and perspectives. Keep your eyes open for the long shot through the kitchen ? Very cool.4.5 buckets of popcorn out of 5</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-01</date>
		<username>smilingzipper</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>PANIC FRIDGE, or Son of HOME ALONE</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Why did I go see this? The only thing subtle about this movie was the fridge in the kid's bedroom, right beside her bed no less. When I first saw that I thought "that's unbelievable, ugh, what a spoiled brat, and what a lousy set decorator" but then later as things unfolded I got the picture loud and clear - ah ha! - and I became quite enamoured with the fridge.I liked the mom/daughter thing above anything else in the movie, not enough of that these days and those were my favourite parts in the movie. So if I were the KING OF HOLLYWOOD I would have decreed the script to include more of that mom/kid stuff (I'm a sentimentalist, why not?)and exclude...if I had a bottle or 2 of white out handy I'd blot out the villains, dab a few drops on the whole panic room idea itself. OK, maybe not get rid of it altogether, I'd keep it as the focus but shrink it down to something more compact...how about "Panic Refrigerator" (did I tell you that I thought the kid's fridge was a nice touch? The kid has a fridge in her bedroom, mom has a panic room, hmmm...anyone care enough about this movie to take this further?) I'd change the three robbers into a trio of Japanese concert pianists who sleepwalked into rich people's fridges to dip their fingers into tubs of cavier and whatnot the night before the big recital because this was their way of purging themselves of their pre-concert panic and post-concert anxiety over reviews. Critics these day can be so brutal y'know...whoops, that would have made this into a more interesting film, my mistake.David Fincher made Aliens 3 so maybe he wanted to do HOME ALONE 3 or something, because the girl does look like Macaulay Culkin (well maybe only for that scene where she raised her hands to her ears to block out a loud noise) but casting dept definitely should have gotten Joe Pesci to play one of the robbers. It would have been hilarious if it were Pesci who got his hand stuck in the door. I'd be rolling in the aisles to this day as they say. Bring in the Home Alone gang I say, bring in stunt co-ordinators too, to make the action sequences more like gags, more zany. Poke-you-in-the-eyes-if-I-don't-punch-you-in-the-belly. That kind of thing is pure gold. Keep it simple, smartguy.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-01</date>
		<username>evangeline</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>purty but weak</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I am a sucker for beautiful cinematography and I did get my fix, but how sad that this is all there was to this film. David Fincher has a story to tell, but rarely does he seem to fully exploit it. He only touches on what is torturing his creative spirit and then style seems to overwhelm him and the result is a stylish mimicry of a good story. In Panic Room visual beauty is all there is and it motivates all action, lighting and character development. Darius Khondjii- always the great cinematographer that he is- carries this whole effort on his shoulders. There is barely any decent acting, the story line is trivial, the characters are motivated by nothing but moving the plotline forward and any logic and/or reality are completely excluded. I have to say Forrest Whittaker is sweet as always, but apart from him and the camera, there are no real heroes here.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-01</date>
		<username>im_a_focking_dumbass</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>good, but not fincher's best</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was worth my time and i plan on seeing it again. I think Fincher's superb ideas in directing are once again shown in this movie. However, i think the script somewhat lacks the power of the other movies he has directed (ie. Fight Club, Se7en, The Game, and Alien 3). While I definately would recommend this movie to anyone, i would also warn them that this is the worst film he has directed so far.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-03-31</date>
		<username>micleung (Mike.Leung@CyberJunkie.com)</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Not as great as the reviews make it sound...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Before I went to watch The Panic Room, I was extremely psyched and eager to see it and felt like this could be a movie that is worth my $8.50 and that I could not wait 3 months for the DVD to come out.It fell short of my expectations. The psychological twists and turns did not impress me - I was searching for something more along the impact of The Sixth Sense or The Others. I did not find that in this movie. In addition, I have a big problem understanding movies that aim to cross genres and be both a thriller and a comedy.Comedy? Yes, Comedy.No fewer than two dozen times, the audience exploded into laughter as the thieves' characters were more like the stupid robbers in the Home Alone movies. I faught between telling myself that was the point of the movie, and that it was a goof-off on the part of the scriptwriters. As a result, I found it difficult to generally be scared or frightened or thrilled because each and every time, the suspense is interrupted by laughter and silliness.Is it dark humor? I don't think so. It's not so much dark humor as a totally misguided plot. Jodie Foster's character and her daughter's performance are great - they are genuinely scared, but I see no connection between their fright and the robber's silly behavior.To conclude, I felt like laughing and shaking my head at this one.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-03-31</date>
		<username>Ken Cochrane (kcochrane)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Good Movie, Check it out.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room starring Jodie Foster, is an action packed suspense thriller, that has an ending that will make you cheer. I saw this movie on the second day of its release and was surprised to see so many people in the theater for the Saturday matinee, especially on as nice of a day as it was.The movie is about a soon to be divorced mother and her daughter that move into this great townhouse in Manhattan. The Townhouse was formally owned by a paranoid rich guy who added some extra features to the house to make it more secure. One of the extra features is a panic room. A Panic room is a place where you can go in case someone breaks into your house. The room is totally secure surrounded in concrete and iron. They are made so that no one will ever be allowed in unless you want them to come in.Here is the problem 3 guys break into the townhouse looking for the missing money that belonged to the dead rich guy. They didn't know that the house had 2 people in it until it was to late. With some quick thinking the mother and daughter end up in the panic room. They should be all safe now right? Wrong the stuff that the thiefs are looking for is in the panic room and they will do anything they can to get in to it.The movie was pretty good, slow at times but picked up at the end. There is one scene in particular that is pretty good, and is worth mentioning. The 3 bad guys decided to draw them out by tainting there air supply, so that take a propane tank and feed the gas into the room. I won't tell you what happened, but lets just say it was a pretty big bang, with lots of cool special effects.All and all the movie was very good, and it kept you entertained until the very end, I only have one problem with the movie is that it should be about 5 minutes longer. They do a good job with the development of characters but they don't say what happens to them in the end. I give it a 9 out of 10 and I recommend that you see it while it is in theaters. I don't think it will be the same at home in the living room. The best part of seeing it at the theater was hearing and seeing everyones reactions for parts of the movie.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-31</date>
		<username>dltdvd</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>An exciting thriller...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When you first think about the premise of "Panic Room," you would think that it's just a cliche like most of the movies out there. However, with the exception of a typical burglars-break-into-house idea, I find the chemistry of this movie to be totally unique and elaborate with all of its modern era Alfred Hitchcockian-type camera work that director David Fincher uses quite often. Fincher is also able to make the story thrilling, yet quiet. It often makes you wonder what's going to pop out around the next corner.The story centers around Meg Altman (Jodie Foster), a recently divorced mother, and 11-year-old her daughter Sarah (Kristen Stewart). They are interested in buying a huge house in Manhattan, which the real estate agent gives them a tour, and introduces them to a safe room known as the panic room. This particular room is used as a hideout from burglars, it has its own phone line, video monitors, and the room is made of very strong steel so the bad guys can't get in. They won't be needing the panic room any time soon...or will they?Soon enough, we are introduced by three burglars who each have their own different personalities. There's Burnham (Forest Whittaker), the brains of the outfit, the designer of the panic room, Junior (Jared Leto), a foul-mouthed leader of the group, and Raoul (Dwight Yoakam), the deranged psychopath with a gun. When Meg notices the three men in the house, she quickly wakes up her daughter and rushes into the panic room. She asks the burglars why they are here, but what they want is inside the panic room, and they won't leave until they get it.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-31</date>
		<username>David Ferguson (fergusontx@gmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>high rent/bad night</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Greetings again from the darkness. Always one to give Jodie Foster a shot on opening weekend, I am a little disappointed in this one. Decent little thriller, but director David Fincher (Fight Club, The Game, Se7en, Alien3) and Hollywood writer David Koepp again just miss offering up a masterpiece. The comparisons I have seen to Hitchcock make me cringe. The trio of bad guys is at times cartoonish. Jared Leto is almost unrecognizable as the ring leader. Forrest Whitaker is the burglar with a heart and Dwight Yoakam is cast as pure evil. His role is poorly written and we know what he is capable of from his stunning role in "Sling Blade". Jodie turns in another professional, believable role, but is let down by the script and direction. Her daughter played by Kristen Stewart is unable to create the sympathy from the audience necessary for her role. Some ridiculous moments prevent this from being the taught thriller it should have been.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>good film, slightly sub-fincher</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you go into Panic Room knowing that its a david fincher film, you probably won't enjoy it as much as someone who is completely oblivious to finchers filmography. I expected great things from the man who gave us Se7en and Fight Club. Panic Room is a good thriller, butt not a great one. Jodie Foster acts as well as...jodie foster. Leto, Whitaker, and Yoakam are equally impressive. The camera work is great. I'm not entirely sure how fincher pulled off some of the shots...probably with some of the techniques he pioneered in fight club, good editing, and a great crew. My one complaint, why did he have the camera fly into the flashlight? Sure, it looked awsome, butt it wasn't really relevant to anything. Also, it starts off a little slow, butt that can be expected in movies of this genre, its almost an essential. In the end though, this film entertains, and even scares you a little. Theres also some comedic moments. Plus, the titles are just plain cool...almost as cool as fight club's titles...almost.7/10</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>Joos</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>A worthy addition to Fincher's body of work</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room is not a masterpiece. That disclaimer should be taken not as a knock against the film, but merely as an advisory for those that are expecting this film to be a work of genius in the way that Fight Club was. This film is more akin to Fincher's The Game in that it takes a tried-and-true film genre and shows that a simple of story can generate incredible suspense. This isn't the type of film that will leave you mulling over the intricacies of its plot and meaning for days; it is 100 minutes of adrenaline. I am going to avoid going into great detail about the story and even the performances; this isn't the type of film that needs to be analyzed on every minute level. Quite simply, Panic Room is an excercize in the way that a great setting, coupled with superb acting (for the most part) and direction, can create a very enjoyable night at the movies for either thrill-seekers or students of film, even if many of the plot developments are heavily foreshadowed. The suspense isn't achieved in the ends, but in the execution, and Fincher's ability to continually create an engrossing and entertaining product across his body of work is what makes him one of Hollywood's best talents at the moment; this film is no exception. The casting, as was anticipated, was nearly perfect, though I found Jared Leto's character to be overly comical in a quite serious film. All gripes aside, this film is quality, and is one of the best nights at the movies you'll have in the annual spring lull. My rating: 8/10.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>MrMovies84</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Quite Disappointing</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Panic Room" is an odd duck of a movie, in that it is a potentially bad idea given to a good director who happened to make it bad anyway. "Seven" is a fantastic film from director David Fincher, and while I think "Fight Club" is woefully overrated, I understand that Fincher does indeed have talent. Unfortunately, "Panic Room" does not take advantage of the key elements of a suspense flick, even though a fine director is at the helm. Claustrophobia is barely even mentioned and does not come into play whatsoever even though the movie could have made the panic room tiny, therefore creating feverish suspense. On the contrary, the panic room seems rather spacious and quite enjoyable. Also, the second the "bad guys" enter the house (that's not giving anything away) they become comical cartoons. Jared Leto is especially annoying as comic relief in a film that needs none. Instead of being afraid of the bad guys, we can't be because they might as well be Daniel Stern and Joe Pesci (ironically, one character is referred to as Joe Pesci in the movie); they aren't scary, they're pathetic. I'll admit that there are some mildly suspenseful parts, but they are often rudely interrupted by a dumb joke or a hackneyed plot device that conveniently leads the characters into another ridiculous situation. The ending is weak at best, and I was ultimately disappointed because I thought David Fincher might have taken a giant step forward in the medium now that he can choose almost any project he likes, but alas, he has tripped and fallen backwards.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>TOOKE2</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>First rate thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Jodie Foster stars as a recent divorcee who moves in with her daughter to a "townstone" house on the Upper West Side of NYC. She quickly finds that the house has a hidden "panic room;" a fallout shelter for rich eccentrics. When three robbers look to find some hidden treasure, Foster, and daughter Kristen Stewart, have the room as their only means of survival. Foster is spectacular in her finest role since Nell, and Stewart is her match as her precocious daughter. Forest Whitaker, and, especially, Dwight Yoakam are standouts as, respectively, the conscientious and psychotic thieves, though Jared Leto is over-the-top. Fincher's direction towers over a weak script by David Koepp, creating real tension out of a contrived situation. A winner. ***1/2 out of four.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Another Great Fincher Film</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I loved Se7en, I loved Fight Club. Panic Room is no different, why? because I love it. David Fincher is slowly becoming a new Hitchcock. Not to say he is replacing him, but the styles of the directors are similar, alot of imagery. Great camera work, haunting visuals, and a Pace that never drops. Alot of effects that were used in Fight Club are used here plus some new tricks.The characters are well developed for their purposes. The actors, all superb. I really enjoyed watching Jared Leto in this film, as well as Jodie Foster and Kristen Stewart and Forest Whitaker.We become involved with both sides and nothing becomes unclear. We see how human all these characters can be and we see the leaps and bounds they will go to for survival.You might think that the film would get boring if everything takes place in a house. You quickly learn that you are wrong. Character chemistry comes into play and we don't want to miss a beat.I loved it, I gave it a 9. Do yourself a favor and see it.</fullReview>

		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fincher Delivers Again</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What makes a good movie is the story. Panic Room has a simple story, but it certainly darws you in. Also at work is Fincher's vision of this movie. His camerawork and visceral images are at work here like they were in his earlier movies. In lesser hands, Panic Room would have been lost as something simple and uninspired. Proof of this is the scene with the fire. His images tell the story in a way that could have otherwise been blase'. Yes, see Panic Room for the story, but also David Fincher's visceral imagery.</fullReview>

		<username>theunitednations</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Not Fincher's Best, But Still Pretty Dang Good</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Personally I prefer "The Game" out of his other films, but that's just me, I like them all. There is definitely a dark mood brought about by this film. It's got the requisite good mixture of thriller, drama, some laughs, and the like. It is clearly more mainstream than "Fight Club" but that's not a bad thing. There's isn't a whole lot to say about it without giving too much away (I had been avoiding the previews for months because I wanted to go in as blank as I could). Good thriller, realisticaly played out. You'll probably like it.One thing that you can always expect from David Fincher is a really neat-o opening credit sequence, and I sure did like this one.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-03-27</date>
		<username>apuluvmanjula</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Why this is the greatest film of 2002 (so far)...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Because most of the films released so far this year have been really dull and uninteresting, whereas this film actually engages the viewer for more than twenty minutes. Intense thrillers don't get much better than this. I suggest you go see this film with a large audience. If the audience has as much fun as mine did, you will be cheering and gasping with all the rest of 'em. Never in all my years have I ever witnessed a movie-going audience cheer and applaud at a particularly intense moment in any film. "Panic Room" actually makes you fear for the lives of Jodie Foster's Meg Altman and her daughter (who oddly enough is a bit of a tomboy--go fig).Speaking of Jodie Foster, she has never been better. It's a wonder why we never see more of her in film. After her two Oscar wins before she was thirty, one would think that she would be the most highly sought after actress in Hollywood. But, being the choosy woman she is, she only plays in the films that interest her. And it's no surprise what drew her to this role. On one hand, Meg Altman is a bit of a paranoid, borderline clautrophobe insistent on moving into a very large New York townhouse with a special "panic room" she can hide in if worse comes to worse (which it actually does--on the first night in the house!). On the other, she is a tough, resourceful woman who remarkably shines through the toughest binds, especially when attending to her diabetic daughter. This is not too much to give away, as the film manages to convey this highly suspenseful twist through a very subtle and implicit means. Very little of this film is out-right revealed. You have to pay attention, if you blink for just a minute you may miss something important.David Fincher does it again by taking a relatively simple story line (three burglars break into a large house to find a hidden stash of cash while the two inhabitants are inside) and weaves this brilliant thriller into a wonderful thrill ride. I'll even go so far to give Kudos to Jared Leto, Forest Whitaker, and the surprisingly convincing yet purely EVIL Dwight Yoakam for their ecstatic performances as the three burglars. Jared Leto is probably the most inept and ridiculous burglar out there and one cannot help but laugh at his banter with Dwight's Raoul and Forest's Burnham. That banter though quickly subsides (thankfully, as too much may have ruined the film) as the real action begins...I won't say much more to keep the fun from being wasted. Have some fun this Easter weekend and go to see this great film. You won't be sorry!</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Claustrophobics beware.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Finally a thriller that fully deserves that description. David Fincher's signature style makes this solid script into a gripping movie experience. No cheap scares here, but if you manage to sit still (not as easy as it sounds), you will feel your own accelerated heartbeat. Mercifully, relief from the ever-mounting feeling of claustrophobia comes in the form of a delightfully black humour, mostly at the expense of the somewhat inept robbers. All in all, a movie to remember - although you might be glad when it's over. There is only so much stress the human organism can take, after all.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-03-04</date>
		<username>Axl (Movieman19)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>3 1/2 out of 4</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I happened to catch a screening of David Fincher's new film "Panic Room" while I was on vacation in Los Angeles. Since 3 out of 4 of his movies have been disappointing for me, I wasn't to enthusiastic about it.It tells the story of Meg Altman and her daughter Sarah. Meg has been recently divorced and both of them are looking for new life after the rather unsuccessful marriage. So they settle down in the big city and find a nice, cozy, perfect house. Or is it...They learn of a safe or "panic" room in the house that has video screens, buried phone line, ventilation system, and a 1 foot thick steel wall. Why would a house need a room like this and when would they need to use it? They find out soon enough.One of their first nights in the house (You'll never guess) people break in. Meg and Sarah are able to get to the Panic Room quick enough, however, to hide from the intruders for a short time. So the first 2 questions on the 2 girls' minds are, of course: Who are you, and what are you doing in my house. They find out that the burglars want nothing other that what is in that room. In fact, they won't leave until they get it. So what is in the room that is soooo special. Are you just dying to know otherwise you won't see it because it looks too scary or something? Well I'm not going to tell you. It's against IMDB regulations.I will however say that this is a very VERY creepy film. If you get the heeby-jeebies already when you stay home alone, this movie will make you catatonic. Just because it takes place in a house doesn't mean there isn't room for fancy camera work. David Fincher can and does take the camera wherever he wants to. Whether it's through cracks in the wall, keyholes, or coffee pot handles, the camera will go there.So did I like it? Yes I did. It is my favorite movie of 2002 so far. (Keep in mind there haven't been many good ones) I loved pretty much everything about it. Do I recommend it? Yes, but only to people who loooooooove a good scare.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2014-07-04</date>
		<username>clay_animator</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>Terrible screenplay</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Most of the people involved in this film did a fine job, but none of that could save this awful screenplay. The entire plot is full of these little moments where the story would have ended if the character thought for a second or acted like a rational human being.The film starts with our villains breaking in and our protagonists hiding in the titular panic room. The burglars need money out of the safe in the panic room it can't get it while it's occupied. Now, the goals of all of these characters aren't really in conflict. The burglars aren't interested in harming anyone and Jodie Foster would probably be more than happy to let them have the contents of the safe especially since she didn't even know it was there. So it would make sense for the burglars to at least try to explain why they broke in, but instead they give some cryptic answer and try to break in to the panic room. Later in the film, the burglars try to smoke the main characters out with some propane. This at least sounds like a plan that makes sense, but the way our heroes escape this is so stupid and so implausible that it makes your brain hurt. After searching the supplies for like 10 seconds and not finding any gas masks, which seems like it should be standard for a panic room, Jodie Foster decides to light the propane on fire. If I were to make a list of ways I would deal with a room filling with propane, burning it would rank somewhere below trying to hold my breath for six hours. What's worse, is this actually works without murdering everyone like it would have in the real world.The movies full of little moments like this. There's no real tension because the villains are idiots and a normal person could have waited it out in that room no problem. The only reason there's any conflict is because Jodie Foster is also an idiot.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2011-07-29</date>
		<username>Cedric_Catsuits</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Silly script</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>There are too many anomalies in the story for this to be considered realistic, and without realism the viewer will not believe the story and therefore quickly lose interest. I won't detail the errors in case you want to watch it and make up your own mind. Let's say, Meg demonstrates some intelligence, but it appears to be selective and geared towards creating dramatic film sequences - maybe she knew her story would be turned into a movie?! Stupid script aside, the performances are all quite good and the tension is aided by good lighting and camera work, albeit said tension is lost due to aforementioned errors. We do learn a lot about the characters and some credit is due for that.However, with the viewer having invested some interest in a character, it seems pointless to undo all that good work by skimping on a decent ending. It may be logical in terms of the way the film is constructed, but in terms of the story I found it unsatisfactory.If you can stand the frustration and disappointment, it's worth watching for the good points, but as a film overall it deserves a low rating for sheer stupidity.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2011-01-11</date>
		<username>TheLittleSongbird</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Could have been better, but efficient and slick enough</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Overall, I did like Panic Room. While it is not as good as Se7en or Fight Club, it is slick and efficient, and you can tell that David Fincher was making an effort to make this good. He is a good director, and he does do a decent job directing. Occasionally though, the breakneck camera work and unconventional angles get in the way of the storytelling and the action, so while Fincher succeeded in trying to impress, occasionally he tried too hard. The plot is also rather formulaic, the script is sometimes lacking and the film loses its way in the pacing towards the end.However, I loved the suspenseful atmosphere, there were occasions throughout the course of the film where it was claustrophobic, and the scenery and dark colour palette were well judged. When the dialogue was good, it was good, while Panic Room does start off wonderfully with a very innovative title sequence. Although it does lose its way, the pace is efficient enough to keep the plot afloat, and the acting is fine. Jodie Foster is very good as the gutsy heroine, while Forrest Whittaker is quite poignant as one of the intruders. I was also pleasantly surprised by Kristen Stewart, I personally have never considered her as much of an actress, but she is quite decent here.So overall, a slight disappointment but a slick and enjoyable flick. 6/10 Bethany Cox</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Stibbert</username>
		<score>0.6</score>
		<shortDescription>Far from perfect, but still quite good</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room has a great story with potential. Unfortunately there are some annoying and very obvious errors that shouldn't be there. They put this film down a bit.Meg Altman, a newly divorced, moves into her new flat with her daughter Sarah. On their first night they get some uninvited guests and seek refuge in the "panic room", a bunker inside the house. Unfortunately what the thieves are looking for is inside the panic room as well.Panic Room has an original story with lot of potential. Unfortunately the characters don't live up to the story and there are some obvious holes and errors that pulls this whole movie down. The story, however, is well told and thrilling from beginning till end witch helps a lot, but David Koepp should have done some more work with the script.The cinematography and editing, however, is excellent. There are some nice long takes and beautiful moves. The composition of the shots, lightning and over all look and feel of the movie is good. The cinematographers does a good job in capturing the mood of the film and the feelings of characters. Jodie Foster delivers as Meg Altman and Kristen Stewart's kind of tomboy style works good as Sarah. The rest of the cast delivers a adequate performance, but still good enough. Dwight Yoakam, Jared Leto and Forest Whitaker makes a good cast for the thieves, but I didn't think Patrick Bauchau did too good as Stephen Altman. In my opinion the wrong man for the character.You don't really notice the score. It's just laying there, building up the mood and excitement. It's really not given that much focus, but it's a good classic score by Howard Shore.Panic Room is a good movie, by all means. I can recommend it because of good cinematography and an original story. It's well worth to watch and if you don't expect all too much you won't be disappointed.</fullReview>

		<username>turnerb-2</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Don't Panic - It's just a room</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room shows that just because you have a place of refuge in times of trouble does not mean it is always the safest place to go. After being left by her husband for another women Meg (Jodie Foster) and her daughter Sarah (Kristen Stewart) move into an Upper West Side 3 story brownstone home which belonged to a deceased millionaire. There is a panic room off the master bedroom which is impossible to get in from the outside. Foster, who is claustrophobic and her daughter who is diabetic are forced to hide in the room when three intruders break in. The intruders are under the impression that the house is empty. Foster tries to drown her divorce feelings in the bath tub and with a bottle of wine on the first night. She wakes up in the middle of the night and notices the intruders on the monitor in the panic room. Foster is able to wake Stewart from an upper floor and make it back to the panic room before the intruders, after a few rides on the house's elevator. Burnham (Forest Whitaker) is a security expert who also builds panic rooms. Whitaker wants some fast cash that is stored in the panic room. Whitaker's partner Junior (Jared Leto) is the grandson of the deceased owner. The third intruder, Raoul (Dwight Yoakum) is a fight ready to happen. Foster and Whitaker do a wonderful job playing these roles. Whitaker who is usually the big hearted character is almost able to turn around, but in the end still shows the softness. Foster brings a little Clarice (Silence of the Lambs) out in the movie with her domineer. These are two great characters that help bring the darker version of Home Alone (1990) out. The elements used to emphasize the theme of Panic Room were the lighting and the music. Both of these elements add to the suspense and dangerous feelings in the movie. The lighting in the Panic Room was low key throughout most of the movie. The scene where Foster is on a mission to get her daughter released from the panic room and she is disabling all the cameras in the home one by one really shows how the low key makes the movie seem almost black. The music puts a twist on your typical horror film music. The Panic Room leaves me with the impressions that even a steel framed door and four walls of concrete cannot always keep you safe.</fullReview>

		<date>2005-04-15</date>
		<username>Eddy Durnan</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Another involving thriller from director David Fincher...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room Meg Altman (Jodie Foster), a divorced woman in her 30's and her daughter, Sarah (Kristen Stewart), are caught up in a cat-and-mouse game inside their new New York brownstone when three burglars come looking for a hidden cache of cash. Mother and daughter hide in the "panic room," a secret room designed for just such a purpose, but still end up fighting for their lives.While not as taut as 'Fight Club' or 'Se7en', 'Panic Room' (written by David Koepp) is still another involving thriller from director David Fincher. Getting back to basics, the filmmaker seems to delight in making the house appear to be gigantic, but at the same time contained, creating a claustrophobic feeling of dread that really brings you into the house with the characters. Jodie Foster gives a solid performance, and it is one of her best yet. The ending is a little flat, but you'll be too busy gazing at your chewed-off fingernails to notice.~ 8/10 ~</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>A fantastic, seat-of-your-pants, thriller movie.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw this movie when it was aired on national TV last night. I think Kristen Stewart (who played Sara)was brilliant in Cold Creek Manor, and seeing that she starred in this film, was what attracted me to it. The film is about a mother (Meg Altman) and her daughter (Sara Altman) who buy an enormous townhouse, complete with working elevator and a full security PANIC ROOM, in Manhatten. However on the first night in the house, three armed robbers break in an attempt to steal a fortune which they think is theirs by rights. Unfortunately, Meg wakes up and realises what is happening. She and Sara only have one chance to survive. So the claustrophobic mother, and the diabetic daughter take refuge in the panic room. Sure, with four concrete walls, a reinforced steel door between them and the robbers, as well as monitors that allow them to see every room of the house, they seem pretty safe. But when they realise that the robbers are staying put, things start to go wrong. The Panic Room is more of a Prison Room. It gripped me the entire way through, it seemed so real, so possible, that I had real trouble sleeping afterwards!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2005-02-20</date>
		<username>bunior</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Stunning choice of wardrobe for Jodie Foster</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Sorry, I just had to get that in there before I started.'Panic Room' is essentially a basic cat-and-mouse thriller with a decent premise, typically over-stylised by director David Fincher. Fincher's work is mostly enjoyable, and the end result looks polished and pristine, but sometimes you have to ask yourself exactly why he does things the way he does.When Jodie Foster and her daughter move into a new house, they must spend their first night in the panic room, a specially reinforced room built into the house to protect you and your family in the event of a break-in, as that is exactly what has happened - burglars, in the form of Jared Leto, Forest Whitaker, and Dwight Yoakam, who, incidentally, have come for the hidden millions in the panic room.Like I said, it looks good throughout, Fincher's trademark camera-work and effects and tricks on show nearly the whole time (shots moving through cup handles and cross sections of flooring), but what sets it above being just another run-of-the-mill thriller are the lead performances. Foster is excellent, as always, and the three intruders play brilliantly off one another. Yoakam injects a real creepiness to Raoul, Whitaker always the strong, level-headed Burnham, and Leto in frantic mode with a little hint of Tyler Durden as Junior (although he looks like he got Forest Whitaker's hairstylist).There are some good action set pieces and a tense moment here and there, but nothing that's going to have you on the edge of your seat. The movies suffers a little from predictability and a lack of pace, but the dramatic finale rounds it off well enough. A salute to the fact that a movie can be good through good performances, so why does David Fincher insist on drawing it out so he can add more clever camera tricks? Is it for us or is it for him?</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Philip Van der Veken</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Is there something wrong with me because I don't hate this movie?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Hmmmm, after reading the comments on this movie I'm thinking I've seen a completely different movie than all the other people on IMDb who wrote a review about it. Especially Jodie Foster's performance seems to be a point of discussion. Personally I liked what I saw. I'm not saying it is the best, most shocking thriller ever, but it sure was able to keep my attention from the first minute to the last.It's about a woman who left her rich husband because he cheated on her with a B-rank model. Because she wants to take revenge on him, she buys a very big, nice house with his money (of course, that's how angry women are! Hahaha), where she will live with her daughter. There is even a 'panic room', a room where they can hide as soon as they are in some kind of trouble. During the first night that they stay there, some burglars, who are convinced that the house is still empty, pay them a visit, because somewhere in the house the former owner had hidden a lot of money.Don't expect any special effects, explosions or other kinds of special things that they like to put in today's movies. This is a thriller like it could have been made 30 or 40 years ago. Perhaps that's what bothered some viewers, but does that mean that this movie can't be good? Not in my opinion. Something else that might have bothered some of the viewers may be the fact that you don't get any images of the city or the surroundings. All the action happens in the house, and the biggest part of it in the confined space of the panic room itself. I guess this may be a perfect movie for the people who loved Phone Booth. It's more or less the same principle, but this time in a house and with a woman that you don't love to hate. Anyway, I don't care what other people think about this movie. Personally I liked to see Jodie Foster play this role and I think all the actors did a fine job. The script was good, despite some minor flaws and the director did a very good job. What else could you possibly want? I give this movie a well deserved 8/10.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>Thought "Panic Room" was pretty good, overall, but one of Fincher's lesser films. I enjoyed the movie-but I didn't know what the director wanted us to get. Should I feel sorry for the security guard? He only did what he did out of necessity. Right? I liked some of the comic-relief, but found it very out of place. I also like the roving camera passing through walls, staircase railings and what not. But I still come back to the point of like or not-like. 	<review>
		<date>2004-07-23</date>
		<username>Adam White</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>The best it could have been but will never be a classic</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>David Fincher has to be one of the most consistent directors working today. Every film he has directed has made me say "wow!" and Panic Room is no different. With all the twists and turns flying around movies these days it made a refreshing change to watch a film that didn't need a huge revelation half-way through. The film was entirely shot in one location with most of the action taking place between two adjacent rooms so it took great acting and storytelling to keep the excitement levels high.David Fincher knows when to use clever visual tricks and that is one of his greatest strengths. He knows when to go into slow motion (and have me jumping up and down, shouting at Jodie Foster to "Run!!!"), he knows when to fly around the house showing the bad guys' attempts to break in in one beautifully long take. He is a master of the camera and all of his films show it.Casting can sometimes let a movie down but this film flourished because of it. Everyone was perfectly suited in the roles. From Forest Whitaker's nice-bad-guy all the way to the random cop who suspects something is happening. Perfect!It falls short of top marks, not because of any real problems with the film, but because this film could never have been a masterpiece. No director or cast could have made it better than it was.8/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Intense...</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The first time you see this movie you think your heart might burst out of your chest, but by the second time, since you've already seen it, it's not quite as bad. Jodie Foster finally makes a come back after what seems like an entire decade since she's made a box-office smash, and is actually good in it, not like she isn't in any other movie she's ever made. The girl that played her daughter was a good choice. Not only was she good in the character she played, but she also looked and sounded (and in some ways acted) like Jodie Foster. Forest W. was good as usual and had a sympathetic kindness to his role. And Jared Leto was also very good in his part. You hate him so much, and that's usually a good thing when it comes to movies. I loved the writing styles of the writer, and I think that the plot was really well thought out and the ending was just as good as the beginning and the middle half of the film. The last scene of the movie however, was a bit disappointing, considering that it's so laid back compared to the rest of the film. I think that it's one of the better of intense dramas in the past decade, and should have gotten more publicity than it did.I give this movie an 8.5 out of 10. A really good flick to rent if you're not doing anything, and if you don't like scary horror movies, but still wanna get your heart jumped, then check this one out for sure!That's the end of my review.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2004-01-23</date>
		<username>gpadillo</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A mildly diverting thriller, not too bad, not too good.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I expected to hate this movie, and ended up pleasantly surprised by it. Put your brain on hold, expect nothing from it and go along for a delightfully tense if implausible ride. The film relies more on pop and flash than on story development (thank goodness, since the story is threadbare) and it's gimmickry pays off well. It does rivet one's attention to the screen, but there were moments when I really wouldn't have minded the bad guys getting Foster's annoying daughter. Mediocre material made into a passably, fun (and unintentionally funny) thriller.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I've read a lot of the negative comments on "Panic Room", and I can't believe my eyes. This movie was one of the smartest I've seen in recent memory. Sure, it was a bit predictable (I never thought the two main heroines wouldn't come out alive), but the tension generated by the cinematography, directing, and performances of the actors (which were outstanding) was much higher and more satisfying than most "thrillers" filmed lately. For those of you who were confused/upset/bored by "Panic Room", I suggest you stick to watching movies more in your intellectual range...like "Pearl Harbor" or any other dreck produced by Michael Bay... "Panic Room" = 9/10....easily....</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-11-10</date>
		<username>movieguy1021 (Movieguy1021@comcast.net)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Panic Room: 8/10</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>David Fincher's Panic Room begins with an uber-cool opening credit sequence with the credits being superimposed onto buildings. They even have reflections and shadows. In this stylized thriller, the rest of the movie is also slick.Meg Altman (Jodie Foster) is a recent divorcee who is looking for a new house with her daughter Sarah (Kristen Stewart). They find a giant house, complete with "panic room". What is a panic room, you ask? It is a room engulfed in steel where you can hide and there is not way you can be gotten to. Since this is a movie, theives have to come on the first night that Meg and Sarah are in. And, of course, what they are looking for is in the panic room.Panic Room cannot be mistaken for an arthouse movie, or anything of the type. It is a perfect example of a Hollywood movie. Bumbling crooks, main female characters who look weak but inside are strong, teens who are the opposite. In fact, we don't even know that Sarah has diabetes until halfway through the movie. If screenwriter David Koepp had had some more time to make characters, then maybe I wouldn't have been so aback when she suddenly starts to have an attack.Panic Room doesn't slack on tense situations. Anytime when Meg or anyone had to dart out of the room for a quick second (in slo-mo, of course), then you feel like your heart is about ready to jump out of your chest. Camera work by Conrad Hall and Darius Khondji was exceptional. When they panned throughout the house, it may be unnecessary, but it still looks wicked cool. It doesn't rely on split-screens or quick cuts or half-second scenes, it just is smooth and graceful.Foster was pretty good as Meg, but she wasn't anything Oscar-worthy. I thought that Stewart was uneven as her daughter, her feelings were mixed and changed at the drop of a hat. The three criminals (Jared Leto, Dwight Yoakam, Forest Whitaker) were pretty good and their bickering looked like it wasn't staged. Many people have complained about the ending. I'm one of them. It seemed abrupt and unlikely, but it's a Hollywood movie. It doesn't have to be original. And the last scene at the bench was unnecessary, two minutes of added time. It was long enough already. I wished that they could have had the entire movie take place in the house and only a couple characters, that would have made it a more inviting premise.All in all, Panic Room is a very tense movie that pales on characters but still makes you be creeped out of your mind.My rating: 8/10Rated R for language and some violence.</fullReview>
	</review>

	<review>
		<date>2002-08-03</date>
		<username>kidbeat (jbaur@gladstone.uoregon.edu)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Sadistic Suspense</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Perhaps you saw Fight Club and could appreciate the visceral intensity but were put off by its muddled message. Or maybe you saw Se7en and noticed the slick and grainy visual style, but couldn't handle the more grotesque aspects of that film. Or maybe you (like me) love everything Fincher's ever done and cannot wait to be once again welcomed into his world of paranoia, pathos, and amazing visuals. Well, no matter who you are, you need to see Panic Room.In Panic Room, David Fincher pulls out all the directing stops, every trick in his magic black bag of film wizradry and delivers on a simple, solid suspense story with none of the concept or pretense of his previous films. This one goes straight for the gut, fiendishly manipulating every standard suspense contrivance, mercilessly playing with any jangly nerve, and keeping you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.There is not one sour note in the whole film (with the exception of the possibly too Hollywood ending, but it still works). Every aspect of Fincher's technical mastery is on full display. His camera moves gracefully across every square inch of the house which becomes a prison for Jodie Foster and her daughter, and the three men who break in one night in search of the former owners hidden riches. In one amazing shot, Fincher moves from the fourth floor of the house where Foster and her daughter are sleeping soundly, all the way down to the first floor where we see the intruders beginning their break-in, throught the handle of a coffee pot, and then all the way BACK UP to the fourth floor where they finally succeed in getting in without the shot breaking once and sliding the whole time with the cool, slow, impartial grace of a cat burglar.The premise is simple: Foster and her daughter are locked in an impenetrable room in their home, along with the loot that the 3 bad guys are looking for. The bad guys want in, the good guys want them out of the house. The plot is really as simple as that, but in Fincher's hands it turns into a beautifully paranoid battle of wits. No time is wasted on anywhere and the suspense is instantly in high gear. The performances are all perfect, with characters fully developed in their first moments of screen time. You know who everyone is right away, with no time wasted on extraneous details, so all that's necessary is to sit and wait while the tension builds to the breaking point. It is a terribly effective tactic as it leaves the audience totally open to watch the sparks fly without miring them in sentimentality.Essentially, if you like suspense, see this movie.</fullReview>
	</review>

It is a good film when looking away from these issues but the ending spoils the film completely. I am not going to go into details in order to not reveal the plot - but it must be said that I would have expected better from Fincher..</fullReview>

I don't mean it's a work of art, but the flimsy premis (a woman and her teenage daughter trapped in a house with three burglars, spiced up with the addition of a high security "panic room" in that house) kept me on the edge of the seat for an hour and a half. Nail-bitingly good.</fullReview>

		<username>davideo-2</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Very impressive thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>STAR RATING:*****Unmissable****Very Good***Okay**You Could Go Out For A Meal Instead*Avoid At All CostsDavid Fincher applies his usual dark,unnerving touch to Panic Room,another fine movie released this year.The title and the story might seem a little far-fetched to begin with,but apparently there are a number of Hollywood movie stars who have them in their homes,for fear of intrusive fans or whatever.Anyway,Jodie Foster stars as a newly divorced single-mother,who moves ,celebratingly enough,in to a large,fancy new house which has it's own 'Panic Room',a special room cut off from the rest of the house.In an emergency,you can contact the police or any other emergency service.But then,on the first night (how lucky) some thieves brake in on the hunt for a huge stash of cash.Feeling lucky and protected in the panic room,they instruct the thieves to leave.But then there's a twist in the tale when the thieves tell them what they want.....is in their room.The opening credits are excellent.They're all put across like building banners in a most creative way.The thieves are very intriguing characters,as their motives for raiding the house are slowly revealed as the plot goes on.There is clever use of fast-camera angles and slo-mo visuals,and the tension at the end is unbearable.Foster should also be greatly commended for turning in a tense,fragile performance in a sweaty,energetic role while in fact heavily pregnant (and to think she replaced Nicole Kidman because she had an ankle injury!).An original and highly recommended movie.****</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>An intense thriller that keeps you gasping for breath.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room is a brilliant piece of film making. Fincher's unique camera shots build tension from the start and keep it going at a frenetic pace to the climax. Jared Leto, Forrest Whitaker, and Dwight Yoakum give convincing performances as slightly inept bad guys after millions stashed in the house. One of the key shots is a seemless camera to computer graphics to camera shot that starts in the upstairs bedroom, pulls back, down two floors, zooms through a coffee pot handle, pans and zooms through a keyhole and pulls back to 2 shot of the bad guys trying to get in the house. Another interesting shot involves an Close Up on Foster in bed with one of the bad guys, out of focus, in the back ground. The camera rotates to show Foster vertical and the bad guy horizontal. I rate this one high on intensity and camera work. Overall - 8.5</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Just OK</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Jodie and her diabetic daughter close themselves off in a panic room when a trio of hoodlums break in for a hidden fortune in a safe. The problem: the safe is in the panic room.It's well-acted (especially by Jodie Foster and Jared Leto), well-directed (Fincher achieves some incredible traveling shots and shots between floors and walls) and purposefully dark--but it's just average.The plot is original but, other than that, it goes through the same motions any other genre picture would go through. I saw every single plot twist coming and the constant darkness and dim lighting really gets depressing after a while. Also I never felt any urgency for the people and their situation--I was always aware I was watching a movie. And I don't like it when movies put an innocent little girl in danger.It is somewhat worth seeing for Jodie alone (with all due respect, she's a better actor than director) but she's done better movies.
