		<date>2002-04-08</date>
		<username>GiphLag</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Great Thriller with fantastic Special FX</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just saw this movie this weekend and was positively surprised. Jodie Foster hasn't been in anything fantastic since "Nell" and it sure was a pleasure to see her on the big screen. The cinematography in this movie is outstanding and I especially enjoyed the very well done special effects which were used in a very subtle way since the whole movie plays in real time inside one big house. Placing cameras in tight spaces is not very easy, hence the need for some "virtual cameras" places in some incredibly realistic looking environments. It was so well done that you couldn't distinguish between life action and animated scenes. For instance, you see a very normal angle of the kitchen, but suddenly the camera takes you straight through the room past appliances and counter tops so close impossible for a "real" camera, and on to a door that then opens and one of the bad guys enters. Good stuff, go check it out. I'd give it 3 out of 4 stars.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Water into Wine</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>First thing's first: Again, the credits in a David Fincher movie were awesome. I love how he always sets the stage with the credits and his attention to details (except for the "rain on the windshield" scene in Se7en) are second to none. As far as the rest of the movie went, the story was mediocre (not the worst neither), and probably, in my opinion, on par with The Game, but not better than Se7en &amp; Fight Club. I don't know, however, which director out there could have pulled off what Fincher did in Panic Room with such a setting to work with i.e. one house, one night, small cast etc...David Fincher did it, and I am willing to bet that he allowed himself this movie, not because the story was so wonderful, but because it was a great challange for him. I hope nobody claims that he did not pull it off, because the dead-spots in the movie were close to none--a very difficult feat with what he had to work with (very much the same with Fight Club where Fincher had TOO MUCH to work with, and he ended up pulling that off, as well). Therefore, don't blame the director on this one if it did not strike your fancy, there are too many other variables. Having said that, I will not say much more, because a lot of my fellow IMDB users have said multifarious things already, and have brought up many good points. Nevertheless, I will say that Jodi Foster, besides being a great actress in Panic Room, was looking pretty HOT in this movie (and I have never really thought she was all THAT--perhaps it was the nerd glasses that made her look so good). Dwight, "The Cowboy Singer," must have taken some acting lessons, for the man was pretty root-n-toot-n good in this one (a far cry from his bland acting in When Trumpets Fade. Enuff Said! I will be getting this movie on DVD for its eye-candy alone. Just watch David Fincher go down in movie history one of these days for his vision and contribution to the industry.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-06</date>
		<username>Steven Reynolds</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Performances save the day</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>David Fincher can always be relied on for well paced, visually interesting, darkly tantalizing entertainment; and David Koepp is a fine and versatile writer. It's no surprise, then, that "Panic Room" doesn't disappoint, but it hardly ranks with their best efforts to date. As in "Fight Club", Fincher's wall-dissolving camera tricks are pretty impressive. But they actually work against the tension in this story by placing the audience beyond the claustrophobic reality of the house. Similarly, Koepp's story premise and dialogue are good enough to keep you watching, but his plot offers few real surprises. Ultimately, it's the performances which save the day. Leto, Whittaker and Yoakam strike the perfect balance between incompetence and menace; and Jodie Foster manages to be maternal, terrified and fearless ? all at the same time. No wonder she has two Oscars.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-06</date>
		<username>(SCF-5)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Terrific Suspense Thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is one of those movies that guides the viewer through the movie. You are shown enough to figure elements out on your own--without being treated as stupid. Jodie Foster is wonderful, her terror and her love and fear for her daughter (who is also a terrific actress, I look forward to seeing her in more movies) make for a wide range of emotions and attitudes.The movie shifts gears several times, so the viewer never gets too comfortable or bored with a situation. David Fincher gives a whirlwind two hours that is heart-pounding (I didn't check my watch once, which generally implies the greatness of the movie). But after "Fight Club" I expect that out of him. I rank it as one of the year's best so far.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-04-05</date>
		<username>Richard Chappell (rchappell32256)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Fincher delivers the goods with yet another stylish and riveting thriller!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Anyone who's familiar with Fincher's work ("Alien 3"; "Seven"; "The Game"; and "Fight Club"), knows that his films aren't well-known for their simplicity. However, his latest release, "Panic Room", isn't what most would expect from him. Unlike his previous films, the plot of this one is considerably straight-forward. Jodie Foster plays Meg Altman who, as a single mom having recently settled a divorce with her wealthy husband, moves into an expensive four-story brownstone in the Upper West Side of Manhattan along with her 11-year-old daughter, Sarah. The brownstone looks to them like the ideal place to live - equipped with all the modern-day conviences. It even has a "panic room" that encases you behind a steel door in the event someone were to break in. Now that's protection!What they didn't expect though was that three burglars - Junior, Burnham, and Raoul - had come prepared to rob the house that night. They're looking to find a safe, one that the original owner of the house had kept hidden in the floor somewhere, that contains millions in bonds. They break inside, surprised to find the the new owners had already moved in. Meg wakes up and finds there are thieves in the house, and immediately runs to wake up her little girl. The mother and daughter quickly lock themselves up inside the panic room, narrowly escaping capture. Unfortunate for them, even though they're safe, the emergency phone with which to call the police is dead. And of course, as you may have guessed, the safe that these crooks are looking for happens to be inside in the panic room.Burnham, the burgular whom Forest Whitaker plays, built the house and knows every niche and cranny of the place. He informs Junior and Raoul that it is impossible for them to penetrate the steel door. He says that in order for them to get inside the panic room, they have got to somehow get the woman to come out. This incites a dangerous game of cat-and-mouse between Meg and the men who threaten the lives of both her and her little girl. Its all very intense."Panic Room" is somewhat different from David Fincher's other movies. According to the director, the film is a popcorn flick. "There are no great, overriding implications," he claims. "It's simply about survival."Even so, Fincher still manages to deliver the goods as usual - displaying the same stylish cinematography he showed in "Fight Club", as well as his knack for keeping people on the edge of their seat as he did with "Alien 3" and "Seven". Not only that, but the film also features a terrific and energetic performance from screen veteran, Jodie Foster. Altogether, I recommend this film to suspense fans who are looking to see something different for a change. This one is definitely worth a look. Star Rating: ***</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-04</date>
		<username>prezike</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Fincher misunderstood once again</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>When I heard about "Panic Room" I was quite intrigued as to how this movie was going to include one of the most important, and consistently overlooked, aspects of David Fincher films. What I am referring to is his devotion to sending a strong message, which is usually a societal critique, within almost every film he has created.Maybe it's because I generally agree with his critiques, but I am surprised to see so few reviewers, both amateur and professional, overlooking the message of this film, and even some of his others. The NY Times seems to have completely missed it, as have several other critics who have argued "Panic Room" "lacks substance." This is also funny because the complaints some had of "Fight Club" was that it was pretentious, over the top, and intent on sending a message to the audience. So what does Fincher do? Actually panders to the critics (whether it was intentional or not is almost irrelevant) by creating a subtle psychological thriller that also sends a clear message about American society and values. But then it seems that these same critics completely miss it, thinking that this is more of a classic "what you see is what you get" thiller.Based upon Fincher's history, I found this VERY hard to believe, when I read some reviews. Then I saw it with my own eyes and once I thought about what he might be saying for one moment after leaving the theater it hit me.I don't think it is anyone's place to tell anyone what that message is, but I suggest to all those who have seen it, or even haven't, to examine the primary themes of the film, the character relationships, and their values, which were all played out in some key scenes. One being, in particular, the last camera shot in the grand finale, which I read someone here argue meant nothing. Well, in my opinion, if you saw that and believed it to posses no meaning, then I think you missed David Fincher's message. Unfortunately, a lot of us will likely miss it because Fincher's style and entertainment value is what they are seeing the movie for. The problem is he has consistently gone beyond that, but it usually falls upon deaf ears with the audience he attracts.Hopefully one day he will be remembered for his attempt in bringing social criticism and thought provocating scripts covered by conventional and pop appearing Hollywood film making. Until then most will likely think of him as a Hitchock disciple who incorperates a lot of style and tricky camerawork (all of which are evident here, like his patented camera movement through walls and other solid objects) to gain his audience. There is more there...just look a little harder.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-04</date>
		<username>boondocksaint20</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Panic room is a really good film, but it could have been great</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>*Spoilers Ahead (mostly minor)*I just went to see Panic Room, and I have mixed feelings about it. The trailer definitely caught my attention as something unique, and though only in one location, I knew that David Fincher, director of Fight Club and The Game would deliver. The good news is, on most levels, he does.First off is his incredible use of direction. I have never seen such fancy camera work in a film; the camera will squeak through tiny openings and snake around from one room of the house to another within a single shot. Definitely impressive, and definitely eye candy. Then we find Jodie Foster and her Daughter, both played very believably forced to seek refuge in the house's panic room when a trio of criminals show up. I thought that the criminals were the most interesting aspect of the film, though a tad underdeveloped and way cliched (The type of people you might know in real life that would actually be willing to rob a house, yet exagerated in an over the top kinda way). There were just too many times where they would do things that people in real life would never do. One of which is at the beginning when one of the three criminals, after establishing to the audience that they have had no prior past together until now, asks for Dwight Yoakam's handgun (the only one who brought one) and he nonchalantly hands it to him. Why would a professional hand over his gun to someone he doesn't know, let alone an obvious amateur? Yes, scenes like this really are irrelevant to the story, yet will bother the best of us to no end when we see them. Still, the criminals are played very well. Forest Whitaker was superb as Burnham, the conscientious safe cracker with a heart, and Dwight Yoakam was fantastic, as always, as the cold and mostly calm Raoul, a mysterious member of the trio whose screen presence expresses his adherence to violence and mayhem more than the limited dialogue he has at the beginning. Definitely the most interesting of the three. Jared Leto was good as Junior, yet his character got annoying very quickly (especially since he demanded that he be in charge and ended up making a complete idiot of himself on many occasions in the film). The suspense is there, not necessarily enough to make you scared, but enough to hold your attention. The ending though is very predictable and rather empty, in my opinion. I feel there could have been more to the ending, something profound to stick with you as you leave the theater (I was also hoping the exact opposite would have happened to Burnham that did. He did have a good side, you know). Overall, I enjoyed this film, it was good for what it was, but it could have been great. This is one of those films that doesn't receive a 9 or 10 for a bad script or bad acting since both were good, but because there is potential for so much more that just isn't there. A solid 8 for amazing camera work, great acting and for overall entertainment value. Go see it, you'll enjoy.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-04-02</date>
		<username>Brian A. Cagayat (dresden212@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Hitchcockian thrill-ride</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Director David Fincher (SE7EN, FIGHT CLUB) and screenwriter David Koepp (MISSION: IMPOSSIBLE and two of the JURASSIC PARK films) created this suspenseful thriller set in a brownstone in New York City, which brings to mind the films of Alfred Hitchcock (and reminiscent, in some scenes, of Stanley Kubrick). Jodie Foster shows brilliance in her role as recent divorcee Meg Altman, who moves into the 19th-century, four-story (with basement) townhouse with her teen daughter, Sarah (an impressive Kristen Stewart). Both are believable in their roles, and their relationship as mother and daughter is convincing, both simmering with hatred because of the straying Mr. (Stephen) Altman (Patrick Bauchau), a pharmaceutical industrialist.The first five to ten minutes are especially Hitchcockian. The credits are displayed as floating white letters before various New York City buildings and skyscrapers, and Ann Magnuson, as Meg's friend Lydia, who finds her the brownstone, and Ian Buchanan, as the realtor, ham it up to perfection in true Hitchcock ambiance. The house's previous owner was an eccentric millionaire; the house, though, is large enough for two families, and comes equipped with an elevator, a large staircase located in the center of the room, a fireplace on each floor, and, especially, a large steel-encased security room known as the "panic room," complete with a vault-like, motion-sensitive door, televisions for security cameras that observe every floor of the house, and food, water, and other supplies. Also in this room (unbeknownst to the audience for the first third of the film) is something--a *LOT* of something--that someone wants.[*SPOILERS* AHEAD]"Someone" comes in the form of three burglars, two of which have a history with the house's former occupant: a conniving, corn-rowed punk (and the millionaire's heir), Junior (Jared Leto, very late of TV's MY SO-CALLED LIFE); the designer of the panic room, a disillusioned man played with startling conviction by Forest Whitaker; and an oft-masked, mysterious psychopath named Raoul (in the film's best performance, country &amp; western crooner Dwight Yoakam). The film boasts much needed humor amid the suspense, and the CGI special effects by Fincher and crew (used previously in FIGHT CLUB) fit, especially with a super-long "single" shot that introduces the thieves of the night. You wonder halfway through the film just how can Meg and Sarah outwit the three men, and when they do (in various ways), it's all plausible. No details are left hanging, and when an obvious goof by the men (hint: involving the "eyes") is realized by the audience, it's mentioned (by Raoul of all people) in such a way that it's laughable.PANIC ROOM is definitely the suspense thriller of the year, if not THE FILM of the year. Much owed to Hitchcock for inspiring Fincher in this one, and to all the exceptional performances (yes, even the seemingly inept New York cops who stop by during the night, played by Paul Schulze and Mel Rodriguez, are credible and even memorable in their encounter with Meg). Look for SE7EN screenwriter Andrew Kevin Walker as the "sleepy neighbor." 9/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>

		<username>whigger</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>An intriguing movie once again</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I knew this movie was coming up in last night's sneak preview and I was eager to see it, knowing it was directed by David Fincher, whom has made beauties such as 'Se7en', 'The Game' and 'Fight Club'. And I must say: the movie didn't let me down! It is a solid story about a mother and daughter spending the first night in their new house. A house that isn't really something out of the ordinary except for one peculiar room: a panic room, used in cases of emergency to seek shelter in. It has everything on the inside to keep one alive: survival goods, cameras with views on every angle in the house, a separate phoneline and ventilation system, plus steel walls and a steel door. On that first night three men are breaking in and the mother and daughter seek refuge in the panic room with no means to get out.. The movie is basically a dark thriller which has its funny moments, set in just this one house, delivered by a well-chosen cast.The camerawork is simply fantastic once again: through floors, inside keyholes, etc. David Fincher is a true master when it comes to innovative handling of a camera. Plus his choice of colors, entourage and timing is superb.All in all: a very nice, straightforward thriller [no plot twists at the end or whatever] revolving around an intriguing concept: a room that no one can get in to or out of..</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>RowdyJimmy819 (wliiafan17@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>VERY Intense</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I have to say I loved this movie! Jodie Foster once again proved she is a very powerful actress, and the rest of the crew did great! I only had one complaint in this movie. I'll explain later.The cinematography in this movie was excellent. Conrad Hall does an excellent job of creating a moody atmosphere with the lighting and camera tricks. I especially liked how he made the camera "fly" in and around the house, very nice. (When you see the shot of the burglars first entering the house, you'll see what I mean.)Oscar worthy work, in my opinion.Again Howard Shore provides a great score, almost reminiscent of his work for "The Cell." No need to say more here.The screenplay by David Koepp was great. The story has been done before: a burglary that turns into a cat-and-mouse game with a twist: the use of a panic room. You'd think that with this tried format, the story would be rather boring, but with Hall's camera work, Shore's score (hey that rhymes!) and Koepp's script, this is a VERY intense piece of work. Which brings me to my complaint.The ads for the movie proclaim a movie that will make you jump out of your seat. I did not jump out of my seat; in fact, I didn't even jerk back in my seat. I was hyped for something that wasn't there. Don't get me wrong, the movie/story is great, but just not scary, and that was what I was looking from this movie: to be scared. Although, my heart was going pretty fast towards the end and a few moments in between.So if you're looking for a good movie to take your girlfriend/boyfriend/fiancee/wife/husband/best friend to, go see Panic Room. You will not be disappointed all that much. Just sit back and enjoy the ride!9/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>Chrissy</username>

		<shortDescription>Recommended</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Jodie Foster has done it again, a star role in another intense thriller. Dealing with her recent separation, Meg and her daughter purchase a plush home in New York. This four-story home is a complete package deal, combining the modern conveniences of its own elevator with the door prop locks of yester year. A panic room is another luxury, with TVs hooked up to the home security system, a phone that is not hooked to the main line of the house, and a steel door with motion sensors.Just before going to sleep, Meg disables her high tech security system, allowing the intruders easy access. She is able to get her daughter and flee to the panic room. And realizes she forgot to have the "other" phone line hooked up. After futile attempts via the intercom to convince the intruders to leave, they tell her the only thing they want is inside the panic room. The story unfolds, will the intruders find a way into the panic room, how long can the girls last in the panic room, what exactly is it the intruders want?This movie is edge of your seat, covering your eyes, peaking in-between your fingers, and not wanting to miss what will happen next. Simply put, not a horror flick but a great suspense movie. Go see it for yourself.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Great Directing by David Fincher</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Not to lessen the quality of any other part of this film, but the best part is truly the directing by David Fincher. His unique camera use of one continuous shot, even when changing floors, helps make him one of todays more original directors. He creates his own identifiable style so you KNOW when you are watching a David Fincher film. The story does seem a little slow moving, but it really is necessary since their (the three men who break into the house) original plan was disrupted by the presence of Jodie Foster's character having moved into the house, so naturally they had to think as events occur. And of course Jodie's reaction wouldn't be planned so she wouldn't be prepared in three seconds. The casting was excellent. Dwight Yokam was very creepy and evil, while Forrest Whitaker draws some amounts of sympathy from you. Jared Leto plays off his part very well also, and the three together have a nice blend of chemistry and detestment for each other, that, at some point makes you laugh a little. It's filled with plenty of surprises that make it a great thriller. I saw it in a packed theatre which I think has the best effect so you can feel the tension of the audience in the air. And what an incredible house! Perfect setting for this film, which in itself is a great character, I'm sure that was the plan though.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Panic Room is everything I watch movies for.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw Panic Room this weekend and I liked it. David Fincher rocks. I would even say he has a unique vision unto Hitchcock for the 21st century. His movies include Se7en, The Game, and Fight Club. All excellent movies.I almost hate to say this, but the opening titles to Panic Room are one of the best parts of the film. A revolutionary use of typography, computer generated graphics, and beautiful photography of Manhattan is used to create eye-popping, 3-D titles aligned to the photographic perspectives of New York buildings. After this, Fincher proceeds to make camera moves through a house that know no bounds. Some of the coolest camera shots I've ever seen.Panic Room is a tightly wound thriller that kept my undivded attention for the duration and made me jump, wince, and laught in several spots. Jody Foster's performance is excellent. Forest Whitaker plays a burglar one can almost sympathize with and you won't believe Dwight Yoakam as Raoul. Panic Room is everything I watch movies for.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-03-31</date>
		<username>RolloTomasi</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Claustrophobic?</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Panic Room" is a pretty good thriller, but disappointing as a David Fincher film. Any number of directors could have done this. I can't say that about Fincher's previous three films, which all seemed to need the dark and innovative visual style he brought to them. His latest has moments with the feel of a Fincher film, as if another director tried his hand at a Fincher film. But even sub-par work by Fincher is better than almost anything else out there. First-time DP Conrad W. Hall (Conrad L's son) shares cinematography credit with Fincher regular Darius Khondji, which might have been the difference.What makes "Panic Room" tick is the script by David Koepp. This is an example of a film that survives on its premise, in the way it makes use of its location and the situations that location puts the characters in. The script falls short, however, on characters. Meg (Jodie Foster) has feelings and a past life, seemingly, but never takes on more than your basic celluloid heroin/everywoman persona. Let's just say that Koepp tries hard with her, but doesn't succeed. The film should be her story but the film's construction doesn't allow it. For instance when she enters the panic room for the first time and is closed in, we find out that she has a phobia about small spaces (go figure). She's able to overcome that in order to battle her home's invaders-the only development her character gets. In a way, Burnham (Forest Whitaker), is the focus of this story. He's the one who has to make the tough choices, to do the thinking, to do the most changing. Whitaker's is also the finest performance in this. Not surprising. Even that cop who presses Meg to "give him a signal" seemed to contain more depth than Meg."Panic Room" has one of those great premises that begs to be utilized to its fullest. Koepp and Fincher go a long way toward succeeding. There was a great risk of having to rely too much on coincidence, but the script is cunning enough to get by this. Anyone who's seen the trailer (the known world, surely) knows that a woman and her daughter lock themselves into their new home's ?panic room' when some violent men break in, only to find that all these men came for is IN THERE. Making the panic room both the womens' safe haven AND the reason the burglars are there could make some kind of ?best movie ideas of all time' list. Wisely, the film's creators know enough to just let this be what kicks things off.Fincher and co. don't go in a direction that I thought they would, which probably just means they're smarter than I am: Eventually we know Meg and Sarah are going to have to leave the panic room. When they do, I thought the idea would be to give a heightened sense of their vulnerability-but turn the tables. The invaders finally get them out, only to find they wish they had not when the girls fight back. The film does play this card to a certain extent, but you never get a sense that over the course of the story, the panic room has begun to protect the invaders, not the tenants. What we end up seeing is your standard, overly violent, bloody, couldn't-think-of-something-better thriller ending.The major downfall of "Panic Room" is that it's not scary. There's a lot of nice cinematic tension, but no 'jolts' to make you clutch the elbow rest. But then, this is not horror. If you want scary, rent "Se7en."Grade: B-</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Fincher finally gets it right</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Am I the only guy that has really disliked every David Fincher film to date. I've seen them all. Alien 3- by far the worst of the series.(I loved Alien Resurrection.) Seven- not too bad, but so so bleak. The Game-worst Michael Douglas film ever. Fight Club- Never has a film begun so promising and ended up so terrible. Think I was loving the first half. Panic Room- From the terrific opening credits to the last frame, I loved it. Yeah it's one of those movies where the characters have to do a whole lot of implausible things to move it along, but man it moves. And credit must be given to Fincher as well as the terrific cast. Howard Shore's score is perfect. See it in the theatres if you get a chance. I think it will lose a lot of it's impact on the home screen.</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Panic Room had almost everything David Fincher has in his movies. The burglars kept the movie very entertaining because they seemed to be a bunch of bungling idiots who really didn't think this plan through. 	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>renchloctc</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Great Characters in the movie especially Forest Whitaker</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie starts off with a house tour and then moves slowly up like the first hill of a roller coaster. Next it really gets moving. Jodie Foster ( "Contact", "Silence of the Lambs") and (Kristen Stewart) play mother and daughter. Jodie Foster plays Meg Altman a newly divorced parent. They seem to have a good relationship. The villains in the movie are Jared Leto ("Switchback", "American Psycho") and Dwight Yoakam (Sling Blade". Dwight Yoakam is a little psychotc to put it lightly and Jared Leto's character is a little over the top and crazy. When he panics it is sort of funny. Forest Whitaker "Ghost Dog: the Way of the Samarai" is part of the crew but he seems like the man with a "heart" throughout this thriller. The cinematography was great and even though this is classified as a thriller it had a sppoky vibe to it. It really almost gave the feel of a horror picture. There is some violent scenes but everything seemed pretty realistic. I would rank this as my third favorite David Fincher Picture . My favorite being "Fight Club" then Seven. I am also a fan of the game. So this being my third favorite is a good thing! Its very watchable and different from most movies i have watched lately. GO SEE IT!!!!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>smashy-2</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>An enjoyable, if somewhat disappointing thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Fincher's "Seven" and "Fight Club" were masterpieces in my opinion, so I was enthusiastic to see his latest, "Panic Room." Unfortunately, I am not so enthusiastic about recommending it to others. It is definitely signature style, David Fincher, but it appears as if Hollywood script doctors got ahold of this otherwise excellent movie.To start with, it has all the usual Fincher direction. As a telephone call is placed, you get the camera moving along with the 'pulse' through the phone wires. As a key is inserted in a lock, you are treated to the same perspective as the key. All of this is signature Fincher (see Fight Club's opening sequence if you don't know what I mean). Visually, it is an excellent film. Fincher deserves the usual credit for direction and casting. The actors portray real emotions on screen. Jodie Foster does an excellent job of emoting as a mother, and Forest Whitaker's concern for life comes across colorful conflict.Unfortunately, the writing withers. A sudden surprise illness of the daughter, Kristen Stewart, seems too scripted to be believable. Likewise with appearance of police officers, and the ludicrous dialogue in the '911' call for help. Why do script doctors, writers, and other Hollywood parasites continue to churn out carnage?</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>AMPNOISE</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>A Grown up version of Home Alone</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This movie was the best movie I have seen in a VERY long time. Well worth the hype! It kept me on the edge of my theater seat at all times and was Jodie Foster's best work since Silence of the Lambs. I feel that this will be in the theaters for a long time, so please go check it out.</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>Maggie Burns</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>excellent thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm not usually one for suspense/thrillers, but I am a big fan of Jodie Foster, so I went to see this movie. It's excellent! It keeps you guessing the entire way through. I didn't know how it would end until literally 60 seconds before the film ended. It's a very tight script, not a wasted moment (except maybe a rare few chatty bits with the bad guys) but the whole thing works so well in sequence, always surprising you, that it's definitely worth a look. Suspense fan or not! This movie had me clutching the armrests and covering my eyes. I'm still wired from it, hours later.The cinematography is also amazing. With a very limited set and a muted palette of colors, the cinematographer somehow manages to keep everything visually interesting and constantly varies what you see and how you see it. I love that in movies! There was one funny moment when I realized from the changing angles that the camera person must have been perched on a toilet seat. There are some amazing parts where the camera does impossible things.Overall Panic Room was a lot of fun, completely stressful, and not for the faint of heart!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>UltimateT</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Fincher masters direction, but fails on the ending.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>So far, David Fincher has made 5 movies.He started with Alien3, then moved on to the excellent 7even. With The Game he showed us a great story, but the ending was too happy to accompany the film.Fight Club brought us back to the gritty with an ending that wasn't happy, but wasn't sad.In Panic Room, he gives us nearly 2 hours of seat gripping, nearly over bearing, suspense, but the last two minutes makes us wonder who slapped it on there.Don't let that stop you from seeing it. It's not THAT bad. The movie twists and turns in directions that you'd not see coming, and better yet, while watching, you don't even TRY to think where it's going. It grabs you and takes you for a ride.The only negative comment I really have to make is the fairly ambiguous ending. It leaves things unanswered. Not in a good way like Fight Club where you want to know what will happen next, but in a way that makes you think... so what DID happen?Everyone is superb in this film, Foster, Whitiker, Leto, and yes, Dwight Yoakam. He portrays a character that you can't hate any more. It's just not possible.I give the film an 8/10 Better that what it needed to be to be a good suspense film, but lacking in how much story there is. The concept does limit us to minimal characters and only 1 setting. But, definitely a good film to see and enjoy.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>matrioshka (matrioshka@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Holds its own</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Am I a spoiled movie-goer? Who knows, I think I expect too much in the theater. Panic room was extremely appealing in the trailers, so I did have my reservations about it. I think that partially I was right. Set aside certain concerns about why, how, and what the hell happens during some parts of the movie. I had so many of them it interfered with my viewing pleasure. When I did that and focused on just how the story developed I think I got more out of it. Jodie Foster is good, I don't think its the movie that allows her to show off her range of acting ability. Nonetheless, I can't complain. Forest Whittaker's character is so cliche as a mild hearted thief that I just couldn't even get mad at the writers, I let it go. Is Jared Leto supposed to be this stupid? Oh well, overall, I say acting was balanced out: certain weak moments were forgotten during the intense scenes. I gave it a 7 because I didn't feel that anxiety, that sense of doom, that uncomfortable feeling I associate with psychological thrillers. Or rather, that feeling was involuntary quite rarely. There were parts where I knew it was expected, where I knew what was the director's and writer's intended effect, but knowing and feeling are two different things. But I absolutely LOVED the way scenes were shot, the camera angles and movements, my praises for that. My recommendation, SEE IT, but leave your expectations at the door.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>steve_bv</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Another success for David Fincher</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Panic Room is a wonderful piece of film-making, a pure thriller. Almost the entire film takes place inside of one house, in a near real-time unfolding of events. Fincher takes us on a modern-day Hitchcock ride, building suspense at every turn. With obvious inspiration from "Rear Window", the film is a joy to watch, and keeps you on the edge of your seat. The acting is top-notch, Jodie Foster is great, Jared Leto turns in a performance above anything he's done to date. Forrest Whittaker is magnificent, building his character as much by his actions as by his silence. And Dwight Yoakam is the most surprising, entirely unrecognizable, and one of the most terrifying characters seen on screen in a while--pure coldness. All in all, the acting and directing make this movie subtly disturbing, unlike any suspense film we've seen in a while, from the visually stunning opening credits to the morally ambiguous ending. It all combines to more than make up for minor shortcomings in the script--tacked on developments to hastily add more suspense.In short, it's worth watching. Five characters, one house, two hours, and constant thrills.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>(ssslawman@aol.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Good film...similar to "Wait Until Dark"</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you suspense, you'll like this movie a lot. All of the characters were pretty credible. Perhaps the only aspect that didn't seem credible was that the burglars would choose to strike when they realized that Jodie Foster and daughter were home (as opposed to waiting for them go out the next morning, perhaps). In a way, I found this movie to be reminiscent of the 1967 Audrey Hepburn flick, "Wait Until Dark". The two movies share the following similarities: NYC setting; a trio of bad guys infiltrating the home of an arguably helpless woman; the trio of bad guys looking for something in the woman's home that the woman doesn't know is there; one of the trio of criminals appearing to be more sympathetic than the others (Richard Crenna as "Mike Tallman" and Forrest Whitaker as "Burnham"; and a young girl who helps the adult female main character. There are probably other similarities that I'm overlooking. Overall, this was a very good movie.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<username>MadBadMovieman</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Home Invasion Roller-coaster!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>What an Exciting Movie. A real home invasion roller-coaster. Jodie Foster was Great. Kristen Stewart may get nominated for supporting actress. Good interaction with Jodie. Forest Whitaker was perfect. Dwight Yoakam was downright Evil. He was good in Sling Blade but this was a much more sinister role. He character slowly emerged and you liked him less &amp; less. One scene was very reminiscent of Jack in "The Shining". You'll see. Dwight may get nominated too but they have to get over disliking his character.The twists and turns were very well scripted and directed. Amazing how things change. The Cinematography should get nominated. Screen play was great. Special effects may get nominated too. Not one thing todis-like about this movie except it's hard to grasp home invasion incidents. The best laid plans- don't always work do they.I am amazed there are no votes out on this movie yet. Worth seeing but please don't bring children. Saw way too many 5-10 year old kids with parents and you have wonder what the heck they are thinking. This movie could make some kids very edgy on dark, stormy nights. Be prepared for a few nightmares if you take yours.Would see it again in a heartbeat.</fullReview>

		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>(jhendricks97@rocketmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Don't Panic -- it's not awful!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>David Fincher, the director of great films such as "Seven" and "Fight Club," knows how to create suspense. And with interesting camera movements; and great acting from the cast; he is able to do just that. "Panic Room" held my interest right until the end. But that is where they lost me."Panic Room" wrap's up all too conveniently, and rely's on too many co-incidences. It's as if the films writer made it to the final 5 pages of the script, and then ran out of original ideas. Still, on balance the movie was worth watching. But it won't cause a panic if you wait to see it on video. 3 AND A HALF STARS OUT OF 5. </fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>elshuefan</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>It ain't "Silence of the Lambs" but it ain't bad</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>If you're looking for maximum intensity, this movie isn't the one for you. Don't get me wrong. It's a GOOD movie that works for one viewing. I'm not sure whether a moviegoer would get anything new out of it watching it twice. It's not that complicated. The acting by most is first-rate (we're talking Jodie Foster, Jared Leto, and Forest Whitaker here. Dwight, don't quit your day job). Kristen does a good job as Jodie's daughter. Most all of the plot "twists" are predictable. What holds the viewer is the skill of the actors and the director. Sometimes when a movie is put together well, it works, even if we're thinking 15 minutes ahead and guessing right every time. Should you see it? I would say it's worth a matinee ticket. If you want to pay full primetime price, you're on your own.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-29</date>
		<username>mrsknoll</username>
		<score>0.9</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent - best this year so far</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I find it is so difficult to be entertained these days. However, this movie had me captivated for two hours. There was never a dull moment throughout the entire movie, which really impressed me. Usually, there's at least a momentary lull which I tend to use as a bathroom break. But Panic Room kept me in my seat throughout. Jodie Foster is marvelous in this movie. Nicole Kidman was originally cast for this role, and though I love her work, Jodie Foster was ideal as Meg Altman. She is as strong and powerful as she was in Silence of the Lambs, which is her definitive work. She empowers women in almost every role she takes and Panic Room is no different. Kristen Stewart plays her daughter, Sarah. Take watch of her - she's definately up and coming. I was convinced that she was Sarah Altman - stone on the outside, fragile inside and afflicted with life-threatening diabetes. Forrest Whitaker was also excellent as Burnham - the kind hearted safe-breaker. I was hoping it would turn out a little differently for him than we assume it had to. I haven't seen Jared Leto as a character I actually liked, and unfortunately, Panic Room was no different. Although he's attractive, he just doesn't have the skills as an actor that I would like to see in such a major box office movie. He plays Junior - the money-grubbing grandson of a very rich man who has died; also the mastermind behind the botched plot to rob a supposedly empty house. I will give him credit for playing this role very well - I just don't respect him as a serious actor.I was surprised that the movie started out so quickly - pulling us in almost immediately. I loved that they didn't drone on about who they were and what kind of lives they were leading. I don't know if it was the screenplay or the direction, but I felt it was an outstanding idea to just show the audience who they were through various objects (insulin in the tiny fridge) and short phrases (Sarah: "F-him. F-her." telling us her father has had an affair). This, I think, ensures that we pay attention to the characters' surroundings, which is very important. And also that we listen to what they say. Their facial expressions, body language and tone of voice lets the audience know exactly who they are - and that Jodie Foster is not going to let them win.In any case, Panic Room is a beautifully written and superbly performed movie and sure to be a major box office smash. I highly recommend Panic Room as a must-see for 2002.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-29</date>
		<username>eXistor</username>
		<score>0.7</score>
		<shortDescription>Fincher Light</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I saw this at a sneak-preview. When the (very stylish) opening credits appeared I was hoping this to be yet another Fincher classic, not that it's a bad movie or anything, but I came out of the movie slightly disappointed. It is all photographed beautifully and Foster does a good job, but the problem is it's just not exciting, it's all very predictable and Forest Whitaker in the role of one of the the bad guys? I didn't buy that at all, Jared Leto plays the dumb crook and Dwight Yoakam is the only one that's remotely scary. This is I feel the main problem with the film: it's simply not very exciting and the ending is too predictableIt seems that Fincher wanted to make a film that would appeal to the general public and in that he has definitely succeeded: this is a film that seems to follow the Hollywood guidelines perfectly, there's nothing wrong with that, but It's a shame, because Fincher can do much better than this, but let's just hope that for his next film he goes experimental again like he did with Fight Club(to excellent results)*** out of *****</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-29</date>
		<username>Ghazi</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Nothing to panic about</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm a huge David Fincher fan, and if you like his work, this movie doesn't disappoint. By no means flawless, Panic Room is a solid effort that's definitely worth checking out.The cast is fitting for the most part, I had my convictions against Jodie Foster in this role, but after viewing it I must say she did a good job. The three men who break into the house hold just as big a role also. They provide a good amount of humor at times (as do Jodie and Kristen Stewart, who plays the daughter role fairly well), and are easy to watch on screen. The movie itself moves along pretty quickly, and doesn't have very many dull moments.The standout point is by far David Fincher's incredible camera angles and techniques. If you were a fan of Fight Club's tracking shots that penetrate walls and buildings, and follow objects as they twist and turn (like the apartment explosion scene) then this movie will impress. Towards the beginning, it's absolutely full of them. This movie also holds some very intriguing action scenes that are executed well, though sometimes exaggerated in terms of reality (you'll see what I mean). As far as being suspenseful, at times Panic Room truly pulls of suspense.Overall, the acting is perfectly watchable, and the humor is actually very funny sometimes. If you can look past the mundane plot, the script is actually pretty refreshing in the way its handled. I personally think it falls apart near the end, and the ending itself left me kind of empty. But hey, you might like it. As a whole however, I'd say it's worth a look. Enjoy.</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-29</date>
		<username>vze263p9</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Awesome; had the whole theater breathless</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I just saw this movie a few hours ago and LOVED it. I go to the movies all the time and this was my favorite movie in years. It may be my favorite movie since American Beauty. David Fincher is a genius. His camera work is beautiful. There were "wow's" from the audience as the camera went through a keyhole or a coffee pot. The scenes in the elevator when the wall disappears is wonderful. The plot is not that complicated, but this is one instance where "the criminal with a heart" is successfully pulled off by Forrest Whitaker.Jodie Foster makes a triumphant return to the big screen in this movie. Being a Nicole Kidman fan, I was upset to hear of her departure from this movie. However, Jodie was wonderful. The entire cast was wonderful.ONE FINAL NOTE: COMIC RELIEF --- Some of you may remember this term from high school english and this film is a perfect example of it. It is used perfectly throughout to relieve tension. Without it, the film would have been overbearing.SEE IT AND BUY IT WHEN AVAILABLE!!</fullReview>

	<review>
		<date>2002-03-29</date>
		<username>Eileen Galen</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Much deeper than the previews</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I went to see this mostly because its director did "Fight Club," which I thought was terrific. This film's previews made it look like a scare-you-to-death drama about expensive real estate: a multimillion dollar NYC townhouse. (Yawn) In fact it's about a lot more. It gives you time to think, and the script is great. This film's done tightly, intelligently, and totally grippingly. It's agonizing in places, and it's plenty violent, too. Like "Fight Club," the story asks some questions about violence, and about what hurts the most.Foster plays a soon-to-be-ex-wife - and there's plenty of food for thought right there. She has a daughter, around twelve, who's terrific in her role. Forrest Whittaker as usual is complex, in complete control - and utterly successful. The story is not what I expected. There are some shots that left me breathless, and they do not depend on violence to make their point. There were young teenagers in the theater with their parents, and they seemed to enjoy it, too. A smart, great film.</fullReview>
	</review>

I don't know if it was the screenplay or the direction, but I felt it was an outstanding idea to just show the audience who they were through various objects (insulin in the tiny fridge) and short phrases (Sarah: "F-him. F-her." telling us her father has had an affair). This, I think, ensures that we pay attention to the characters' surroundings, which is very important. And also that we listen to what they say. Their facial expressions, body language and tone of voice lets the audience know exactly who they are - and that Jodie Foster is not going to let them win.In any case, Panic Room is a beautifully written and superbly performed movie and sure to be a major box office smash. I highly recommend Panic Room as a must-see for 2002.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<fullReview>I was very excited before seeing this movie. The trailer was good, I like Jodie Foster, and David Fincher is a great director, with movies like Fight Club and The Game. 		<date>2002-03-14</date>
		<username>Ian (ibuck-2)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Taut action thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Fincher has made for yet another reason to give pause while walking past the usually mundane action/thriller section at the video store. Certainly not as complex as Seven, and without the social commentary of Fight Club, Panic Room is just a good, old fashioned, tension filled game of thrilling cat and mouse. Most films of this sort have plot holes big enough to drive trucks through. You find yourself hating the protagonists for being so stupid as to miss the obvious way out of the situation, or the writer/director for thinking the audience is so stupid as to not see the obvious way out. Fincher and Koepp cover all their bases, at least that I saw. There is only one thing I saw that they didn't do at first, and it was completely understandable that they forgot about it in their panic...and they DO get to it, just not right off the bat. (Those who've seen the movie know what I mean, for the rest of you I won't clue you in)Don't look for subtext or deeper social significance, it's not there, though I did like the gradations of "badness" among the "bad guys" which lent a little bit of moral ambiguity to the proceedings. Fincher is unapologetic in his gleeful pursuit of the simple goal of scaring the pants off us. And when it's done this well, that's enough.</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-04-06</date>
		<username>videofreak2002 (videofreak2002@aol.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>An edge-of-your-seat thriller!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>"Panic Room," directed by David Fincher ("Alien 3," "Se7en," "The Game," and "Fight Club"), works on so many levels that I don't know what to say. The story: Meg Altman (played by Jodie Foster), is a divorced mother looking for a new life with her daughter, Sarah (played by Kristen Stewart). They go to a new house and discover something they couldn't believe. A safe room-"The Panic Room"-that will protect them from any kind of robbery and explosions and all kinds of things. On the night they move in, three burglars, Burnham (played by Forest Whitaker), Junior (played by Jared Leto), and Raoul (played by Dwight Yokham), break in and look throughout the house and discover that there are people in the house, but, there were supposed to be nobody in the house. Then, Meg wakes up and hears noises downstairs and wakes up Sarah and run to the panic room. The only problem is that whatever the burglars want is in that room that Meg and Sarah are in. So, they have to think of ideas of getting them out and not kill them and try to break through the room. My thought for this movie. Leave the house and go see this movie. The cast were excellent, including Jodie Foster's performance. The best performance out of the burglars was Dwight Yokham. His performance was a mean person. He was cool. The script (written by "Jurassic Park," "The Lost World: Jurassic Park," "Mission: Impossible," and "Snake Eyes's" David Koepp), was excellent. What I was most interested by this movie were Howard Shore's music and David Fincher's directing. Howard's music really made the audience on the edge-of-their-seats (his best since his oscar win for "The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring"). But, David's directing steals it. His camera work will take you through places and things that no other director can do. In this one scene, when Meg falls asleep, the camera goes backwards, through the bars of the stairs, climbs down, then comes the burglars, then the camera goes through the lock from the door then comes back and all through the house following the burglars without going to a different scene. It was just brilliant. Plus, this movie made me jump a few times (that's scary, and that's a good movie for me) and made my heart jump several times through some realistic and unbelievable scenes. This is also Fincher's best work since "Se7en" (probably his best work right now). This movie is a keeper. One of the best movies of 2002, along with "Black Hawk Down" and "Blade 2." Also, screenwriter Andrew Kevin Walker ("8MM," "Se7en," and "Sleepy Hollow"), makes a cameo appearance as the neighbor Meg and Sarah awake from across the building. If you like thrills and David Fincher's work, THEN GO SEE THIS MOVIE!! TRUST ME! YOU WON'T BE DISAPPOINTED!!A+ 13/13 ****** (out of ****** stars)</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>Rod-88</username>
		<score>0.5</score>
		<shortDescription>Old-Fashioned Thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Like the Mountain Dew commercial says, `been there, done that,' Panic Room is reminiscent of a movie from yesteryear. It is quite simply an old-fashioned thriller. The plot is simple, the characters are stereotypical, and of course all ends well. Panic Room is the new film from young director David Fincher. Fincher was a very successful music video director that went on to direct standout movies Se7en, The Game, and Fight Club. Panic Room, however, does not live up to his `hot' reputation. One thing that all of his previous movies have in common is that they all have surprising plot twists in the end. Panic Room does not delivery any such twists. It comes off as a simple thriller that does not take any chances. Panic Room is equipped with a very good cast: Jodie Foster, Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto (who was great in Requiem for a Dream), and the quirky Dwight Yoakum. They all turn in satisfactory performances, however, none standout playing the one-dimensional characters provided to them.Panic Room starts with an interesting premise, and it is has you on the edge of your seat in parts, however it will soon be forgotten. This is definitely a disappointed from Fincher. I expected a much more frightening thriller with an `edgy' quality, not this old-fashioned movie with some flashy camera shots. In this day and age, it takes a lot more to shock or scare me.5/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-29</date>
		<username>SimianLogic (learnyourabcs@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>Excellent, could have been better.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I'm a huge fan of David Fincher, so there wasn't really any chance for this movie to suck. Objectively, however, I saw some places where the film could have been a little better. In the beginning of the film, the audience is treated with shots that are reminiscent of Kieslowski's Red, almost giving the impression of an omniscient narrator who can go literally anywhere he wants (into keyholes, through coffee pot handles, through floors, etc.). This is very cool stuff.Once the action kicks in, however, all of this changes. Instead of gliding through the walls and maintaining the illusion that it could all be one steadily-flowing scene (not harsh breaks from one room or place to another, only intercutting within each locale), the narrator almost completely disappears.The movie is still very entertaining, but I think it could have been much eerier if David Fincher had kept the illusion that all of this was unfolding in front of one observer.8/10</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-27</date>
		<username>Steven Bailey (skad13@aol.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Best thriller in years</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I've just read an interesting book titled Brave Dames and Wimpettes, in which novelist Susan Isaacs posits that most modern movie heroines still use old feminine wiles instead of brainpower to get what they want.Urgently recommended viewing for Ms. Isaacs would be Panic Room, one of the best thrillers I've seen in years.The movie's heroines are Meg Altman (Jodie Foster), a recent divorcee, and her young daughter Sarah (Kristen Stewart). They've just moved into a three-story Manhattan home of the kind to be found more easily in movies than in Manhattan. The prime draw of this house is its "panic room." In the event of a burglary or similar emergency, the resident locks himself inside this room and uses its separate phone line to call the police.On their very first night in the house, Meg and Sarah find out just how good to be true this room is, when three unruly burglars break in. It happens that the house's previous owner left a few million dollars behind in the house, and wouldn't you know it, the money's in the same panic room where Meg and Sarah lock themselves. Oh, and for good measure, Meg didn't have a chance to get the separate phone line hooked up.Yeah, I know, this whole set-up could happen only in the movies. But before the thrills are unleashed, the movie takes the time to set up the relationship between Meg and Sarah, and it's nicely done. Because we get to know them for a while, we have a stake in their peril.And believe me, these are not two women who sit around screaming and waiting for some moronically written boogie-men to kill them. Simply because the marvelous screenplay by David Koepp (Jurassic Park) allows these women to think, they manage to stay one step ahead of the burglars, who eventually find themselves cowering as much as those wimpettes Isaacs writes about. You'll not have heard such cheering from a movie audience in quite a while.Except for some overly swooping camera movement at the beginning, direction by David Fincher--formerly known for such existential dreariness as Fight Club and The Game--is as perfectly taut as you could hope to find in a thriller.As for the lead actresses--what a wealth! According to The Internet Movie Database, Kristen Stewart is only *11 years old*. But with her interplay with Foster and her remarkable subtlety, she can only be described as...well, the next Jodie Foster.And what is there to say about Foster? I find her one of the most beautiful women in movies, simply because she makes intelligence sexy.Going to a seeming no-brainer like Panic Room is like expecting an ice-cream cone and getting a dinner at Four Seasons.Panic Room is rated R for much adult language,</fullReview>

		<username>KubrickCRM114</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>David Fincher still rocks.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>I honestly wasn't sure what to expect from Panic Room when I entered the theatre. I have been a fan of David Fincher since Alien 3 (forget the critics, it was a well directed film) but I was leery of David Koepp's screenplay; I like his work but his scripts usually aren't of that Se7en/Fight Club caliber. Needless to say, I was not disappointed.The film is steadily paced, given the idea that the character are trapped in a small space and it feels like forever, which is not bad at all. It made me more claustrophobic the longer it lasted. Of course, David Fincher was making the camera into a character all its own, going through floors, walls, keyholes, coffee pot handles, railing, you name it. The special effects are superb, but DO NOT have to make up for content, unlike many films appearing so often (Lord of the Rings). The special effects never enhance the story, just the presentation of Finch's visionary directing style. The cinematography was beautiful, giving the panic room itself an assaultingly dark overtone. Conrad Hall and Darius Khondji are definetly on their game. The dark, ominously large house is spooky almost to the point of being gothic. Also, you have to give credit to a film that makes Dwight Yoakam scary as hell. I can't go into dark rooms of my house without getting a chill thinking about "Raoul" jumping out at me. Any movie that scars me for life (Jaws, Taxi Driver) is, at least in my opinion, a good movie.All in all, go see Panic Room, it is worth every second and penny to say the very least. </fullReview>

		<shortDescription>Effective thriller</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is the latest offering from director David Fincher (toning down his trademark visual style this time) and features Jodie Foster as a woman who buys a weird building after her divorce from her husband and moves in with her daughter. The building of course has this "panic room" which is supposedly this impenetrable place that no one can get in or out of.. though a trio of hoodlums (including Forest Whitaker and Jared Leto) decide to try anyway. This film has a number of chilling moments and ratchets up the suspense.. though they throw in a few too many cliches (such as the daughter needing an insulin injection at precisely the worst moment). 	<review>
		<date>2002-03-31</date>
		<username>Kirasjeri</username>
		<score>0.8</score>
		<shortDescription>ENTHRALLING, COMPELLING, AND JUST PLAIN GOOD</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The Safe Room ("Panic Room" sounds better!) cannot be breached by the three home invaders determined to get the millions stashed inside that room. The mother and her diabetic daughter, who just moved into the upscale Manhattan townhouse don't know it is there - and haven't even installed the phone system yet! They are trapped, with time running out and the daughter quickly heading for diabetic shock. The invaders will do whatever it takes to get into the Panic Room, or to find a way to get the frightened pair to come out. Such is the concept of "Panic Room" - and it works very well, although somehow I left thinking it could have been even better considering the cast.It is reminiscent of home invasion movies from "Wait Until Dark" to "Straw Dogs" - although there is no giant bear trap in this one. The three invaders do try some original stuff with propane gas and switching identities. At one point the situation is reversed with the mother outside with the gun, and the invaders in the Panic Room with her daughter. It all works very well to a claustrophobic, tension-filled effect. Jodie Foster nicely underplays the mother, and Forest Whitaker reprises his well-known "lovable bad guy" act to effect. Jared Leto is good as the whiny "brains" of the gang, and Dwight Yoakum correctly psychotic as the homicidal sadistic villain. Kristen Stewart is adequate as the generic kid.One of the more effective aspects of this film is the direction that well uses the architecture of the house; its sterile, scary atmosphere is heightened by the fact that there is almost no furniture or decor, they having just moved in. Very well directed.A good, entertaining movie. 8 out of 10! </fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-30</date>
		<username>Melissa McNamara (queequeg092500@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Foster and Fincher - A Winning Combination</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>Having set his tone and style with the breakthrough "Fight Club", David Fincher creates another cinematic masterpiece with "Panic Room". It's the story of a recently divorced woman (Jodie Foster) and her daughter (Kristen Stewart) looking for a home in New York. They find one and as an added bonus, it has a panic room, a steel lined room with tv monitors, seperate phone line and ventilation system and emergency supplies stocked in it. On the first or second night in the house, three intruders come in, not knowing anyone is living there. What follows is a stand-off of sorts between the intruders (Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto, and Dwight Yoakam) and the residents of the house, laced with nail-biting, edge of your seat moments of suspense and action. Although not having as many speaking lines as normal, Jodie Foster is brilliant (as usual) and belivably carries the movie and the emotions in the film. Just her facial expressions are amazing. Another incredible force in the movie is newcomer Kristen Stewart, who plays Foster's smart-mouthed, tough but sweet, pre-teen daughter. This being Stewart's first time under the weight of a major role, she handles it with wonderful depth and realism. Not to be forgotten are Forest Whitaker as the oafish burglar, and Dwight Yoakam is a bad guy you love to hate. Both are memorable, along with Jared Leto as a wannabe thug. Fincher's inventive camera angles, x-ray vision style, and uniquely-lit sets really set the mood. He is a powerful director, who has been quite underrated. I loved this movie! I was on the edge of my seat the whole time and I will definately be going to see it again!</fullReview>
	</review>
	<review>
		<date>2002-03-29</date>
		<username>giancarlo de lisi (giancarlorocks@hotmail.com)</username>
		<score>-1.0</score>
		<shortDescription>Fincher is Fantastic...and so is Foster!!</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>It is not common to discover a Director in Hollywood who can consistently deliver a good film. Such is the case with the experimental and exceptional David Fincher. While he has created only a handful of films such as ?Fight Club', ?The Game' and ?Se7en', this is even more of a reason why such attention must be drawn to this ambitious and multi-faceted Director. In his latest film, ?Panic Room', Fincher creates a superbly suspenseful and eerie piece of entertainment all the while breaking new ground in terms of technological achievement. Jodie Foster stars as a newly divorced single mother who upon her first night in her spacious new Manhattan apartment battles against intruders. Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto and Dwight Yoakam portray these unorganized criminals who will stop at nothing to capture hidden money locked away in the apartment. Within this spacious apartment, there is a secret room that resembles something of a bomb shelter. Contained in the room is a bank of security monitors, extra food and supplies and no possible way in. That is until the trio of intruders break into the home and force Foster's character and her daughter to lock themselves into this claustrophic room. David Koepp's script is full of pulse-pounding moments and will certainly keep many at the edge of their seats. But as a discerning viewer will note, it is quite difficult to script a film that takes place entirely within a vast apartment. And so does ?Panic Room' retain a sense of excitement even though its locations are limited? Indeed. The script is tight and has even a sly dose of humor to relieve the tension some audience member's might experience throughout this taut film. This film can be known to be a great film by observing its' many elements that make it a good time at the movies. First and foremost, the opening credits say a lot about the film's artistic sense. The opening title sequence has the credits of the film displayed as though they are Marquis on high-rise buildings. While the sequence is short, it is succinct and creates a sense of excitement among the anxious crowd. Furthermore, ?American Beauty' Cinematographer Conrad W. Hall plasters this film with rich ambience in a dark undertone that reflects a sense of urgency with every passing frame. Hall and Fincher collaborate on an extraordinary level, as the film is a luscious example of poetic beauty conveyed through excitement, thrills and astonishing cinematography. In addition,, as mentioned earlier, the film breaks new ground in terms of 3-d compositing. If one has seen the film and does not recall these scenes - that is because they were so well done that they are almost naked to the human eye. Fincher embarks on a journey of discovery as he explores the wonder of Digital Animation within ?Panic Room'. One such example is how Fincher uses his camera to track through the whole house from moving the camera through the kitchen in one single take, or bringing the camera through floors and walls in order to maintain one single, fluid sequence of beauty within his film. And even though the film is dark, moody and very chilling at times, it is all done with a sense of class and achievement that catapults this film onto another level. If one has seen the film, they may recall this class conveyed on screen with the first intruder sequence. Fincher terrorizes the audience and will never make anyone completely secure about their home's personal safety when he films the intruder sequence. With one single take, Fincher travels the rampant apartment and makes the camera track from the front door, to the back door, through walls and through floors all in one take in what proves to be the film's most technologically memorable moment. And while this review seems to be centered upon the technological achievements of the film, that is because it is a wonder to watch. Yet, in terms of a well-built and solid suspense film, it is well worth the panic to see the film.Giancarlo's Rating: ***</fullReview>
	</review>

		<date>2002-10-23</date>
		<username>MacaulayConnor</username>
		<score>0.4</score>
		<shortDescription>The three Stooges vs. Ripley-without-brain</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>This is like a "Die Hard "scenario: Hero can't get out, villains need something the hero has, they can communicate with each other, but not reach each other. If you do a movie like this, it is always risky. Because people tend to think what *they* would do in this situation and usually people come up with better ideas than the hero - or the heroine in this case. That's because they don't feel any stress, unlike the hero - does. But if the audience is smarter than the hero it soon will start to get annoyed or bored... They just don't care anymore and thoughts are no longer with the movie - the director loses the audience. The other risk is that it is too predictable. So the director and the author have to come up with something original AND they have to fill all the holes. This is the only way to keep the audience on the right side, identifying with the hero, feeling his slim chances of getting away, feeling his fear. But in Mr. Finchers film you just think: why do they act like this, so stupid? Why don't they do this or that? etc.Another rule is: the more dangerous / the better / the smarter the villain appears the more danger to the hero. And in the end - the bigger the victory will be.This is why "Die hard" worked (Alan Rickman as the fast thinking, strategic genius, Godunov as his extremely dangerous hit-man), and that is another reason why this movie fails - the villains act like the 3 Stooges...Macaulay J. Connor 4/10</fullReview>
	</review>

		<shortDescription>Beautiful, thrilling, and a joy to watch.</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>David Fincher's "Panic Room" does everything right. Writing is excellent. The people seem to say things that would be natural in a situation like the on presented in the movie. Acting is pitch-perfect. Jodie Foster is fantastic. Kristen Stewart is a child actor that rivals Haley Joel Osment. And the thee crooks, Forest Whitaker, Jared Leto, and Dwight Yoakam give memorable and fascinating portrayals of their complicated characters. Another extreme pro of "Panic Room" is the cinematography. From the opening credits to the end of the movie, each frame has its own unique, "artsy-craftsy" persona that can be sometimes subtle, or fantastic with computer animation. Fincher is a director I have admired for a long time and each of his movies are astounding both in material an visuals. Howard Shore's music sets the tone of the movie right. Another thing I loved about "Panic Room" is that although the robbers can be humourous, you still don't like them. Other movies have tried to make villains funny and gross at the same time and it ends up being excrement (John Travolta in "Broken Arrow", for one). It somehow worked here, something I thought would never happen in movies. "Fight Club" wasn't terrible, but making "Panic Room" has assured me that Fincher hasn't succumbed to the Dark Side. This one is on par with his other works- "The Game", "Se7en", and "Alien3". "Panic Room" is a colossal experience. See it. 10/10</fullReview>

		<fullReview>Pretty simple. Meg and her daughter Sarah move into a beautiful old house in Manhattan, right after Meg and her husband get divorced. She notices that one of the rooms are smaller than it should be, and the realtor explains this "Panic Room". A room that is a "safe-haven" for anything that could go wrong. You then have the 3 burglars that break in and try to get something from the house. They are furious because they hadn't planned on Meg moving in yet, just a slight obstacle for them. The movies keeps you on the edge of your seat for most of the time, and has you jumping in some cases. The camera work of David Fincher is absolutely amazing. Anywhere he wanted the camera to go, it went; keyholes, through walls, through floors, anywhere. The only reason I gave the movie a 7 out of 10 is because I found it pretty predictable. Although, still good, I was able to determine what was going to happen long before it actually did. In general, a good movie.</fullReview>

		<shortDescription>A brilliant exercise in cinematography</shortDescription>
		<fullReview>The art of cinema is first and foremost a visual art. David Fincher brings this visual aspect to new heights every time, which makes him one of my favorites. His expert use of the camera can be matched to Christopher Nolan's mastery of editting.The idea of the movie is not really amazing: a mother (Foster) and her diabetic daughter (Kristen Stewart) move into a spacious townhouse, and on their first night there three burglars break in. Their only defense is the built-in panic room, which unfortunately is what the thieves are after. So far, nothing innovative.The story contains a few twists, and this is a suspense movie more than anything else. But to me, the real beauty of the movie is the cinematography. I've seen this movie on a big screen, and again on a TV screen, and both are remarkable. This is a rare quality in movies.The soundtrack dictates a suspense atmosphere very adequately, and the actors are quite good (though not amazing). After you've seen this movie once to enjoy the storyline, watch it again with the sound off, just to enjoy the breathtaking shots and the lighting of the scenes.For the excellence in filming, I gave this movie 8/10.</fullReview>
